description: Guillaume Roget, former chef of Saint Jean de Luz’ star restaurant, Brouillarta, has crossed Socoa Bay to take over this kitchen in Ciboure on the Ravel docks above the port in a location that is perfectly suited to this restaurant, whose name means ‘storm’ in Basque. The interior sports a sober, airy vibe with lots of space between tables and a glimpse of the open kitchen to the rear of the dining room. Top of the range Basque ingredients are quietly crafted, jazzed up with the occasional bold association and flanked by a deluge of fine sauces. Wine lovers may like to know that the 5 courses of the Arnoa menu are prepared according to the wines chosen by the customer – the chef is a former sommelier.

name: Vieux Pont
description: Nestling in a leafy green site and dominated by its castle, the quaint village of Belcastel rises up on the right bank of the Aveyron River. Work up an appetite by strolling along its cobbled streets and up and down its steep paths! Quietly feeding hungry travellers is something of a tradition in this family-owned business opened by the grandparents of sisters Nicole and Michèle Fagegaltier, now at the helm. The enticing menu naturally highlights local delicacies such as lamb and veal from Aveyron and Ségala, Aubrac beef, Bigorre black pig and sweet onions from Cévennes, without forgetting fish and farmer cheeses. Stock of caramelised sweet onions, Laguiole braised cabbage, or Greffeuille lamb sweetbread, sorrel-flavoured mayonnaise and grilled leeks. This old bridge believes in food that satisfies the soul and the appetite!

name: Le Restaurant des Rois - La Réserve de Beaulieu
description: One of the most opulent luxury hotels of the French Riviera, dating from 1880 and later extended in a Renaissance Florentine style, has been playing host to monarchs and Hollywood stars since 1900. Dining on the terrace facing the Mediterranean is a magical experience. The food is now conjured up by chef Julien Roucheteau, straight from Paris (Table du Lancaster, Scène Thélème). While remaining loyal to the establishment’s heritage, he is already adding his inimitable hallmark, depicted by graphic presentations and consummate craftsmanship with a specific theme for each dish: seafood, smoked, spicy, acidic, refreshing…

name: Jérôme Nutile
description: Jérôme Nutile brings plenty to the table: "Meilleur Ouvrier de France" 2011, he notably presided over the heyday of Hostellerie Le Castellas, in Collias. In his Nîmes location, a converted farmhouse, he celebrates the seasons through delightful dishes: tender leeks cooked on Camargue fleur de sel, fondant of wild salmon confit; the traditional French classic of hare à la royale cooked two ways – in the style of Antonin Carême and Senator Couteaux's recipe, beautifully executed and tasty. Add to this the friendly and competent service, a fantastic list of regional wines, and you have everything you could ask for!

name: Le Chantecler
description: On the Promenade des Anglais, Le Negresco, which celebrates its 110th anniversary in 2023, sits majestically in its seafront location. Le Chantecler, its fine dining restaurant, has "Meilleur Ouvrier de France" 2015 Virginie Basselot at the helm. In this exceptional setting, the Normandy-born chef doesn't beat around the bush, training her laser-like focus on serving up creative contemporary cuisine in the form of two set menus (without options, except for the dessert course) and an à la carte menu made from top-notch ingredients. Simplicity wins the day: cf. the poultry, white cabbage, kumquat and pistachio, or the subtle use of olive oil in the sweet dishes.

name: La Réserve Rimbaud
description: “Montpellier the Gifted”, as the city likes to bill itself, provides the backdrop to this well-hidden restaurant on the banks of the Lez. Slightly off the beaten track, it boasts a divine riverside terrace shaded by plane trees – a refreshing haven in hot summers. This modern and sophisticated Reserve is located in an old country house, an Ali Baba’s cavern of gourmet delights, unearthed from the little-known repertory of Languedoc-Roussillon. Former second of Alain Dutournier at the Carré des Feuillants, Charles Fontès signs intelligent compositions that revolves around the ingredient. Subtle plays of textures and flavours with an overriding goal of authentic simplicity. Seabream, squid and red mullet, Camargues eels and Lucques olives feature among the appetisers – Occitania on the table!

name: Les Sources de Fontbelle
address: 1 bis rue des Meules-à-Grain, Angoulême, 16000, France
description: Five minutes from the centre of Angoulême, brace yourself for the sight of this visually arresting modern structure built of metal, concrete and glass that looks out over the forest. At the helm is chef Guillaume Veyssière: he draws on his consummate skill to cook up innovative cuisine on these premises that suit him down to the ground. From the appetisers onwards, his flair for theatricality is second to none. His endeavours to keep it local are laudable and feed into his success, a case in point being the Gascon pork chop with roasted parsley roots. He also enjoys addressing flavoursome tongue-in-cheek references to tradition and the terroir (eg his "casse-croûte charentais" with snails). For lunch, there is a pleasant seasonal menu at the Forêt des Sources bistro.

name: L'Arbre au Soleil
description: We first met Yorann Vandreissche at the Arbre crossroads by the cobblestones of the mythical Paris-Roubaix bicycle race, where he was successful for five years; he is now basking in the sunshine, opposite the marina of Lavandou harbour. With the help of his friend, Didier Anies (Best Craftsman of France 2020), he conjures up food that shines the spotlight on premium quality produce in a menu that displays a distinct fish and seafood slant. For example: a slab of super-fresh seabass with fennel cream, orange slivers and an orange-kumquat condiment… Refreshing, contrasted, skilful: each dish is an ode to fine craftsmanship!

name: Skab
address: 7 rue de la République, Nîmes, 30000, France
description: This gourmet bolthole located behind the Arènes, just opposite the Musée de la Romanité, is run by chef Damien Sanchez, a local boy who has worked at the Cabro d'Or, La Réserve de Beaulieu, at Christopher Coutanceau's restaurant in La Rochelle and, now, in his hometown alongside Jérôme Nutile. His cooking easily wins you over with fresh and lively dishes that highlight the Gard terroir: sea bass cooked two ways, steamed and served tartare-style; monkfish tournedos, stuffed artichoke with pepper. As soon as the sun starts to shine, make a beeline for the patio shaded by maple trees.

name: Domaine du Colombier
description: Built on the ruins of a monastery hermitage in the heart of Provençale Drôme, this proud homestead first woos us with its bare stone walls, vaulted ceilings, vintage furnishings and patio. The cuisine celebrates regional and Mediterranean produce thanks to spot-on recipes: accurate, precise cooking, flavoursome, balanced recipes, all of which in keeping with the establishment’s sustainable development ethos.

name: La Bastide de Moustiers
description: In this fine bastide, savour Mediterranean cuisine that combines the flavours of ingredients direct from the market or the kitchen garden managed by two full-time staff (don’t miss the adjoining Jardin des Simples). The chef here conjures up meticulously executed dishes bursting with sun-blessed flavours such as rabbit with polenta and mustard-flavoured chips. The pleasant setting, including a plethora of olive trees and a plane tree-shaded terrace, adds to the attraction of this perfect resumé of Provence.

name: La Nouvelle Auberge
description: On the doorstep of Munster valley, this “new inn” is a fully refurbished former posthouse. On the ground-floor, an Alsace bistro regales diners on weekday lunchtimes. Upstairs, the gourmet restaurant sports a suitably rustic, half-timbered dining room. Bernard Leray, who hails from Rennes in Brittany, has taken to Alsace like a stork to its nest. After honing his skills at Bernard Loiseau, Leray puts a delicate new spin on local produce. All his dishes demonstrate his painstaking work and consummate technique, as in this fillet of pike-perch with red cabbage and squash “fleischnaka”, red-wine reduction.

name: La Robe
description: The word “robe” in French is used in oenology to describe the colour and appearance of a wine – an apt name for this restaurant in an attractive old house nestled in the centre of Montaigu, given the careful attention it pays to its wine pairings. Chef Xavier Giraudet, who has worked in many Michelin-starred restaurants, demonstrates his skills in the kitchen here, using local, seasonal ingredients (sometimes even from his family’s kitchen garden) and precise cooking methods to create dishes full of flavour and with a distinctly contemporary feel. The restaurant’s old beams and contemporary furnishings and paintings combine to give it a cosy atmosphere.

name: Les Clefs d'Argent
description: Over the years, this establishment, entirely renovated in a tasteful, low-key contemporary vein, has become a culinary benchmark in Mont de Marsan. It owes its success to Christophe Dupouy, who learned the trade in prestigious houses ranging from Ducasse to Michel Sarran. A committed champion of nature and local produce, his food is a patchwork of influences, mingling southwest France (particularly the Landes) and Benin – the place of birth of his wife Eugénie, who is in charge of the polished, yet casual service. The vibe is friendly and easy-going.

name: Hedone
description: Don't be fooled by Balthazar Gonzalez's young age or his meek air: Hedone is proof that he is right on course and not about to waste time getting there! He has developed an effective concept: just five tables and a single set menu at lunchtime and at dinner, which allows him to give free rein to his creativity. You can expect to spend up to 3 or 4hr at the table, but the experience is more than worth the time! Excellent, even outstanding fresh produce, a preference for vegetables and seafood, explosive flavours with some real show-stopping moments. We can only salute his daring and applaud his skill.

name: Le Royal
address: Hameau de Bellevue, 9 rue de la République, Champillon, 51160, France
description: In the vineyards of the Champagne region, this restaurant fetes the terroir by means of elegant dishes that make no bones about their weakness for seafood either, eg scallops with salsify and black chanterelles, venison with sauce grand veneur, and pear with honey from the beehives. The contemporary dining space is devoted to champagne (note the gilded ceiling with a slight patina, monumental chandelier with 36 amber-coloured blown-glass orbs) and to the women who played a role in the life of Napoleon Bonaparte, who stopped off here in its days as a coaching inn. Lovely contemporary guestrooms; simpler brasserie cuisine at Le Bellevue.

name: Aux Terrasses
description: After a tour of Saint Philibert Abbey, take a break on these enchanting terraces. Bare stone walls and large untreated solid oak tables set the scene indoors, flooded in light thanks to floor-to-ceiling windows. The peaceful garden and attentive service lavished by the chef’s wife are also outstanding. Chef Jean-Michel is an enthusiast, capable of changing his gourmet offering from one table to another in the same evening. His approach is entirely instinctive. His food is thus rich in emotion and establishes a natural complicity with the region, particularly through the use of first-rate local fruit and vegetables and other top-quality ingredients, whilst compromising nothing in terms of high-precision cooking. His weekday lunchtime Market menu is a bargain!

name: Le Sergent Recruteur
description: Chef Alain Pégouret has inherited his love of precise, painstaking work from Joël Robuchon. To see for yourself, you only have to enter Le Sergent Recruteur, a historical tavern on the Île Saint-Louis that has been converted into a fine dining restaurant. The former chef at Laurent displays an impressive command of his craft. His subtle dishes abound with well-defined flavours – you can sense the solid classical foundations – and linger in the memory on account of their sense of harmony, the sophistication of the jus and sauces, and the perfect cooking of the different elements. This establishment exudes a hushed and elegant atmosphere that artfully brings contemporary design into these old walls. A successful revival.

name: Signature
description: The ebullient Coline Faulquier celebrates the Mediterranean virtues of sharing by means of a positively sun-drenched menu (also available in half portions so that you can try several dishes) and a tasting menu. The ingredients are carefully selected – from organic market gardeners and wild herb gatherers, fish from the Mediterranean – and you will enjoy tucking into her signature "Aïoli", comprising a mosaic of crunchy vegetables, monkfish and hake, aioli (both as a sauce and iced), ink tuile; or her fine catch of the day served au naturel with a light black-garlic glaze, blanquette-style bone jus, Buddha's hand, asparagus… Personality, enthusiasm, flavour: a true signature style.

name: Solstice
description: If there are "writers' writers", then there are chefs' chefs. A Meilleur Ouvrier de France, a mainstay of the Ferrandi gastronomy school, promoter of culinary design, restaurateur in Tokyo, Éric Trochon is that sort of chef – admired and yet relatively little known. He and his sommelier wife preside over this modern, intimate-feeling restaurant with a decor that blends designer furnishings and unfinished walls. The menu also errs towards minimalism, with just two on-point proposals (one is an omakase menu). The dishes showcase French cuisine with Japanese and Korean touches, such as volaille du Gâtinais (PGI poultry) with wild cinnamon leaf and its succulent juices with white miso. Two places with a view into the kitchens are available at the counter.

name: Pastis Restaurant
description: Wend your way along the narrow Rue Terral to this comfortable and attractively decorated restaurant. It is one of Montpellier’s most popular eateries and you will quickly understand why! It is impossible to resist Daniel Lutrand’s cuisine, which is both inspired and inspiring, refined and delicate, in a bid to showcase the region’s top producers as well as more unusual ingredients (such as barracuda). An example: Candillargues chicken served with artichoke and hazelnuts and a reduced jus. As well as the sensibly priced lunchtime menu, you’re in for a treat with the “surprise” menu which varies depending on the chef’s inspiration. Cheerful, enthusiastic service by manager and business partner Jean-Philippe Vivant. Knockout wine list.

name: Pavyllon
description: There’s no stopping Yannick Alléno! The latest venture of this chef from the Ile de France region is a real winner with guests and rightly so. Offering space for just thirty guests at the counter (similar to a Joël Robuchon Atelier but with a more hushed feel), the restaurant serves refined, delicate cuisine based around classic recipes. Dishes are blended with interesting flavours and the occasional international influence, such as the tempuras which accompany the main courses. A smart yet relaxed setting in which to enjoy a splendid meal.

name: L'Ekrin by Laurent Azoulay
address: Le Kaïla, 124 rue des Jeux-Olympiques, Méribel, 73550, France
description: L’Ekrin is the perfect fit for this elegant, luxury hotel, offering its guests an intimate setting in which to enjoy an aperitif by the open fire to the sound of quiet piano music in the background. Chef Laurent Azoulay, himself the son of restaurateurs, worked at the Oustau de Baumanière and for chef Pierre Gagnaire before taking the helm here. Skilfully playing with the flavours and traditions of different regions, Azoulay takes guests on a culinary journey through his native Provence and adopted Savoie. He includes the best Mediterranean fish on his menu, alongside ingredients such as pine honey, saffron and snails from the Savoie, as well as vegetables sourced from Éric Roy in Tours. The result is creative and colourful cuisine which is refined and delicate yet also offers some bold combinations.

name: Les Trois Rochers
address: 16 rue du Phare, à Sainte-Marine, Combrit, 29120, France
description: On the Odet estuary, opposite the pretty port of Bénodet, the view overlooks the sea on one side and a forest of pine and oaks on the other… You could do worse! The chef, who trained in Quimper and has worked in Brittany and Switzerland, aims above all to highlight the work of the craftspeople and producers of Brittany (essentially organic) in his menus. He combines regional delicacies with spices from further afield and fresh herbs on a constant quest to exalt the flavour. His langoustines ravioles and shellfish stock is out of this world!

name: Le Charlemagne
description: In the heart of this vineyard devoted to Corton-Charlemagne, Laurent Peugeot nurtures guests in a peaceful, contemporary interior, ideal to sample good food that wavers between France and Japan and which is dotted with surprising but inspired combinations. Out-of-the-ordinary creations, distinctively personal, based on the produce of the restaurant’s garden (and hives) and from local, stringently selected suppliers. The wine list is truly awesome, which is hardly a surprise when you learn that Laurent is both a wine connoisseur and a producer himself.

name: Holen
description: “Seasonality on the plate” is the mantra of this talented chef, who has worked at the prestigious Auberge de l’Ill, as well as with renowned names such as Michel Bras and Emile Jung. His Breton-inspired recipes demonstrate his dedication to top-quality ingredients, including vegetables grown by small local producers using permaculture principles, and fish sourced from small boats that avoid intensive fishing (as a result of which he has been awarded a “Green Food” label). Holen also has his own kitchen garden and makes his own compost. The final result is ethical cuisine that is full of flavour and elegantly presented in the form of surprise menus, all served in a bistro refurbished with natural materials. Delightful!

name: Le Restaurant du Cerisier
description: On the first floor of an ultra-contemporary building in the centre of Lille, the former chef of Le Meurin, Mathieu Boutroy, can be seen at work in a superb open kitchen. His single set menu makes the most of hand-picked produce. A few examples: langoustine, cabbage, buckwheat, watercress; morel, yellow wine, tarragon, Comté; Quercy duck, red onion, beetroot. The chef turns out perfectly executed dishes, and has a knack for finely crafted sauces and jus. Colourful, vibrant and aromatic – the appetising fruit of this "Cherry Tree" is well worth picking.

name: La Maison dans le Parc
description: Established in a handsome mansion, abutting the opera house and just behind one of France’s most beautiful squares, chef Charles Coulombeau and his wife Roxane (front of house) are a firm fixture of the culinary scene of Nancy. Having worked at Les Prés d’Eugénie, Lameloise and Gravetye Manor in Sussex, Charles deftly crafts modern cuisine, enhanced by creative flourishes and a nod to Japan (where he worked for a few months). Citrus fruits (such as Buddha’s hand and calamondin orange) and Asian flavours are perfectly paired with premium ingredients such as ikejime Vosges Arctic Char or plump Bresse chicken. Heroically wondrous (without forgetting the knockout terrace overlooking the park…).

name: Le 7ème Continent
description: This restaurant's incredible decoration (inside and out) was created by painter and decorative artist François Zenner, an amateur naturalist with a passion for plants. Also passionate about his work, and very much influenced by his years with Bernard Loiseau, chef Laurent Haller is never at a loss for ideas when it comes to sharing his love of good food. He likes to revisit the great classics of French cuisine and creates surf and turf combinations. His menu, a veritable ode to the market and its often local produce (lamb from Rixheim, split peas from Petit-landau…), changes every month.

name: L'Aspérule
description: Chef Keigo Kimura incorporates a Japanese twist into French cuisine in this tastefully appointed Dijon restaurant. He surgically crafts set menus and even a mystery menu in the evening. Like all genuine Japanese chefs, his flair for precision and balance (plating, cooking and flavour) is second to none, and his dishes are also sprinkled with tributes to the region, such as pinot noir or vin jaune sauces and mustard shoots. The memory of his ginger-flavoured gyoza of game in a red wine sauce and his shoulder of lamb, first slow-roasted then grilled on a binchotan griddle and served with a Japanese pancake, linger with us still! Last but not least, the wine cellar is an Aladdin’s Cave for connoisseurs.

name: La Galinette
description: Christophe Gomes is a chef who is passionate about plants! He is genuinely committed to his vegetable gardens and collections of citrus and olive trees. Plant-based notes permeate his cuisine from starter to dessert. The bitterness of the romaine lettuce is given a twist with a dash of slightly peppery nasturtium oil and accompanied by trout from Irouléguy; the John Dory, with its reduced bouillabaisse, fennel confit and rouille, is another dish with a strong vegetable flavour, which serves to enhance the top-quality fish. Last but not least, the dessert is fresh and light, made with the chef's own citrus fruit (yuzu, orange and kumquat). A real success.

name: Le Petit Hôtel du Grand Large
address: 11 quai Saint-Ivy, à Portivy, Saint-Pierre-Quiberon, 56510, France
description: It would seem that the world of advertising can open every door! Hervé Bourdon, former Parisian art director, and his wife, Catherine, ditched their former lives to take over and transform this small hotel restaurant. It is idyllically located a pebble’s throw (literally) from the seashore, overlooking the pretty harbour of Portivy, with sea breezes and dazzling sunsets. A single set menu unfolds to reveal resolutely local produce including fish and shellfish, while the herbs, flowers and veggies are from one of the restaurant’s organic cottage gardens. The chef has a knack with fish that he sears on a teppanyaki, and if you are very lucky, you may be able to sample rare delicacies such as barnacles, which taste a bit like a cross between a lobster and a clam and are eaten with the fingers – out of this world!

name: Le Cerf
description: In a group of pretty buildings accessed via a paved inner courtyard and a spruce garden, this former coaching inn has been transformed into an enticing restaurant and hotel. This institution was a bright culinary beacon for a long time thanks to the talent of chef Michel Husser, who passed the reins to Joël Philipps. Bringing to bear his expertise, the chef demonstrates his finesse and delicious eclecticism in the form of a short à la carte menu and two set menus: langoustine tartare; grilled octopus and Iberian chorizo; classic opera cake with wild blueberries and lavender.

name: La Tour des Vents
description: At the top of a hill, surrounded by the Bergerac vineyards, next to the ruins of a windmill, this beautiful, opulent restaurant affords unforgettable views of the surroundings. Chef Damien Fagette promotes the local produce of the Périgord by working with Blonde d'Aquitaine beef, foie gras and free-range Périgord chicken. Prepared with great care and skill, his contemporary cuisine is a succulent alliance of fine ingredients, accurate cooking and well-defined flavours. Grilled squid, shallot with red wine and chorizo churros; variations on lamb (roasted saddle, confit shoulder rissole and leg marinated kebab-style); warm Grand Marnier soufflé. A wonderful experience.

name: Les Fresques - Château des Vigiers
address: 644 route Lars-Urban-Petersson, lieu-dit Le Vigier, Monestier, 24240, France
description: On the crossroads between Dordogne, Gironde and Lot-et-Garonne, the Vigiers Castle is a splendid 16C Périgord edifice, set in grounds that are home to a vineyard and a well-known golf course. This several hundred-year-old castle houses a restaurant whose walls are appointed with frescoes dating from the Renaissance period. Virtuoso chef Didier Casaguana paints from a palette rich in flavours and aromas, directly inspired by the region. This Toulouse boy, who admits to an overriding passion for nature and small producers, also works with noble produce from the land of abundance that is southwest France, which he crafts into surprise menus: tartare of oysters with Prunier caviar, pigeon with chicory and hazelnut and a dessert that revolves around strawberries and tarragon sorbet…

name: Äponem - Auberge du Presbytère
description: Äponem means happiness in Pataxo and Amélie Darvas and Gaby Benicio definitely found their bliss in this inn of a 17C former presbytery. They stumbled across it by accident when on holiday in the region and it has become, in their own words, their “life project”. “Get back to the basics, to ourselves and to home-grown produce”, such is the goal of chef Darvas, originally from Paris, who is committed to working with ingredients sourced only from the local market and their own garden (seven permaculture gardens in all!). Amélie’s bold, transparent cuisine is perfectly paired with the insightful suggestions of fine regional wines by Gaby, a trained sommelière. Meals are served in the spruce interior overlooking the magnificent countryside or on the patio, shaded by a climbing wisteria. More than a restaurant, Äponem is a life project

name: Hostellerie de Levernois
description: The tradition of hospitality is kept alive in this elegant house situated in the middle of extensive grounds dissected by a river. Here, chef Philippe Augé creates carefully prepared, seasonal cuisine based on classic principles, resulting in dishes such as green Acquerello risotto with frogs’ legs and Burgundy snails, and blue lobster with aubergine moussaka and a coriander and lemongrass shellfish jus. Make sure you save space for the cheese platter which includes over forty different varieties! A wine tasting cellar and shop complete the picture.

name: La Grange de Belle-Église
description: Some restaurant and village names instantly conjure up a picture of ‘la vieille France’ and La Grange de Belle-Église is the quintessence of this gourmet bucolic image. We expect to taste traditional recipes, lovingly crafted from first-rate produce sourced from the surrounding countryside, and we are not disappointed. This former coal barn has been converted into a peaceful, cosy sanctuary that is a temple of good food. Chef Marc Duval is a champion of old school culinary tradition, although he does allow himself the odd more modern creation. Blue lobster, crunchy spring veggies in cream or veal in truffles. Meals are served in a plush dining room which leads into the manicured garden in fine weather.

name: Intuition
description: Make your way upstairs from the Brasserie les Capucines, which serves simpler fare, to this understated, plush restaurant overlooking the castle of Saint Lô. After acquiring a faithful following of regulars in Coutances, Mickaël Marion has returned to his birthplace and opened the floodgates of his creativity. A steadfast champion of local produce, he frequently goes walking in the countryside and marshes to pick plants and herbs. Back in his kitchen, he waves his magic wand/spoon and lo and behold - meadowsweet ice cream, pesto of wild herbs and lovage appear! He is a past master in the art of subtly assembling stellar Normandy produce – scallops, fish from small boats, with a dash of exoticism. A fine dining experience to remember.

name: L'Or Bleu
description: After stints in respected Michelin-starred restaurants in Switzerland and Chantilly, Alain Montigny (Meilleur Ouvrier de France 2004) is now the chef of the exquisite Tiara Yaktsa hotel, whose terrace commands a drop-dead view over the sea and the ruddy Esterel mountains. His distinctive Mediterranean-inspired recipes are balanced and delicately flavoured thanks to top-quality ingredients and superb craftsmanship. Highlights include creamy scrambled eggs, truffles and focaccia toast or Brittany spider crab, smoked eel in green apple aspic with an iced cream of lentils and shrenkii caviar.

name: Ursus
address: Maison Bouvier, rue du Val-Claret, au Val-Claret, Tignes, 73320, France
description: Housed within one of the resort’s fine hotels, this restaurant loves nature, with a name that pays tribute to the last species of bear in the Savoie. Its dining room resembles a forest with its slim tree trunks separating each of the tables into little copses, a ceiling covered with a canvas representing leaves, and magnificent tables carved from walnut wood. The chef here also loves gathering wild herbs and plants while out walking in the mountains. Once second in command to Jean-François Piège, he creates contemporary-style Alpine cuisine with real technical wizardry, resulting in generous dishes which are full of flavour while respecting the seasons and constantly searching out the best local ingredients. The cheese selection focuses exclusively on the Savoie and is accompanied by an impressive wine list.

name: Origines
address: Rue du Clos-de-la-Chaux, Le Broc, 63500, France
description: Is Adrien Descouls's inspiration for his exceptionally fresh cuisine his native Auvergne? Close to Issoire, in a modern building perched right next to the 14C castle, he demonstrates his talent without overplaying his hand: well-selected ingredients, showcasing of the local terroir, and all the ambition that comes with being a young chef. Lovely, comfortable guestrooms with pretty views of the surroundings.

name: Le Bénaton
description: In the heart of Burgundy, Beaune is famous for its annual wine auctions that take place in the prestigious Hospices, famous for their glazed tile roofs. A fervent champion of pedigree Gallic food and fine French wines, Japanese chef Keishi Sugimura, couldn’t have found a town that suits him better. Trained in Japan, the chef excels in the art of the porkpie, which earned him the title of vice world champion in 2013. He meticulously, almost surgically crafts fine seasonal ingredients into classical recipes rich in complimentary flavours, throwing in the odd dash of creativity from time to time: œuf parfait, dashi stock, Japanese wagyu; Corton pigeon served two ways. Also a cook, the chef’s wife pampers guests who are invited to take a seat on the patio in the garden come summertime.

name: Le Pot d'Étain
address: 4 avenue de la République, Danjoutin, 90400, France
description: A few minutes from Bartholdi's Lion de Belfort, Le Pot d'Étain is packed with gourmet delights thanks to a talented chef, Philippe Zeiger, who has made his restaurant an absolute must for anyone who loves good food. The chef showcases generous and tasty French cuisine that is prepared using superb seasonal ingredients (scallops, hare à la royale, truffles). His scallops with caviar, lardo di Colonnata and a vin jaune sauce, or back of venison, civet sauce, winter root vegetables are two examples of delectable dishes that take no prisoners! Also worth a mention: the wine by the glass is served from magnums (a rare treat).

name: OKA
description: The Brazilian owner-chef, Raphaël Régo, who boasts an enviable CV (Ferrandi, Joël Robuchon, Taillevent) signs a creative repertory at Oka, underscored by his distinctive culinary identity. He successfully navigates between France (fish from the Vendée coast) and Brazil, always with a focus on outstanding produce. Meals are served in a cosy, smart interior, which sports an open kitchen, where you can admire the artist chef at work. His visually sophisticated and minimalist dishes cleverly play with contrasting flavours (sweet, spicy, acidic) and textures, without ever falling foul of the flaw of showing off! You can trust the insights of the gifted sommelier for his wine pairing suggestions. Exquisitely personal, artfully curated and divinely flavoursome – classy! Love at first bite!

name: Haut Bonheur de la Table
description: Situated between Steenvoorde and Saint-Omer in the heart of Flanders, Cassel is a beautifully kept little village built in brick and perched on the hill of the same name. with this small village comes a small restaurant: the tiny Haut Bonheur de la Table, housed in a beautiful 18C residence, has space for just twenty guests and is run by its owners who are passionate about fine cuisine. Here, Eugène Hobraiche carefully crafts contemporary cuisine that goes hand-in-hand with seasonal produce, using local fruit and vegetables in his dishes, as well as fish from the auction at Dunkirk. Grilled wild turbot with artichoke, samphire and coriander sauce, and grilled tuna with tomato water and green tomato sorbet are just two of the fish specialities on the menu.

name: La Sommelière
description: Both originally from Japan, owner and sommelier Shoko Hasegawa and chef Takafumi Kikuchi honed their skills at the renowned Au 14 Février in Saint-Valentin (Indre). Now, in this Lilliputian restaurant that seats only a handful of diners in the heart of historic Lyon, Ms Hasegawa is responsible for the attentive front of house, while the chef applies his almost surgical precision to distinctive and seasonal recipes: shellfish, tomato and cheese consommé; smoked duck foie gras and sweetcorn; “acqua pazza”-style line-caught croaker… The experience is enhanced by inspired wine-food pairings and prices that make sense.  Be sure to book: tables here are snapped up fast!

name: Auberge Grand'Maison
description: The food here traverses the annals of French cookery: classical and tempting with immaculate plating. Christophe Le Fur, formerly the chef of the chancellor of the Paris academy, when he cooked both for the Dalai Lama and for Hillary Clinton, has returned to his roots (he comes from Cap Fréhel) to regale us with his generous, culinary score: crunchy-melting Ancenis poultry with foie gras stock; biscuit of pike, black wheat crackers and ricotta, red wine sauce.

name: Moulin de la Tardoire
description: Teeming with history, this 16C forge was converted into a flour mill in 1854 and later into an olive oil mill. It now houses a charmingly bucolic restaurant situated by the river and surrounded by greenery. Here, chef Matthieu Brudo serves up seasonal cuisine with a focus on local ingredients, including snails from the Charente, trout from Magnac, squab and duck breast from Nontron, and other top-quality meats which he buys whole from small producers in the local area. Refined, well-crafted and carefully presented dishes that meet with our approval!

name: L'Écrin de Yohann Chapuis
description: Occupying a former orphanage made famous by Jean Ducloux, this restaurant now offers a superb setting for the cuisine of Yohann Chapuis, a chef who did much of his training at the Maison Lameloise. The iconic staples of yesteryear (still served at the Bouchon Bourguignon next door) have made way for a cuisine of “taste and emotions” which has its own distinct identity and character. The focus here is on the best seasonal ingredients, including crayfish from the Saône, turbot caught from small fishing boats, and Charolais beef, all beautifully presented. An excellent wine list and astute recommendations from the sommelier complete the picture.

name: La Mutinerie
description: This chef who has worked in some (very) fine establishments (Le Negresco, La Dame de Pic, Ledoyen and Têtedoie) has opted for a pared-back decor with a slightly vintage look featuring brick, wood and polished concrete. He serves up a mystery menu both at lunchtime (very good value) and dinner. His vegetable-based cooking is focused, delicate and light; he is effective at combining simplicity and clarity, in dishes such as char, lovage, Granny Smith apple and dill, or pigeon, quail and parsley root. Delicious and creative.

name: Auberge Nicolas Flamel
description: Was Nicolas Flamel also an alchemist, as well as a rich bourgeois and former owner of the oldest house in Paris (1407)? Historians may disagree, but we have no doubt about chef Grégory Garimbay. This chef with a star-studded CV (Sylvestre Wahid, Alain Ducasse at the Plaza Athénée) transforms his ingredients into culinary gold. Jelly of courgettes and blackberries; field-grown tomatoes, smoked ricotta and sorbet of green zebra tomatoes; blue lobster from Brittany, green peas, shellfish jus: the new master chef of this distinguished establishment signs balanced, modern recipes, whose aromas and flavours are intelligently assembled, resulting in no-frills, down-to-earth, occasionally original dishes, like his chocolate and girolle mushroom tart. Ah! a culinary alchemist indeed!

name: Auberge de la Tour
address: Place de la Fontaine, Marcolès, 15220, France
description: Located in the heart of a medieval village, this stone property with its corner tower and spiral staircase, is teeming with charm, and it is here that Renaud Darmanin has transformed this former café into a gastronomic outpost. Following his studies at the Chamalières hotel school, Darmanin went on to hone his skills at some of the world’s leading restaurants: at Paul Bocuse in Lyon; with Frédéric Anton at Le Pré Catelan in Paris; and at Le Parc des Eaux Vives in Geneva. He only works with the finest fresh and local ingredients (chestnuts, in particular), creating delicious, accomplished cuisine that skilfully combines the local terroir with spices from around the world.

name: Une Table, au Sud
description: Ludovic Turac, who boasts stints at Le Bristol and Guy Savoy, is happily at the helm of this restaurant, firmly anchored in the South of France. His inventive yet disciplined recipes overflow with regional flavours from Provençal vegetables to locally sourced fish and meat from the Southern Alps, further enhanced by panoramic views over the old port and the basilica of Marseille. His signature dishes “My version of aïoli” and “Local catch like a bouillabaisse” are always a delight, which is also the case of his passport menu in tribute to Marseille’s international maritime heritage.

name: Saisons
description: In the heart of Marseille, a stone’s throw from Place Castellane, this contemporary venue is the exuberant project of a duo of pros, both local lads. Chef Julien Diaz, who honed his talents in London and Corsica, works with sommelier Guillaume Bonneaud. Seating for thirty, a pared-down interior, depicted by wood, iron and untreated materials, spot on food-wine pairings and creative cuisine that bears witness to the establishment’s ethos, particularly in terms of seasonal and locally sourced ingredients from the Mediterranean and Corsica. The lunchtime menu is a bargain.

name: Le Carmin
description: On Place Carnot, not far from the Hôtel-Dieu, this restaurant with a modern façade occupies the ground floor of a picturesque old house. After stints with Robuchon and Ducasse, chef Christophe Quéant crafts modern, seasonal cuisine based on traditional textbook foundations. His top-quality ingredients are transformed into spot-on, straightforward dishes, blessedly free of fancy frills. The contemporary-style dining room, which sports a beige colour scheme and exposed stonework, is the perfect foil for delicious dishes such as caramelised quail breasts and legs, white asparagus and baby carrots and the hot Grand Marnier soufflé – to die for!

name: Sola
description: Just a stone's throw from the River Seine, looking out onto Notre Dame, we are clearly in Paris – yet here we are in Japan! Sola's interior is full of contrasts, from the calming pale wood to the exposed ceiling beams and heavy solid wood doors. In the basement, there is a vaulted cellar with tables arranged on tatami mats (be sure to remove your shoes). Japanese chef Kosuke Nabeta serves a delicious fusion of the exacting standards of Japanese cuisine and the wealth of ingredients from rural France. He introduces us to traditional Japanese culinary techniques, which he wields with great skill (smoking, drying, marinating, fermenting, alternative cooking methods etc) using ingredients such as soya, sake, ponzu and mizuna. Be sure to try his signature dish of calf sweetbreads served with a rice cake topped with a truffle emulsion! Harmonious, refined and personal cuisine.

name: La Table de Philippe Girardon
address: Domaine de Clairefontaine, Chemin des Fontanettes, Chonas-l'Amballan, 38121, France
description: The fourth generation is at the helm of this family business, established in a splendid 18C edifice surrounded by grounds, which was once the holiday home of the bishops of Lyon. The inventive food is the consummate work of a chef who has had a Michelin star since 1993 and who became a MOF in 1997. Top quality regional produce, surgically precise craftsmanship in a classical vein and the occasional more modern technique depict the culinary ethos. This welcoming scene provides the backdrop to dishes such as a soup of frog’s legs with mushrooms and wild garlic, Grenoble-style arctic char, slowly baked in its juices, risotto of soft wheat and beurre noisette.

name: Auberge Saint-Laurent
address: 1 rue de la Fontaine, Sierentz, 68510, France
description: This elegant and authentic 18C coaching inn with a long, flower-filled and welcoming façade is a local family-owned institution, appreciated as much by its regulars as it is by the many tourists on their way across Europe. They all sing the praises of the service and keen sense of hospitality, the snug and appealing guestrooms, and, of course, the excellent cuisine served here. Chef Laurent Arbeit presides over the kitchen, having learned his craft under Haeberlin and Ducasse. A proprietor who is very much in tune with the times, his delicate and harmonious cuisine is replete with well-balanced flavours. A resounding success.

name: Auberge au Bœuf
description: You can’t help but fall under the spell of this Alsace inn with its church pews, wood-panelled walls, regional furniture and small museum dedicated to Goethe (the village was once the setting for a love affair between this famous German writer and the daughter of the local pastor). The chef here – the fourth generation of the same family – serves delicate, refined seasonal cuisine which is skilfully crafted from carefully selected ingredients. He has created a small network of direct suppliers who provide him with outstanding fish from Plouguerneau, which he transforms into delicious dishes such as fresh brill with a variety of white asparagus. There’s also a Stammtisch, a “table d’hôtes” where regional specialities are served, plus four luxury guestroom-suites.

name: Ambroisie
description: What initially draws the eye, right in front of us, is the lake hemmed in by wooded banks – the location alone is worth seeing. But above all there is the remarkable work of the chef – after all, that's what we came for… He excels at transforming fine ingredients (scallops hot-pâté style; Breton lobster with raspberries, dried caviar and mizuna; pigeon breast roasted and smoked on the barbecue). His trompe l'œil desserts are at once amusing and delicious (apricot, lemon, chestnut – depending on the season). For fans of truffles, the chef serves a truffle menu all year round: it wouldn't seem right not to indulge.

name: L'Épuisette
description: An “épuisette” is a child’s fishing net, often forgotten on the rocks by the seashore and this establishment enjoys a matchless waterside location on the fishing port of the Vallon des Auffes. The house’s iconic “Fanny” menu is as dazzling as the July sunshine. The chef knows his business: the produce is flawlessly fresh, the recipes meticulous and the flavours distinctive – all of which with lashings of generosity. We sampled a bouillabaisse of capon, monkfish, galinette, weever and John Dory – to die for! A delicious port of call.

name: Ogata
description: Ogata could well be Japan’s other Embassy of Paris. This temple dedicated to Japanese art de vivre is located in a private mansion in the Marais, masterminded by Shinichiro Ogata, a world-famous designer and restaurateur, who seeks “beauty and balance in all things” (his own words). The essentially traditional Japanese food sports an omakase spirit, through a tasting menu comprised of immaculate seasonal produce that is perfectly suited to the restaurant’s suave sophistication. We tasted some remarkable starters (spinach, roast asparagus, fried squid, sashimi of horse mackerel), as was the tamago yaki, a subtly perfumed omelette roll. The best seats are at the counter. Pop into the shop or art gallery before leaving…

name: La Liégeoise
description: From its first-floor vantage point, you can't escape the panoramic sea view! This family-run hotel in the oldest seaside resort on the Côte d'Opale immediately turns your head with its freshly redecorated vintage-style decor. Before dropping anchor in the English Channel, Benjamin Delpierre worked for a time with Jean-Michel Lorain at Côte Saint-Jacques and then with Michel Roth at the Ritz, before setting sail for the Caribbean with his wife, who now works front of house. Fish and shellfish run the show here from the get-go: red mullet, snails, oysters, razor clams and mussels – enhanced by the chef's flair for cooking seafood. L'Aloze, on the ground floor of the hotel, serves simpler fare.

name: Accents Table Bourse
description: "An accent indicates where a person comes from; it tells us about their country, their region and their history. It is this idea of openness and discovery that I want to uphold, a cuisine made up of encounters and exchanges." These are the words of Ayumi Sugiyama, the Japanese proprietor of this contemporary restaurant with a Scandinavian vibe, as well as its pastry chef. The dishes are a combination of classic fare (succulent hare à la royale in season), more daring creations and subtle experiments with roasted and smoked flavours. From start to finish, balance and precision… as is the case with the owner's desserts and the sommelier's judicious advice. Warm and vibrant service.

name: Le Jardin Secret
address: 32 rue de la Gare, La Wantzenau, 67610, France
description: This secret garden lies opposite the small railway station. The welcoming restaurant is the den of a youthful team, led by an ambitious, talented and seasoned chef, Gilles Leininger. In addition to his signature “artichoke” recipe, which won a prize at the 2019 Bocuse d’Or competition, he crafts dishes that keep pace with market availability and his inspiration: roasted scallops, Jerusalem artichoke and truffles; turbot in a Tom Yam sauce; squab and duck foie gras pie… The other secret of this contemporary-styled establishment is its exquisite leafy patio in the back garden.

name: Michel Sarran
description: As Michel Sarran puts it, "this is more of a house than a restaurant", where guests are invited to take the time to eat and enjoy the moment in one of two dining rooms – a modern space on the ground floor and a more hushed and elegant ambiance on the first floor. Originally from the Gers département, the chef divided his time between the South-West and the Mediterranean before settling in Toulouse, where he came to be one of the city's culinary ambassadors. With his single set menus that celebrate the region's finest produce, he creates a sun-kissed take on the cuisine of the South of France, whose spices, marinades and confits occasionally meet more far-flung influences (Maghreb, Asia, Caribbean).

name: Buerehiesel
description: This picturesque, half-timbered 17C farmhouse was reconstructed stone by stone in the Orangerie Park, next-door to the Council of Europe. The conservatory dining room and patio command a bucolic view of this leafy haven. The menu features some of the house signature dishes, such as frog’s legs sautéed in chervil or free-range pullet roasted in a casserole dish (backeoffe), together with more contemporary seasonal recipes.

name: Au Déjeuner de Sousceyrac
description: A seriously reliable establishment, whose success is undoubtedly due to the professionalism and distinctive personality of chef Patrick Lagnès. His carefully designed recipes, often founded on a patriotic line-up of French classics, make ample use of fine ingredients, with, depending on his inspiration, the occasional more modern creation. The decadent desserts are the work of his daughter. Meals are served in a dining room characteristic of provincial France, appointed with wainscoting and classical furnishings. Good value for money.

name: La Table d'Aurélien Largeau
address: Hôtel du Palais, 1 avenue de l'Impératrice, Biarritz, 64200, France
description: A gift from Napoleon III to his wife Eugénie in 1854, the Hôtel du Palais, the emblematic palace of the city of Biarritz, has just reopened after being beautifully refurbished. The restaurant is on a par with this splendid setting, thanks to chef Aurélien Largeau (who has worked for Christophe Hay), who rises to the challenge admirably. Eel from the South-West, John Dory from our shores, Baserri guinea fowl from the Basque country: local produce is elevated by his meticulous approach. Pastry chef, Aleksandre Oliver (previously of Gordon Ramsay's restaurant in Bordeaux), meanwhile, successfully combines seaweed and rhubarb!

Opposite the Palais Rohan, a classical masterpiece completed in 1741, this venerable restaurant sports a romantic look, both intimate and elegant, thanks to a chic baroque décor and soft lighting. The chef, Jérémy Page, whose CV includes 15 years in the Joël Robuchon group between Paris and London, signs delicate, precise recipes, strewn with passing nods to Alsace. His inspiration comes to the forefront in sauces and jus, such as rockfish bisque with lightly seared red mullet or breast of squab with a punchy jus deglazed with Nusswasser liqueur. Fine food paired with a splendid selection of Alsace wines (grands crus, organic, etc).

name: Au Crocodile
description: The stuffed crocodile in the window, a souvenir brought back from Egypt by a Napoleonic soldier, underlines the historic character of this iconic Strasbourg establishment, which boasted 3 stars under chef Émile Jung. Following a top to toe refurbishment that has preserved the spirit of the venue, it shines brightly on the culinary scene of Strasbourg. Chef Romain Brillat, former second of Gilles Goujon and a distant relative of Brillat-Savarin, a famous French gourmet, has achieved a balance between classicism and sophistication. Examples include his inventive take on scallops (including the roe and muscle) with black truffles or the more traditional slab of turbot in a crust of breadcrumbs, lemon and herbs. The polished tableside service is a pleasure to behold.

name: Le Cénacle
description: The plush atmosphere, depicted by a superb fireplace and a Caravaggio print, invites you to take a seat at this cenacle. Your intuition is confirmed as you sample the chef’s undeniable know-how, finely balanced between regional produce and contemporary notes, all of which founded on flawlessly fresh ingredients. Indeed, the chef takes pride in forging long-lasting partnerships with local producers (organic vegetables from Gers and breeders). He has a particular knack for enhancing simple ingredients, such as a roast rack of Monts Lagast pork, paccheri stuffed with brown and black chanterelle mushrooms. The lunchtime menu is a steal.

name: Noni
description: What was once the home of ‘Xmun Borg & Sons Bakery & Confectionery’ is now anequally appealing restaurant; sit at ground level for a quiet meal or, for a livelier ambience, head downstairs, past the kitchen, to the stylish, stone-walled cellar. The restaurant’s moniker comes from the nickname of chef-owner Jonathan Brincat – whose passion involves bringing a refined, modern approach to traditional Maltese and Mediterranean cuisine. The attentive team are happy to make recommendations from the concise menu, which showcases quality seasonal ingredients in visually appealing, well-balanced dishes, cooked with a measured approach and an eye for detail. A fairly priced list of local and Italian wines provides the perfect accompaniment.

name: De Mondion
description: The luxurious Xara Palace Hotel is set in a 16th century building in the heart of the beautiful walled city of Mdina and, on its top floor, you’ll find this intimate, elegantly dressed restaurant featuring impressive artwork of the island. If you’re here in the summer, a table on the terrace is a must, to enjoy stunning views out across the east of the island to the coast.Cooking is technically adept and combinations, well-judged, with menus showcasing the best of the island’s produce in sophisticated, classically based Mediterranean dishes – the suckling pig is a speciality. The impressive wine list offers a broad choice with some great quality vintages and it’s worth asking the sommelier for recommendations from their local selection. Despite the hotel’s sumptuous style, service remains friendly and not overly formal.

name: Under Grain
description: Enter the Rosselli Hotel and descend via the lift to this elegant cellar restaurant, where you walk past the kitchen before entering into a dining room with a vaulted stone ceiling and dark, moody décor. Under Grain is inspired by Merchant Street’s former tailor shops and evidence of this theme is all around, from the sewing pattern menu to the clothing displays – and even a pin-cushion bill-holder.As a tailor would create something exquisite from cloth, the chef here does the same with fine ingredients, skilfully applying his talent to produce a beautiful end product. Expertly cooked Mediterranean dishes burst with bold, gloriously harmonious flavours and, while their base may be classic, the overtones are modern. Professional, personable service and a relaxed atmosphere add to the experience. The wine list is well-chosen and contains plenty of gems from the world, especially from Italy and France.

name: Fernandõ Gastrotheque
description: A small quiet bistro in French style which is informal yet elegant, with contemporary furnishings, subtle lighting and soft background music. The highly talented chef here creates Mediterranean dishes with the occasional international touch and plenty of character, all prepared from the best seasonal ingredients. The wine list is worth a mention, featuring over 600 labels from across the globe with a particular emphasis on France and Italy. The restaurant is located in a small street at the back of the lively Sliema, a little town rich in tourism with a waterfront that features restaurants, bars and a busy promenade. The restaurant is small and intimate, and from its windows you can watch the world pass by on the street as if you were out there yourself.

name: Bahia
address: De Paule Avenue, San Anton, Balzan, BZN 9023, Malta
description: Bahia is located on the first floor of the elegant Corinthia Palace Hotel. The restaurant is named after the prestigious naval orange which is grown in the region, and a preserved orange tree sits at the centre of one of the dining rooms. The other room features an open kitchen and both areas are bright, elegant and incredibly comfortable. The talented kitchen headed by Tyrone Mizzi offers two 7-course surprise menus: ‘Past’ takes diners back in time with sophisticated dishes inspired by various periods in Maltese history, including the Stone Age and Roman times, while ‘Future’ allows diners to explore new, sometimes daring combinations of flavours in dishes which push boundaries. Meanwhile, ‘Present’ is a seasonally changing à la carte menu which focuses on local ingredients delivered in a contemporary vein.

name: ION Harbour by Simon Rogan
address: 11 St Barbara Bastion, Valletta, VLT 1961, Malta
description: AS OF MARCH 2023, SIMON ROGAN, THE CHEF-OWNER OF L’ENCLUME IN CARTMEL, UK, HAS TAKEN THE LEAD OF THE FOOD OFFERING HERE.  From the moment you step out of the lift, the team at this restaurant put all their effort into creating a memorable experience. It’s set on the 4th floor of a hotel and the magnificent view from the terrace over the Grand Harbour provides an amazing backdrop for your meal. The restaurant itself is stylish yet informal, with some tables able to catch a glimpse into the kitchen, and service is second-to-none, with some excellent wine recommendations from the passionate sommelier. Mediterranean cuisine is prepared using modern techniques and is beautifully presented, with careful attention paid to detail and colour. The highly talented chef makes a point of choosing ingredients of the highest quality for his dishes.

name: [aend]
description: The clean and minimalist design immediately catches the eye, as do the striking brick arches overhead. The clear view into the open kitchen showcases the skill and dedication of Fabian Günzel's team. The pared-down interior is reflected in the set menu, which comprises up to 15 modern and creative courses, made using top-quality produce. Superb wine recommendations.

name: APRON
description: You will find this stylishly elegant yet modern restaurant not far from the Stadtpark and the historical centre of Vienna, adjoining the Sofitel Hotel. The impressive-looking open kitchen turns out a creative set menu that draws on regional and seasonal ingredients to deliver beautifully handcrafted dishes that are full of flavour. The desserts are fabulous! You can also have lunch in the bistro.

name: Pramerl & the Wolf
description: This former pub in Vienna's ninth district is now a great casual fine dining restaurant. In a pleasantly informal atmosphere, the friendly and highly competent front-of-house team serve dishes that draw on modern inspiration and feature contrasts that work well. A sophisticated surprise menu with the focus squarely on the excellent ingredients is proposed. Tip: take the U4 underground line to get here.

name: Edvard
description: The elegant fine dining restaurant of the Palais Hansen Kempinski Hotel Vienna offers a successful marriage of modern and classic. The food is refined and technically sophisticated, with a penchant for Mediterranean produce. A nice touch is that at the start, your friendly server comes to your table to give you a rundown of the ingredients used. There are Austrian and international wines to accompany your food.

name: The Glass Garden
description: Housed in a distinctive glass vault with an elegant interior and a magnificent view of the city, Schloss Mönchstein's fine dining restaurant is really impressive. Here, well-drilled waitstaff serve fabulous modern cuisine with a personal touch. Opt for one of two set menus (one vegan), or order premium steak and classics like sole fried whole and Wiener schnitzel à la carte. The wine list includes a decent selection of Austrian labels as well as some big names from France and Italy.

name: Esszimmer
description: As far as Salzburg's foodies are concerned, the Kaiblinger family's elegant restaurant with its vibrant, colourful decor is as important a landmark as the Mönchsberg. Made using excellent produce, Andreas Kaiblinger's culinary creations are classical in their foundations and full of flavour. He sparingly incorporates Asian and Mediterranean seasonings and gives his dishes a certain individuality. He and his team work meticulously to create punchy cuisine. Your charming maître d', Andrea Kaiblinger, has some fascinating wine recommendations up her sleeve. Delightful rear courtyard terrace!

name: TIAN
description: This beacon of vegetarian gourmet cuisine proposes a set menu with six or eight courses that can also be vegan. The depth of flavour in the dishes is down to the technical prowess of chef Paul Ivić, as well as the fantastic quality of the ingredients, which are seasonal and locally sourced. There's a great selection of organic wines – alternatively, opt for one of the non-alcoholic beverage accompaniments. The waitstaff are warm and professional, and they always go about their work with a smile. The stylish decor incorporates modern design into a historical setting.

name: Kilian Stuba
description: From the moment you arrive, service of the highest standard awaits you here in the fabulously chic fine dining restaurant of the Travel Charme Ifen Hotel! And that's before you even sample the food coming out of the kitchen. The select produce draws on what the region has to offer, but also looks beyond the borders of the Kleinwalsertal valley. Sascha Kemmerer (who once worked under Ortwin Adam, who was awarded a star in 1978 in the original Ifen Hotel) proposes a four- to six-course set menu, which is pleasingly pared down to the essentials and technically outstanding – the sauces are fabulous! The chef occasionally likes to get in on the act himself and serve one or two courses. As an alternative to the set menu, there is the Ifen speciality: prime rib of beef for two, carved at the table.

name: Pfefferschiff
description: Iris and Jürgen Vigné and their team live and breathe hospitality at this restaurant on the outskirts of Salzburg. In a lovely 17C parish house, diners take their seats in one of the charming, cosy dining areas, outside on the attractive terrace or in a lounge. The classic cuisine has modern and seasonal influences; some of the ingredients are sourced locally or even from the restaurant's own garden – Jürgen Vigné sets great store by working closely with nature and is mindful of the produce he buys in. Iris Vigné is a natural born hostess who ensures that her guests feel at home. The well-curated wine list focuses on Austrian labels. They also cultivate a vineyard in the Kamptal.

name: Opera Bombana
address: Shop 21, LG2 Level, Parkview Green Fangcaodi, 9 Dongdaqiao Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Umberto Bombana stunned the world with his 8 1/2 Otto e Mezzo in Hong Kong. This is his latest brainchild, after ventures in Macau and Shanghai. The classic degustation menu is the best way to sample his signatures, which are rooted in tradition but jazzed up by modern touches. They go big with the wine list featuring great selections of Piemonte and Tuscan reds. The spacious and striking dining room befits the art-themed shopping mall it is in.

name: Poetry‧Wine (Dongsanhuan Middle Road)
address: 61 Dongsanhuan Middle Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: The bamboo bush, jade ornaments, ink paintings and cut flowers may prime your brain for a hefty price tag, but a meal in this modern restaurant doesn’t break the bank. With a daily limit of 100 orders, its signature braised fish head is juicy and tender, nicely braised in an aromatic brown sauce. Roast duck uses 40-day-old birds that are chargrilled to perfection and plated gorgeously. Always save room for the creamed yam and osmanthus sweet soup.

name: Xin Rong Ji (Jianguomenwai Street)
address: 5F, Tower A, Yintai Centre, 2 Jianguomenwai Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Having started life as a small shop selling seafood dishes, this chain now has branches in most large cities in China. At the heart of the CBD lies its second outpost boasting butler service for diners – reserve a table ahead and pre-order the freshest seafood flown in from Taizhou every day. Besides the famous wild-caught yellow croaker and fried hairtail, also try blanched baby octopus, braised radish slices, and bean noodles in sea anemone soup.

name: In Love (Gongti East Road)
address: Next to East 2 Gate, Workers' Sports Complex, Gongrentiyuchang East Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: This is a Hunanese restaurant, but its décor easily passes for a modern bistro with sleek furniture and a muted palette, punctuated by lime green banquettes. The same degree of eclecticism is at work on the menu, as the Hunanese chef puts a new spin on the classics. Steamed fish head with pickled chilli duo uses bighead carp shipped daily from Qiandao Lake in Zhejiang. Pre-order this dish alongside others when booking a table.

name: Lu Shang Lu
address: 2A01-2A03 / 2A05-2A13, 2F, Sunshine Financial Center, No.1 Tower, 33 Jinghui Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: This new brand from the restaurant group specialises in Shandong cooking, especially Confucius cuisine, sea cucumber and live seafood shipped from Jiaodong peninsula daily. The young chef from Yantai knows the food from his home province inside out. Try his roast 45-day-old duck served with caviar, prawn crackers and Shandong pancakes, combining the characteristics of both Beijingese and Shandong cooking. Consider booking a room for more privacy.

name: The Georg
address: 1 Jade River, 45 Dongbuyaqiao Hutong, Dianmen East Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Tucked in a restored riverside quadrangle house, Georg Jensen’s flagship restaurant serves open sandwiches and hams at lunch, but an unmistakably fine-dining menu at dinner. Nordic techniques such as smoking and curing are skilfully deployed in dishes that pack real depth in flavours and contrasts, not to mention the superb ingredients and painterly presentations. Order the classic or degustation menu to sample the breadth and complexity of its culinary repertoire. The restaurant is now closed and plans to reopen at a new location in Summer 2023.

name: Trb Hutong
address: 23 Shatan North Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Hidden in a maze of alleyways, the restaurant is difficult to find, but your effort pays off as you get to taste the modern French cuisine in a temple courtyard-turned dining room. Local ingredients are cleverly prepared to make refined dishes with a novel twist and set menus change according to the season. The highlight of a meal here is definitely the must-try caviar dish that leaves a robust aftertaste. Also, save room for desserts.

name: Country Kitchen
address: 3F, Rosewood Hotel, Jing Guang Centre, Hujialou, 1 Chaoyangmenwai Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: While this room commands panoramic vistas, your attention may be drawn to the gastronomic spectacle in the open kitchen. Rows of chestnut-fed Huairou ducks prized for their unique nutty sweetness are grilled in a display oven. The long-lost Beijing classic crispy pork belly is also a must-try. This delicious cut of meat is marinated, sun-dried, wood-grilled, sliced and stewed in a dense chicken stock that takes eight hours to make. Reservations are a must.

name: Fu Chun Ju
address: 3F, The Puxuan Hotel, 1 Wangfujing Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Designed by the German architect Ole Scheeren, this dining room seamlessly blends pared-down modernism with hutong tradition. Imagine circular booths that create an array of semi-private spaces. The experienced head chef from Hong Kong showcases his solid and astute skills in signature dishes like the roast pigeon. The revamped menu includes many items that are available in individual portion sizes, so diners may sample the length and breadth of his repertoire.

name: Jing Yaa Tang
address: LG Level, The Opposite House, Taikoo Li Sanlitun North, 11 Sanlitun Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: In a serene hotel amidst the busy Sanlitun area, this high-ceilinged dining room exudes understated luxury. The menu changes from time to time and is mostly Beijingese, with occasional offerings from elsewhere. Watch your 45-day-old Peking duck browning for an hour in the jujube wood-fired oven before being carved table-side. Osmanthus-scented lotus root stuffed with glutinous rice, and dishes made with fresh mushrooms are also popular.

name: Jing
address: B1 Level, The Peninsula Hotel, 8 Jinyu Hutong, Beijing, China Mainland
description: What this basement dining room lacks in scenery, it more than makes up for with eclectic art and a chic bar. The chef hailing from Bayonne has worked in some prestigious kitchens in Europe; he puts a new spin on French classics with novel creations like 52 degree egg with potato foam and white truffle. Try also wild-caught scampi from New Zealand, or the velvety spring lamb. Consider booking the chef’s table in advance to be close to the action.

name: The Beijing Kitchen
address: D6007, 6F, SKP Beijing, 87 Jianguo Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: With over 20 years of experience, this owner-chef from Hong Kong samples what his team makes daily to keep improving the quality. While he is most proud of his Cantonese barbecue (crispy deep-fried squab, in particular), double-steamed soups, dim sum, and original creations such as steamed tofu with shrimps and goji leaves also impress. And of course, nothing ends a Cantonese meal better than a serving of sago and pomelo in mango purée.

name: Sheng Yong Xing (Chaoyang)
description: This east-meets-west décor melds Jiangnan motifs and furniture with moody lighting and a glass-clad wine cellar plus bar. The Beijingese menu is complemented by a reasonably priced wine list. Feel free to seek advice from the sommelier. The signature roast duck is exactly 30-days-old, grilled in a stone oven over jujube wood for 70 minutes, and can be served with caviar if you wish. Zhajiang noodles is another unmissable item.

name: Lao Ji Tang (Gongrentiyuchang South Road)
address: 15 Gongrentiyuchang South Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: This exceptionally skilled kitchen team hails from a time-honoured restaurant in Shanghai and successfully delivers that same city’s authentic flavour here. The retro décor exudes a historic charm with dim lighting, coloured glass and vintage images. The must-try steamed drunken crab bursts with heady aromas. Stir-fried and blanched shrimp duo, braised pork belly, and grilled fish head with scallion are all excellent. Reservations are recommended.

name: Xin Rong Ji (Jinrong Street)
address: B1 Level, Financial Street International Hotel, 11 Jinrong Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: This is the first Beijing branch of the Taizhou brand famous for its fresh seafood shipped from the East China Sea daily. The dimly lit dining room dotted with bird cages and other Chinese motifs feels chic and sophisticated. The menu changes according to availability, but the star of the show remains the wild-caught yellow croaker – pre-order the flavourful and umami-loaded yellow croaker soup with matsutake mushrooms, as it takes hours to double boil.

name: Mansion Cuisine by Jingyan
description: This historic courtyard house was remodelled in 2013 to house this atmospheric, expansive restaurant. Likewise, traditional Beijing dishes are given a modern and eclectic remake. Peking duck is served three ways that entail caviar and black truffle, or carved into 108 slices the traditional way, boasting crispy skin and juicy flesh. Signatures like sea cucumber with Peking style pork sauce, and the seasonal claypot rice with crabmeat and crab roe are also phenomenal.

name: Zijin Mansion
address: 3F, Waldorf Astoria Hotel, 5-15 Jinyu Hutong, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Though its name means purple and gold, this cosy dining room is clad in orange hand-embroidered fabric with a bird theme. The menu sees a good mix of Cantonese classics and bold creations, thanks to the head chef’s experience around the world. The must-try goldfish shrimp dumplings taste as good as they look. Seared Australian scallops with kale stems in XO sauce exhibit exceptional wok hei. Oenophiles should check out the spectacular wine cellar.

name: Seventh Son
address: 4F, China World Summit Wing, 1 Jianguomenwai Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: This outpost of the Hong Kong group is conveniently located near a shopping mall, with a dining room that emanates the glamour of yesteryear. From rustic home-style dishes to rare gourmet food, the menu emphasises the chef’s respect for ingredients. Quality products are prepared with exceptional skill and authentic flavours shine through. Signatures include stuffed crab shells, crispy fried chicken and fried rice wrapped in lotus leaf.

name: The Tasty House
address: Block 21, 4 Gongrentiyuchang North Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Nestled in Jing Yard, a tree-lined entertainment and dining complex converted from a heritage factory site, this elegant dining room is a subtle nod to the building’s industrial past. A skylight on the gable wall and glass doors flood the space with natural light. The large menu is dominated by Jiangnan cuisine, with crispy Peking duck roasted over jujube wood being the highlight. There are five private rooms available. Make sure you book ahead.

name: Furong
address: 1F, The Westin, 9C Jinrong Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Named after the provincial flower of Hunan, it makes perfect sense that this new brand under the Xin Rong Ji Group focuses on the Hunanese cuisine. The Hunanese chef delivers authentic classics such as fish head covered in chopped chillies that pack a punch of flavour – make sure that it’s ordered in advance. Porcini-pork tripe soup with pickled radish is cooked in a casserole over charcoal. Bonus tip—you may order certain items in smaller portions as well.

name: Ling Long
address: 3F, STEY-Sanlitun Hotel, BEI Zhaolong, 2 Gongrentiyuchang North Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: The dining room feels airy, minimal and fresh, with just one wisteria plant as the centrepiece. In the semi-open kitchen, the young head chef with around ten years of experience deftly prepares his seasonally inspired menus, consisting of up to seven artfully plated inventions that taste unmistakably Chinese. Most of the ingredients are sourced locally, including the beef from Shandong, oyster sauce and fermented condiments which are all made in house.

name: Vege Wonder
address: Shop 212, 2F, West Building, WF Central, 269 Wangfujing Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: If you crave taro fish or chicken nuggets made with soy, you’re in the wrong place. Championing the ideals of natural, eco-conscious and artistic culinary creations, this destination strives to mix and match authentic tastes and textures of various ingredients, while refusing to imitate any meat dish. Produce is sourced from all over China and the presentations are exquisite. Meticulous service completes the experience. Pre-book the private rooms.

name: Gastro Esthetics DaDong
address: 1-2F, Nanxincang Business Tower, 22A Dongsi 10th Alley, Beijing, China Mainland
description: The Peking duck chain’s flagship in town got a makeover in 2021 and was re-branded as the chain’s most exclusive branch. The signature roast duck only uses 22-day-old birds, and is served with condiments like pancake, cucumber, scallion, minced garlic and bean sauce. Braised sea cucumber is a sensational tour de force – spiny sea cucumber from Kanto, Japan is prepared tableside à la minute. Seasonal seafood and mushroom dishes are also the highlights.

name: Forum
address: 2F, Empark Prime Hotel, 2 Wangfujing Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Forum has long been an institution of deluxe Cantonese fare in Hong Kong. Its first outpost in Beijing is helmed by Chef Lee who perfected his skills throughout his career of over 30 years. The menu offers many of the same dishes as its Hong Kong flagship, such as sauteed lobster with crab meat and pigeon egg that boasts velvety texture and briny-sweetness. The signature fried rice packs rich wok hei whereas braised abalones are not to be missed.

name: Lu Style (Anding Road)
address: 5F, Uni Elite, Building 6, Courtyard 5, Anding Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Instead of typical Shandong classics, this native chef from the province champions a seafood-heavy menu with critters that he sources from the Weihai port daily. Braised sea cucumber with scallion takes five days to prepare and shouldn’t be missed. Also try the giant mixed-grain pancake, a staple from the Mount Yimeng area, served with six condiments on the side. Round it out with artisan yoghurt freshly made daily from donkey’s milk.

name: Lei Garden (Jinbao Tower)
address: 3F, Jinbao Tower, 89 Jinbao Street, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Lei Garden hails from Hong Kong and specialises in traditional Cantonese fare. The décor feels festive and joyous. Most ingredients are sourced from their own farm to ensure quality and freshness. The signature roasted pork belly boasts alternate layers of fat and meat, with crispy skin and juicy flesh. Slow-cooked and double-boiled soups are also recommended. Sago and pomelo in mango purée is the perfect end to the meal.

name: Mio
address: 3F, Four Seasons Hotel, 48 Liangmaqiao Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Despite its discreet entrance, the lavish dining room will take your breath away: strings of glass beads draped from the mirrored ceiling form a dazzling sculpture that spans the room’s length. The head chef champions a seasonally driven menu complete with modern techniques and aesthetics, but with a nod to Italian traditions. Boston lobster paccheri, for instance, is cooked to perfection, complemented by dried cherry tomatoes and basil pesto.

name: Il Ristorante - Niko Romito
address: 1F, Bvlgari Hotel, Building 2, Courtyard 8, Xinyuan South Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: This dining concept by the eponymous Milanese chef epitomises all that is Italian luxe. Lit by Murano glass chandeliers and clad in marble, warm wood and leather, the high-ceilinged dining room overlooks a manicured garden. Classic recipes are given a subtle and modern twist that adds sophistication and depth. The à la carte menu changes every season, while degustation menus change every month. The wide array of Italian wines on offer match the food well.

name: Zhiguan Courtyard
description: This restaurant, annexed to an art gallery, sports a dining room complete with lush garden views through its floor-to-ceiling windows. Liaoning fisherman’s-style dishes are re-created here, with produce from Changbai Mountains and fish from Bohai Sea and Liao River. Signatures include green willow clams, and stir-fried sea snail with green onion—both flavoursome and full of umami.

name: Huaiyang Fu
description: This period mansion, complete with a stone garden, brick walls and carved wood windows, befits the refinement and subtlety that define this restaurant’s cuisine. Thanks to a renovation, booth seats are the prized spot for a truly comfortable experience. The menu celebrates the greatest hits in Huaiyang cooking, such as braised pork belly in brown sauce and tofu chrysanthemum in matsutake stock. Seasonal offerings like crystal yellow croaker aspic are also worth saving room for.

name: Cai Yi Xuan
address: 2F, Four Seasons Hotel, 48 Liangmaqiao Road, Beijing, China Mainland
description: Having worked with various teams within the hotel group for years, Chef Li hailing from Tianjin makes sure every top-notch ingredient is prepared meticulously in his kitchen. The main menu focuses on Cantonese fare, but regulars may refer to another menu for popular dishes they miss. Chef Li is especially proud of his signature wok-fried prawns with fermented black garlic and dried chillies. The wine list also features some great selections.

name: Xin Rong Ji (West Nanjing Road)
address: 2F, 688 Plaza, 688 West Nanjing Road, Shanghai, China Mainland
description: Among the four branches in Shanghai, this location and the one on the Bund prominently feature Taizhou cooking alongside Cantonese cuisine.
