Chef Mario Affinita delights the palate with his exciting cooking methods and light preparation, resulting in dishes such as his surprising “n’uovo”, which despite the name (“uovo” is the Italian for egg) consists of tomato water, scampi and marine plankton – there’s no egg to be seen! The wine list is also worthy of note, offering a good selection from across Europe and even further afield.

name: In Viaggio - Claudio Melis
description: The name of this restaurant gives a good indication of the experience you can expect here: a culinary voyage through the chef’s varied selection of recipes and ingredients, some from the Alps, others from countries across the globe. Dishes are served on tasting menus of five, seven or nine courses in a quiet dining room with just a few tables, where the chef himself explains his dishes to guests.

name: Antica Corte Pallavicina
address: strada del Palazzo Due Torri 3, Polesine Parmense, 43016, Italy
description: Situated in a fairytale setting, this property resembles a castle although it was in fact built as a customs house on the Po river in the 14C. It is now renowned for its “culatello”, one of the region’s famous hams. In addition to the culatello, almost all the produce served here is raised or grown on the property. The menu features skilfully prepared traditional dishes, such as the herb tortelli with parmesan and sturgeon from the river, while clay from the Po is used as a way of cooking guinea fowl. The parmesan matured on the premises appears in many of the dishes, alongside a few more creative options.

name: La Bandiera
description: If you’re drawn here for La Bandiera’s delicious, creative reinterpretations of local dishes, you may be surprised to find that the location equals the fine cuisine. Secluded and surrounded by greenery (it’s best to ask for directions before you set out!), the setting is yet another reason for choosing this restaurant. It was a love of cooking and of this region that persuaded Signora Anna many years ago to convert an old tobacco shop into a trattoria. From its early beginnings, the restaurant has grown from strength to strength, supported by hard work and research that has led it to becoming one of the Abruzzo’s leading restaurants, in which aromatic herbs grown in the kitchen garden add extra flavour to the house specialities. Alessio and Mattia Spadone are the third generation of the family that has run the restaurant ever since their grandmother founded it in the late 1970s, followed by their parents, Bruna and Marcello, who transformed it into the elegant, famous restaurant we see today.

name: ARIA
address: via Loggia dei Pisani 2, Naples, 80133, Italy
description: The ambience at this hushed and discreet restaurant couldn’t be more different from the hustle and bustle of the elegant district in which it is situated. The softly lit dining rooms are elegant and minimalist in style, with lamps creating pools of light illuminating the dishes conjured up by Paolo Barrale. Originally from Cefalù but now settled in Campania, the chef’s cuisine is inspired by the culinary traditions of both regions which he reinterprets with ease, occasionally creating more personalised dishes. Generous in every way, from the warm welcome to the cuisine right up to dessert, Paolo offers guests a top-quality dining experience ably assisted by his well-trained, professional staff.

name: Osteria degli Assonica
address: via Don Santo Carminati 9, Sorisole, 24010, Italy
description: A couple of young brothers with plenty of experience behind them work harmoniously together in this restaurant, where they are supported by a talented and innovative female owner. Opened in early 2020 a few kilometres from Bergamo, the restaurant has been renovated and updated in a functional, contemporary style. The cuisine echoes this new look, with modern, colourful and generous dishes of the highest quality. Giovanna Danzo offers friendly and professional service front of house.

name: Lux Lucis
address: viale A. Morin 67, Forte dei Marmi, 55042, Italy
description: A lift takes guests up to the roof garden of this restaurant housed in the Principe Forte dei Marmi hotel, where a terrace provides the perfect setting for an aperitif with its enchanting views of the coast and (if you’re lucky) beautiful sunsets. From here, you move into the dining room preceded by an open-view kitchen. Originally from the hills around Modena, the chef here likes to include Emilian touches in his perfectly presented dishes. The wine list has an unusual layout, with wines listed according to grape variety and each one accompanied by an interesting description.

name: ConFusion
address: via Aga Khan 1, Promenade du Port, Porto Cervo, 07021, Italy
description: This restaurant has brought a breath of fresh air to the area around the port thanks to its enchanting and distinctive decor. With its mirrors, gold-coloured features, glass and open-view kitchen, ConFusion demonstrates its owners’ real attention to detail, which is even more evident in the creative and technically astute dishes prepared by its chef Italo Bassi, making this a truly memorable dining experience. The clean flavours in this chef’s cuisine are the result of precise cooking methods and skill in combining different ingredients to create balanced and elegant dishes. Sardinian ingredients are to the fore here, with raw fish, top-quality meat, oysters and caviar all featuring on the menu, accompanied by excellent wines and a good selection of renowned champagnes.

name: Gabbiano 3.0
address: Porto turistico 11, Marina di Grosseto, 58100, Italy
description: Meals at this restaurant are served in an elegant dining room with views of the marina below or, on warm summer evenings, on the stylish outdoor veranda. The views include some incredible sunsets, with Elba standing out in the distance, as well as Pianosa and even Corsica on the clearest days. In the kitchen, the chef takes guests on a culinary journey with a focus on flavour and contrasts, often creating unusual combinations. There are some excellent wines to accompany the tasting menus, with young, professional staff on hand to offer their recommendations.

name: Il Pievano
address: Località Spaltenna 13, Gaiole in Chianti, 53013, Italy
description: Occupying the charming, romantic setting of a thousand-year-old monastery, this restaurant serves meals either in the Sala dei Papi or at tables arranged in a delightful inner courtyard. Either way, you’re in the capable hands of a young chef who hails originally from Greece. Having fallen in love with Tuscan cuisine, he serves elegantly presented dishes prepared from carefully chosen ingredients (with a focus on local producers). He also demonstrates real skill in creating balanced cuisine with a light Mediterranean touch. Make sure you try the Cantina del Castello wines which are made from the restaurant’s own grapes.

name: Angelo Sabatelli
description: A talented and brilliant chef is at the helm in this restaurant in the town’s historic centre, where elegant, contemporary-style dining rooms provide the backdrop for technical cuisine that showcases local produce with the occasional added Asian flavour. A visit to the large, well-stocked wine cellar is highly recommended (there’s an excellent selection of sparkling wines and champagnes), where a couple of beautiful tables are used for tasting and private dinners.

name: Per Me Giulio Terrinoni
description: This restaurant in the historic centre of Rome is situated in Vicolo del Malpasso, a street famous throughout Italy for its “tappi” (tapas-style snacks). It’s no surprise then that tapas lunches are one of the specialities served by the chef here – elaborate variations with a strong focus on beautiful presentation and decisive, delicious flavours (available only at lunchtime from Monday to Friday). The main courses are also worthy of note and are subdivided according to their method of cooking (fried, roasted or steamed). Ingredients are carefully chosen, and close attention is also paid to guests’ individual requirements (including vegans) – by calling ahead, you can arrange your own ad hoc menu. The restaurant’s concern for its sustainable impact is evident throughout in small yet important details, such as the support given to the district’s local artisans in the choice of decor and furnishings. In summer, make sure that you book ahead if you’d like to dine at one of the few tables in the charming outdoor space.

name: Pascucci al Porticciolo
address: viale Traiano 85, angolo via Fiumara 2, Fiumicino, 00054, Italy
description: A focus on the sea underpins the whole philosophy of this restaurant, which is perhaps not surprising at a coastal location such as Fiumicino! Here, chef Pascucci celebrates the sea to the full on his “Come è profondo il mare” menu which showcases beautifully presented dishes accompanied by a wine list that celebrates local producers from the Lazio coast. The chef selects top-quality local ingredients which he prepares with an almost Oriental precision – we particularly recommend the raw gurnard with ceviche, Kaluga-Amur caviar and courgettes. Vanessa oversees the dedicated front-of-house team, who provide warm and attentive service.

name: Unforgettable
description: Christian Mandura has a simple yet revolutionary philosophy which puts vegetables centre stage. All the courses on his set menu are created around a particular vegetable, with protein ingredients such as meat and fish acting as a side dish. Modern techniques and a passion for cooking are to the fore at this restaurant, which is run by a young management team who aim to surprise their guests with dishes full of colour and flavour as they perch on one of the ten stools arranged around a counter. The new Paradigma menu focuses on using every part of an animal to avoid waste and is served to just four guests in a private room.

name: Local
address: salizzada dei Greci, sestiere Castello 3303, Venice, 30124, Italy
description: An elegant restaurant with a rustic yet chic atmosphere, where the cuisine manages to surprise without losing its connection to local traditions. Here, ingredients from the lagoon are prepared using modern ideas and techniques, resulting in dishes that are carefully balanced and yet full of contrasting flavours. The young female owner and excellent sommelier are friendly, full of energy and attentive to their guests’ every need.

name: Pipero Roma
address: corso Vittorio Emanuele II 250, Rome, 00186, Italy
description: Situated opposite the church of Santa Maria in Vallicella (known to locals as Chiesa Nuova or new church), this restaurant is named after its owner and maître-d’ Alessandro Pipero. Young chef Ciro Scamardella from Campania is at the helm in the kitchen, where he prepares modern dishes with a focus on the seasons, including a few specialities from his native region. His cuisine demonstrates a continuous search for balance and colour – the recipe that particularly impressed our inspectors was his reinterpretation of mussel soup, in which the full flavour of the sea shone through. A second dining room on the first floor, decorated in the same refurbished style, is available for small groups and private dinners.

name: Locanda San Lorenzo
address: via IV Novembre 79, Puos d'Alpago, 32015, Italy
description: The Dal Farra family opened this inn way back in 1900, when the current owner-chef Renzo’s grandparents established a simple osteria-style restaurant to provide meals for workers at the nearby mill. In the 1950s, Renzo’s parents took over at the helm, with a Michelin star awarded to the restaurant in 1997. Passion and consistency are the characteristics that have drawn guests to this restaurant for over a century: the cuisine makes full use of regional ingredients in dishes that have occasionally been reinterpreted with a modern twist. Some guests may prefer the modern dining room, although regulars may well choose the more rustic-style room, where two of the tables are laid out right in front of the fireplace. There’s a good selection of wine, plus a few simple guestrooms on the upper floors.

name: Antonello Colonna Labico
address: via di Valle Fredda 52, Labico, 00030, Italy
description: Situated in a scenically impressive setting nestling in the Vallefredda countryside and housed in an original, avant-garde building, this sophisticated restaurant serves carefully balanced and elegant dishes that underline its proximity to Rome and its close connection with Lazio’s rural traditions. Here, nature and modernity go hand in hand: the restaurant is home to large, almost museum-like rooms adorned with works of art and surrounded by parkland. The dishes, on the other hand, are classic in style, in deliberate contrast to the striking, contemporary backdrop in which they are served, and are inspired by many of Italy’s different culinary traditions. We highly recommended booking a table on the lawn under the mature chestnut trees in summer.

name: Essenza
description: Situated just a stone’s throw from the sea, this restaurant boasts a charming view of the Temple of Jupiter Anxur. However, once in the restaurant itself, your attention is focused fully on the experience that awaits. A modern and elegant dining room provides the setting, where a cheese display and a cabinet used to age premium meats demonstrate that they take their food seriously here! The owner-chef’s cuisine has moved with the times, while still remaining anchored in the region – fish caught in local waters takes pride of place on the menu, while the meat is sourced from around the world. “I never move away from my kitchen” says Simone Nardoni, “so that I can prove to myself every day that it is only through hard work that you achieve your goals”. Looking at his results, how can we not agree?

name: Il Papavero
description: Papavero is the Italian for poppy, a plant which grows tall and has strong roots, making it an apt symbol for this restaurant housed in a palazzo in the town centre. In a few classic-style rooms, the chef offers a menu that focuses on fish and seafood, although ingredients from the surrounding countryside also feature. Simple, solid recipes made with just a few ingredients, exactly as described on the menu, and a passionate dedication to the Mediterranean result in attractive cuisine which also offers good value for money. In fine weather, meals are served outdoors under the jasmine in a romantic garden. A restaurant that appeals to the heart as well as the palate.

name: Il Centro
description: There’s a timeless feel to this restaurant, which serves some of the best Piedmontese cuisine in the region and is run by a highly competent and welcoming family. Heading the team here are Elide in the kitchen, and husband Enrico and talented son Giampiero front of house (the latter a real wine connoisseur who looks after the ever-expanding wine cellar), all of whom continue to maintain the high standards set by Giampiero’s grandparents when they opened this restaurant back in 1956. With skill and dedication, they serve traditional cuisine that is full of substance and flavour, which you could happily eat every day without ever getting bored, including the restaurant’s legendary peppers in a sweet and sour sauce, “agnolotti del plin” and finanziera stew. On certain days in winter, the restaurant offers a delicious Piedmontese “fritto misto” made up of 12 courses of sweet and savoury dishes (it’s essential to book well in advance). Accommodation is available in the elegant Dimora Cordero just a stone’s throw from the restaurant.

name: I Tenerumi
description: At this restaurant, meals are served in the Therasia Resort’s luxuriant garden, which boasts unrivalled panoramic views. In the kitchen, the young chef prepares a menu with 15 courses, each of which is explained in detail when brought to your table. Almost every course is accompanied by a cocktail, with explanations given by the bartender. The delicious desserts provide a fitting conclusion to a truly memorable dining experience.

name: Otto Geleng
description: The elegant atmosphere at this restaurant is typical of Taormina and of Sicily’s old villas. It offers just eight tables laid out on a terrace adorned with bougainvillea and overlooking Taormina, the Bay of Naxos and Etna. The decor here shows real attention to detail, with an emphasis on the splendour of a grand old residence. To this backdrop, chef Roberto Toro creates typical Sicilian dishes reinterpreted with his own personal twist, and where a modern take on tradition and top-quality local ingredients are to the fore. More than 400 different wines are available to accompany this gourmet journey, with a choice of regional, Italian and French labels, including several excellent wines from small local wineries.

name: La Rucola 2.0
description: Situated next to the Castello Scaligero in one of the most attractive alleyways of Sirmione, la Rucola 2.0 is striking for its contemporary ambience dominated by a profusion of wood. The cuisine has the same modern feel as the decor, maintaining its creative focus over the years. Saltwater fish and seafood continue to take pride of place on the menu, which also features meat and freshwater fish options. The formula here focuses on tasting menus, although it is possible to choose different combinations of dishes from the à la carte.

name: Retroscena
address: largo del Teatro 3, Porto San Giorgio, 63822, Italy
description: One of the most interesting Michelin-starred restaurants in the region. Situated among houses with brick façades in Porto San Giorgio’s charming historic centre, this restaurant has just a few tables in an elegant, minimalist-style dining room. When focusing on their food, the attention of guests will be also drawn to the open-view kitchen, where the team led by Richard Abou Zaki prepares remarkable and often exciting dishes. Although this young yet highly experienced chef’s cuisine reveals influences from his time spent in Modena, for the most part his dishes are original, personalised and imaginative.

name: Iacobucci
address: via Ronco 1, Villa Zarri, Castel Maggiore, 40013, Italy
description: Large, well-spaced-out tables arranged in a charming historic setting make this a restaurant for special occasions, whether you’re here for a romantic dinner or simply for a gourmet experience. Here, chef Agostino Iacobucci serves unmissable classic favourites, from interpretations of raw fish to his famous babà dessert. The restaurant is housed in Villa Zarri, an enchanting late-16C residence surrounded by mature grounds.

name: Li Galli
description: This restaurant housed within the elegant Villa Franca hotel in the upper part of Positano boasts a small, bright dining room with distinctive black marble tables (just seven of them!), a glass ceiling and floor-to-ceiling windows that open in summer to create an outdoor dining space. The beautiful view looks out to sea and Li Galli, the island after which the restaurant is named. Following the end of the restaurant’s partnership with Nino Di Costanzo, chef Savio Perna (originally from Torre del Greco) now steps into the spotlight on his own. He takes his inspiration mainly from the local region, although the pigeon in one of his more interesting dishes is sourced from one of the best breeders in Tuscany. Much of Perna’s technique focuses on beautiful presentation and a light touch, while the excellent service also adds to guests’ overall enjoyment of the dining experience. The trolleys that display a selection of olive oils, excellent bread and a choice of tempting desserts are also worth a special mention. The wine list practically spans the globe with around 1 000 different labels – France and Italy take centre stage, with a focus on champagne (especially Krug), with many wines also available by the glass.

name: Il Desco
address: via Dietro San Sebastiano 7, Verona, 37121, Italy
description: With its classic and elegant decor, salon-like ambience and excellent cuisine, this restaurant in the heart of Verona is a perfect choice for a special occasion. The long-established Il Desco serves dishes which have become renowned classics over the years and which are always a delight to rediscover. Recently, the cuisine has been given an interesting and innovative twist with the arrival of son Matteo Rizzo in the kitchen.

name: Vitium
description: A young chef from Puglia is at the helm in this restaurant occupying a historic palazzo in the centre of Crema. Despite its location, you’ll only find a tiny hint of Crema and Puglia in the excellent creative cuisine on offer which showcases the exceptional talents of this skilful chef.

name: Luisl Stube
description: Chef Luis Haller is at the helm in the kitchen at Luisl Stube, an elegant restaurant housed in a charming 16C building. Cooking with almost entirely local ingredients, such as Laugen beef, Cembran pine-nuts, and vegetables grown according to permaculture principles, the chef creates dishes which are modern yet unfussy in style. The service and choice of wines (featuring over 400 labels) is of the same high quality.

name: L'Arcade
address: lungomare Gramsci 315, Porto San Giorgio, 63822, Italy
description: This restaurant wholeheartedly embraces the sea, whether via its views visible through the floor-to-ceiling windows in the dining room, or through its cuisine with its focus on fish and seafood. Dishes are served on a tasting menu (from which single dishes can also be chosen à la carte), with a meat menu also available if booked ahead of time. Chef Sergeev Nikita, who arrived in Italy as a child, creates technically skilful, creative cuisine which is both surprising and entertaining.

name: Abbruzzino
address: via Fiume Savuto, località Santo Janni, Catanzaro, 88100, Italy
description: Temporarily closed for renovation. The elegant and welcoming Abbruzzino is still a good choice for anyone looking for a flavour of this region, showcased through its cuisine and the chef’s personal memories, reinterpreted with a modern twist. At the helm in the kitchen, Luca (the son of owner Antonio) offers dishes which perfectly combine creativity with Calabrian traditions, while the well-structured wine list demonstrates a real passion for local wines. Professional service, to which the presence of the chef’s mother in the dining room adds a pleasant and authentic family feel.

name: Mammà
description: Not far from Capri’s piazzetta, the island’s fashionable centre, this restaurant is accessed via a dark, narrow tunnel that is part of medieval Capri, which makes the dining room’s bright interior with its views of the Bay of Naples even more of a surprise. Chef Raffaele Amitrano creates two different types of cuisine here: traditional dishes from Campania at lunchtime, and more elaborate, creative and expensive options (yet still very much influenced by the region) in the evening.

name: Cielo
description: Cielo (“heaven” in Italian) is part of the aptly named La Sommità hotel, which occupies a large house in typical local style at the top of this whitewashed town with its medieval limestone steps known as “chianche”. The perfect setting for a romantic summer dinner, either among the citrus trees in the small inner courtyard or in the dining room crowned with a vaulted ceiling, this restaurant serves regionally inspired cuisine to which the chef adds his own creative twist. Guests choose from a number of different tasting menus (including a vegetarian menu) or from the well-structured à la carte with its choice of meat and fish dishes.

The name of this restaurant refers to the year in which the hotel in which it is located (the Park Hotel Holzner) was opened, while the design is a nod to the Liberty style of the period. Despite this, both the ambience and the cuisine bear the modern and imaginative hallmark of Stephan Zippl. Paying careful attention to sustainability, this chef selects the best regional produce for his dishes – even the Wagyu beef is raised in the chef’s native Renon region. This strong connection with the Alto Adige is also evident on the excellent wine list, which features almost 400 labels from the region and provides perfect pairings for the chef’s tasting menu. Other options include non-alcoholic drinks such as apple juice and alcohol-free cocktails.

name: President
description: A mathematician in the kitchen! Although it sounds like a film title, this is the career path of owner-chef Paolo Gramaglia who, together with his charming wife Laila (a lawyer by profession), runs this elegant restaurant just over 500m from Pompeii’s archaeological site. Both the food and the hospitality are excellent at this restaurant, where this dynamic couple give guests their undivided attention. Laila takes care of the wine and front of house, while Paolo dedicates himself to creating delicious, seasonal and moderately creative dishes from the Campania, including the occasional reinterpretation of traditional dishes from Pompeii. You’ll also find intriguing mathematical references in Italian on the menu – feel free to ask the chef for explanations! The dining room boasts beautiful furnishings and careful lighting but has just five tables so it’s best to book ahead.

name: Borgo Sant'Anna
description: Having worked in Piedmont for many years, Puglian chef Pasquale Laera has accumulated vast knowledge of the region’s culinary traditions. The result is a personalised menu which showcases local dishes alongside more creative options. The restaurant stands in a beautiful setting of rolling hills, which can be admired from the outdoor terrace in summer and from the glass-walled veranda in winter. A few tables have been arranged directly in front of the kitchen allowing guests to watch the chefs at work.

name: Sedicesimo Secolo
address: via Gerolanuova 4, località Pudiano, Pudiano, 25034, Italy
description: Taking its name from the period in which it was built (the 16C), this restaurant boasts a modern decor which adds a light touch to the dining room with its paved floors, original ceilings and fireplaces. The imaginative menu features decidedly modern and creative dishes with an emphasis on meat, although a few fish options and regional specialities are also available. There’s plenty of choice for all tastes here, with carefully designed dishes prepared by a skilful chef who is well versed in the basics of culinary chemistry and who has a fine palate with a light touch. There’s an interesting selection of different breads, while the choice of coffees includes some rare blends.

name: Il Piastrino
description: The home of Riccardo and Claudia, Il Piastrino is situated amid the beautiful Montefeltro hills. A long-held dream for this couple, which they nurtured during their formative years working in various Michelin-starred restaurants, the restaurant was finally opened in 2007. Beautifully looked after and embellished with each passing year, the house now boasts a magnificent contemporary decor that is in total harmony with the warm rustic nature of its surroundings. The restaurant’s crowning glory is Agostino’s technical, creative cuisine, which showcases the best seasonal ingredients, often sourced from the local region. This chef’s dishes are a feast for the eyes and the palate, often complex and elaborate in style yet never overly artificial.

name: Massimo Camia
address: strada provinciale 3 Alba-Barolo 122, La Morra, 12064, Italy
description: In this restaurant decorated with modern furnishings, the attention is drawn to the picture windows which offer fine views of the La Morra hills and surrounding countryside. Massimo Camia’s menu includes classic favourites from his much-loved repertoire, plus a few elegant dishes and some fish specialities. The excellent selection of Piedmontese cheese is also worth a mention, as is the extensive choice of Barolo wines on the wine list.

name: La Pineta
address: via dei Cavalleggeri Nord 27, Marina di Bibbona, 57020, Italy
description: You pass through a pine forest to get here, taking your car almost as far as the shoreline where you arrive at the long-established fish restaurant run by the Zazzeri family, housed in what at first appears to be an ordinary private beach club. Picture windows offer views of the waves lapping on the beach, while at lunchtime in summer there are sunshades and bathers on the beach, with the ebb and flow of the sea providing an expanse of blue in the background. The menu here features classic Tuscan and Italian dishes, all prepared using traditional methods: irrespective of whether you prefer your fish raw, grilled, steamed or baked, the quality is paramount. The atmosphere here is so relaxing that you’ll find yourself in no hurry to leave!

name: Cracco
address: Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, Milan, 20121, Italy
description: The Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is one of the most iconic sights in Milan and as such it is apt that it is home to this star of Italian cuisine. Cracco is not just a gourmet restaurant – it’s also a bistro and an excellent pastry shop which is open all day, with separate spaces for special events on the top floor. At the helm in the kitchen, chef Luca Sacchi (ably assisted by owner Carlo) creates top-quality cuisine with impeccable technique, inspired by the culinary traditions of Milan and the broader Mediterranean with fish from Liguria taking pride of place on the menu – the chef also has a new restaurant in Portofino. The wine list is an experience in itself, offering one of the best and most comprehensive selections of French wines in Italy, as well as an excellent choice of wines by the glass. Guests also have the opportunity to taste wines from the organic Vistamare estate situated in the Romagnole hills. The professional career of the chef at Cracco is one of the most impressive in Italy, with influences that include the culinary master Alain Ducasse and wine expert Giorgio Pinchiorri. The most popular tables are those by the window with views of the Ottagono building.

name: Esplanade
address: via Lario 3, Desenzano del Garda, 25015, Italy
description: This long-established address is one of the best restaurants on Lake Garda, boasting luxuriant gardens in a panoramic location with an outdoor space overlooking the lake, as well as refined and elegant dining rooms. The menu offers an extensive choice, including an equal balance of meat and fish (most of the latter comes from Sardinia) without compromising on the quality of the cuisine – the ingredients, technical precision and presentation of the dishes are all excellent. In addition, the portions here are strikingly generous – it would be difficult to find a restaurant that serves such large portions with this level of quality. Mention should also be made of the excellent wine list, which will appeal to aficionados of sparkling wine: it includes labels from Italy, over 200 different champagnes, and wines from further afield, including England.

name: Anna Stuben
description: Although many brilliant “Anna’s” have cooked in this family-run restaurant over the years, for the past ten years there has been a superb male chef – Reimund Brunner – at the helm. The romantic ambience of the two Stube-style dining rooms is now famous, having become one of the places that you want to visit every time you return to the Val Gardena. The cuisine is inspired by the Alto Adige, yet also remains open to ingredients from further afield, including fish and seafood, in dishes which are lighter and fresh in style with a reduced use of butter and sugar. The service is excellent and highly attentive to guests’ needs, while the talented sommelier is always on hand to offer recommendations with a smile. Last but not least, this excellent restaurant is housed within the Alpine-style Gardenia hotel which offers classically elegant guestrooms which pay little heed to passing trends.

name: Iyo
address: via Piero della Francesca 74, Milan, 20154, Italy
description: The cuisine served at the elegant Iyo is heavily influenced by Japan while at the same time being rooted in Italian flavours and traditions. The extensive à la carte includes the type of dishes that you would expect of a Japanese restaurant (such as well-known versions of sushi, sashimi and tempura, to name just a few), alongside more creative fusion recipes which combine influences from Japan, Europe and elsewhere. There’s also an excellent selection of around 500 wines, including the option of ordering wine by the glass.

name: Lorenzo
address: via Carducci 61, Forte dei Marmi, 55042, Italy
description: This gastronomic institution has been an emblem of the Versilia region for the past 40 years, offering unchanging quality ever since it opened in 1981. The baton is slowly passing now to daughter Chiara, an expert sommelier who, together with her staff, ensures that guests enjoy the best possible experience. Surrounded by contemporary works of art (a passion inherited from great-grandfather Lorenzo after whom the restaurant is named), guests are guaranteed a fine dining experience thanks to the excellent fish dishes (some of the best in Italy) as well as iconic dishes such as spaghetti alla versiliese and other delicacies on the three tasting menus (Cuori, Picche, Quadri). The wine cellar is also worthy of praise, with its two wine lists (one dedicated to Italy, the other to non-Italian wines) that will appeal to connoisseurs with their excellent vintages and renowned labels.

name: Casa Sgarra
description: Three brothers (two front of house and one in the kitchen) offer a friendly welcome at this modern, elegant restaurant on the seafront at Trani, just a 20min walk from the town’s picturesque port. Although the menu also features dishes from other parts of Italy (especially Piedmont), on the whole the cuisine here is typical of Puglia, featuring local ingredients such a broad beans, almonds from Toritto, burrata and ricotta cheese, truffles and black chickpeas from Murgia, “grano arso” flour and, of course, the region’s excellent olive oils. The friendly, welcoming feel of the restaurant is summed up in the slogan that the three brothers have chosen for their restaurant – “a family story”. And, we would add, a story of fine cuisine!

name: Quintessenza
description: Having moved to new premises near Castello Svevo and Santa Maria Assunta cathedral, this restaurant now boasts splendid views from its outdoor terrace and a comfortable, historic ambience in its other dining spaces (including a cellar) which are decorated in tasteful contemporary style. Quintessenza remains in the capable hands of the Di Gennaro family – four brothers (including head chef Stefano) who are equally passionate about Puglia and its excellent ingredients, especially fish and seafood, all of which are showcased in the superb, precisely prepared modern cuisine served here. There’s just one table in the splendid wine cellar (book well in advance), which offers a fine selection of wines including a few labels by the glass.

name: Somu
address: piazza Due Vele, Baia Sardinia, 07021, Italy
description: With experience in Michelin-starred restaurants behind him, owner-chef Salvatore Camedda demonstrates his talents to the full in this restaurant, where he combines top-quality Sardinian ingredients with flavours and aromas discovered on his travels around the world. Every dish showcases the superb produce of the region, from casizolu and fiore sardo cheeses to Cabras bottarga  (cured fish roe) and wild herbs from the Costa Smeralda, all prepared in contemporary style with combinations that are unusual not only for the general public but also for more gourmet-focused palates. The stunning location offers views of the beach and the bay.

name: Paca
description: Just a stone’s throw from the historic centre, this restaurant serves modern Italian cuisine prepared with carefully chosen ingredients sourced, where possible, from local and zero-kilometre producers. The excellent service adds to this pleasant gourmet experience in the town of Prato.

name: Casual
description: This restaurant boasts a delightful urban setting at the entrance to Bergamo Alta, not far from the picturesque hills that surround the town. Although Casual is run by Enrico Bartolini, Marco Galtarossa has made a name for himself at the helm in the kitchen. This young, surprisingly skilful chef prepares delicious, generous cuisine, where every dish is a feast in itself. His plentiful use of vegetables and aromatic herbs and pleasing balance of acidic and bitter flavours result in colourful and carefully presented dishes. The specialities on the two tasting menus can be exchanged for options on the à la carte.

name: Famiglia Rana
address: via Feniletto 2, località Vallese, Oppeano, 37050, Italy
description: Situated in the countryside to the south of Verona, where industrial zones alternate with small oases of greenery, this restaurant run by the famous Rana family features the creative cuisine of chef Giuseppe D’Aquino, who combines regional recipes with international influences to create carefully prepared and beautifully presented dishes. Good selection of wines to accompany your meal.

name: La Cru
description: Temporarily closed. The Valpantena hills, halfway between Verona and the Lessini mountains and famous for their Amarone wines, are home to this restaurant. La Cru is housed in a new building which forms part of the 15C Villa Balis Crema hotel (which now also offers splendid guestrooms). Here, the kitchen is the heart of this modern, open-plan dining room decorated in wood and burnished steel (some of which is recycled), while floor-to-ceiling windows offer relaxing views of the garden with its biodynamic vegetable plot, the source of many of the chef’s ingredients. The kitchen team creates imaginative dishes which stand out for their precision and careful presentation with a light touch. In the villa itself, enjoy regional cuisine at Bottega & Cucina

name: Il Cascinalenuovo
description: Having been in business for over 50 years and with a newly expanded team, Il Cascinalenuovo continues to serve its classic favourites (such as veal’s tongue millefeuille and foie gras with port jelly, and Piedmontese tonnato) while also extending its repertoire to include new options, including fish. The Ferretto brothers are still at the helm here, one front of house, the other in the kitchen. If the weather allows, book a table in the attractive outdoor space overlooking the garden and swimming pool.

name: Capriccio
address: piazza San Bernardo 6, località Montinelle, Manerba del Garda, 25080, Italy
description: This restaurant standing on the shores of Lake Garda has been famous ever since it opened in the mid-1960s, thanks to its female owner’s passion for fish and seafood from the Mediterranean. Today, Giuliana continues to showcase fresh fish in her classic-style recipes and demonstrates real skill in bringing out the full flavour of her ingredients on a menu which also includes a few meat specialities. Among her memorable historic dishes are the aubergine parmigiana (on the menu since 1965) and the red berry soup marinated in cooked wine must and served with ice-cream and Italian-style meringue. Daughter Francesca offers guests a friendly welcome front of house, assisting them with their choice of dishes and also providing wine pairing recommendations. The interesting wine list will delight lovers of champagne and German Riesling. In summer, take a seat in the large, comfortable outdoor dining space with the restaurant’s bucolic garden in front of you and the lake in the background.

name: Veritas
description: The flavours of Naples reinterpreted in simple, convincing dishes in which imagination goes hand in hand with tradition. Situated near the Vomero district, this welcoming restaurant offers attentive service and has an excellent sommelier who will be happy to guide you in your choice of wine, including recommendations from exciting small wineries from Campania.

name: Shalai
description: Situated in the historic centre of Linguaglossa, one of the most picturesque villages around Etna, this restaurant is part of the highly recommended hotel of the same name which occupies a delightful 19C palazzo. The Pennisi family are at the helm, alongside chef Giovanni Santoro, a partnership which has resulted in a long-standing Michelin star here on the slopes of Mt Etna. Santoro creates extraordinarily varied cuisine, which is not surprising given that Linguaglossa is situated in a mountainous region with rich volcanic soil that produces a whole host of unrivalled ingredients, with the added advantage of being just a few kilometres from the sea. Superb wine list, including magnums, vertical wines and top-quality labels from Etna.

name: L'Argine a Vencò
address: Località Vencò 15, Dolegna del Collio, 34070, Italy
description: This perfectly restored old mill is home to a chef who creates original cuisine that demonstrates her connection with her region and showcases ingredients grown in the restaurant’s own kitchen garden, especially the aromatic herbs that are a characteristic feature of many of the dishes served here. Antonia Klugmann’s house stands in attractive unspoilt scenery near the Slovenian border and in the middle of two major wine-producing areas, namely the Colli Orientali del Friuli and the better-known Collio, both of which are well represented on the extensive wine list.

name: Cannavacciuolo Countryside
description: This restaurant tells the story of chef Antonino Cannavacciuolo, who created this special place to reconnect with his childhood memories (his grandfather was once the caretaker here) and its sense of hospitality. This chef’s culinary philosophy is ably interpreted by resident chef Nicola Somma, who celebrates the region by combining ingredients from Cannavacciuolo’s adopted home with his native region in a journey that takes guests from northern to southern Italy. The ingredients used are carefully chosen and either sourced from local producers or grown in the restaurant’s own kitchen garden, keeping alive the precious traditions that have influenced this chef’s character and culinary skill. There’s an excellent and constantly expanding wine list, which will more than satisfy even the most demanding wine-buffs. An unforgettable, relaxing gourmet experience in a bucolic setting.

name: Matteo Grandi
description: Matteo Grandi moved from the province of Verona to these elegant premises near the Renaissance-style Basilica Palladiana. Despite the change of venue, his cuisine remains the same, showcasing a culinary philosophy which avoids fat and is fully focused on flavour. Made from top-quality ingredients, the chef’s dishes are balanced and skilfully imaginative, with the occasional exotic twist thanks to his previous experience working in China. His wife Elena Lanza oversees the front of house with elegance and expertise.

name: Lorelei
description: The two cornerstones of this chef’s philosophy are zero-mile produce and seasonality. Passionate about aromatic herbs, Ciro Sicignano tends his own garden not far from the restaurant. His dishes showcase the abundance of this region that has few equals when it comes to its variety of ingredients. It’s difficult to imagine a more romantic setting in fine weather than the terrace here with its soft light and stunning views. Interesting choice of regional wines, including many also available by the glass.

name: Acqua Pazza
address: via Dietro la Chiesa 3/4, Ponza, 04027, Italy
description: This restaurant boasts a glamourous setting with terraces on different levels offering breathtaking views and a space for pre-dinner drinks, while the soft candlelight and cooling sea breeze (so welcome after a day in the sun) add to the romantic appeal. Patrizia Ronca’s cuisine showcases ingredients from the island, including delicious fish prepared with an imaginative touch. The raw fish dishes are highly recommended.

name: Wistèria
address: fondamenta del Forner, sestiere San Polo 2908, Venice, 30125, Italy
description: Situated along the Rio de la Frescada, one of Venice’s many quiet side canals, this restaurant’s small entrance overlooks an outdoor dining space enhanced by the wisteria which provides the outdoor tables with shade, and which gives the restaurant its name. New chef Valerio Dallamano has many years of experience with the Alajmo family, delighting guests with dishes made from seasonal ingredients that reflect the diversity of the region. Full of character in terms of its presentation, the cuisine showcases the best of Venice’s gastronomic traditions in contemporary dishes featured on six- or eight-course tasting menus.

name: The Cook
description: Housed in the beautiful 14C Branca Doria palazzo in Genova’s historic centre with its typical narrow alleyways, this restaurant boasts an extraordinary ceiling decorated with frescoes by Bernardo Strozzi in 1618. Chef Ivano Ricchebono’s cuisine is served on three tasting menus from which guests can choose courses à la carte style, even combining dishes from different menus. The cuisine is largely creative in style, with an equal balance of meat and fish options available.

name: Tilia
description: This glass and steel cube in the middle of the garden of the former Grand Hotel in Dobbiaco has been home to the Tilia restaurant since 2010 and is now more intimate than ever, with just five tables and seating for 12 diners (booking is highly recommended). Chef Chris Oberhammer’s menu is enticing, featuring just under 20 dishes with a modern yet regional flavour. Many of the ingredients (such as the flour and some of the meat) are sourced from the “Klaude” farm which is run by one of the chef’s childhood friends with whom he works very closely, while other more exotic fare comes from further afield, adding luxury ingredients such as caviar, truffles (in season) and prawns to the mix. Anita Mancini oversees the front of house with skill and professionalism, as well as taking care of the wine list which includes a selection of international labels.

name: Vescovado
description: This restaurant serves dishes full of distinctive character in the 15C rooms of the prestigious building complex known as the Palazzo Vescovile, as well as on an attractive terrace with sea views in summer. Giuseppe Ricchebuono focuses on local ingredients in his dishes, showcasing heritage grains from Monteggio and other ingredients sourced from small local producers from the region. There’s no improvisation in this chef’s cooking; instead, he uses a variety of culinary and cutting techniques that have developed over years of experience and that result in firm, simple and authentic flavours. The wine list is subdivided into two sections – one dedicated to regional wines and the other to labels from elsewhere in Italy – with the option of ordering excellent wines by the glass.

name: Contaminazioni Restaurant
address: via San Sossio 2, Somma Vesuviana, 80049, Italy
description: Temporarily closed.There’s a real fusion of styles in this restaurant, where chef Giuseppe Molaro draws on his time spent working in Japan to play with highly personalised techniques, flavours and cooking methods which result in delicate and cerebral cuisine. Although the ingredients here come from Campania and the Mediterranean, the style of cuisine is very different. This superb dining experience will take guests on a fascinating culinary journey in which lightness of touch is paramount. Guests choose between three tasting menus, while the chef’s wife offers friendly yet professional service which aims to ensure that guests fully understand the philosophy behind the cuisine served here.

name: Virtuoso Gourmet - Tenuta Le Tre Virtù
address: Località Lucigliano 13, San Piero a Sieve, 50037, Italy
description: Nestled in the bucolic setting of the Mugello hills less than 50km from Florence, this rustic-chic restaurant pays tribute to Tuscany thanks to chef Antonello Sardi, who is himself from Florence. Having learned modern techniques in previous restaurants, Sardi also keeps the connection with his region alive. Although many of the ingredients used in his two tasting menus are home-produced, the chef has also forged strong links with small producers from across the region, showcasing top-quality produce and early fruit and vegetables. The wine list demonstrates the same focus on the region (as well as a love for France), with a good selection of local labels. Seven charming suites in rustic Tuscan style are also available.

name: Lino
description: A centrally located restaurant decorated in elegant style with hints of Art Deco design. Here, executive chef Andrea Ribaldone creates light, contemporary dishes on tasting menus which vary in length and where courses can be transferred from one menu to another; dessert can also be served in a small, intimate lounge with comfortable sofas and armchairs. More simple fare is available at the Bistrot, which is open daily for lunch and dinner.

name: Casa Vicina
description: Renowned over the years for its traditional Piedmontese cuisine, Casa Vicina is situated near the Lingotto factory (easily accessible by metro if you don’t have a car) on the top floor of the “Green Pea”, a building that showcases sustainable and environmentally friendly products. Meat dishes (including specialities such as Fassone steak in a tuna sauce, rabbit and ossobuco-filled agnolotti pasta) dominate the main courses although fish options are also available. Make sure you leave room for desserts such as ice cream, zabaglione and Ivrea tart.

name: Piano 35
description: With its geothermal energy, self-regulating lighting that reacts to natural light, and “double skin” façade, the tower block housing this restaurant is unique for its innovative architecture and materials and its cutting-edge technology. And there’s more – Piano 35 is situated within the building’s bio-climatic greenhouse, a unique high-altitude garden that extends from the 35th to the 37th floors. Here, the restaurant serves three different menus: “In Piemonte” pays tribute to the culinary traditions of Piedmont; “Giro d’Italia” focuses on ingredients and recipes from all over Italy; and “Piccolo Lago a Torino” features some of the most famous dishes created by chef Marco Sacco (ably assisted here by Christian Balzo) at the two-Michelin-starred Piccolo Lago restaurant in Verbania. Each of the menus can be ordered as a lighter four-course version or the full seven-course option. Lighter bistro-style meals are available at lunchtime.

name: Damini Macelleria & Affini
description: Gourmet food, a wine boutique and luxury butcher’s shop all in one, this restaurant serves remarkable produce and delicious cuisine at the tables behind its gleaming windows, while its wide selection of wines is announced at your table by the owner himself. Without doubt, this is a highly original gourmet experience in which respect for ingredients and culinary expertise results in strong, enticing flavours. It’s no surprise that particular attention is paid to the choice of meat, much of which comes from the restaurant’s own farm in Trezzo sull’Adda: meat is aged on site, with the duration depending on the type of meat (up to 100 days for the famous Gallega and Wagyu). Here, the cuisine appeals directly to the heart and the senses!

name: All'Enoteca
description: Standing at the beginning of the gracious Corso Roma, considered to be the town’s “showroom” with its elegant shops selling gourmet delicacies, this restaurant occupies a simple yet refined dining room on the first floor of a 19C palazzo, where Davide Palluda continues to delight guests year after year. His high-quality, memorable dishes speak for him. Based on faithfully interpreted Piedmontese recipes, such as the excellent plin al sugo d’arrosto, or skilfully updated with no unnecessary frills, his cuisine aims to satisfy his guests at every turn. The quality of the bread (especially the potato focaccia) deserves a special mention, as does the trolley with tasty delicacies that follows after dessert. There’s a terrace planted with a wisteria for fine weather dining, while the Osteria on the ground floor serves simpler, more reasonably priced fare in a pleasant, original ambience.

name: Osteria Acquarol
address: via Johann Georg Plazer 10, San Michele, 39057, Italy
description: A centrally located restaurant with a small outdoor area for summer dining, the Osteria Acquarol serves dishes which are strongly rooted in the region yet prepared with modern techniques and their own individual character. Regionally sourced sustainable ingredients often feature in the cuisine which, despite its local roots, is highly original thanks to the owner-chef from Cremona and his Mexican wife. Along with a liberal use of wild herbs, Latin-American touches add a vibrant flavour to the chef’s delicious recipes. The extremely long tasting menu can be divided into shorter options and dishes can also be chosen from the à la carte. An excellent wine selection completes the picture.

name: Il Tiglio
address: via Isola San Biagio 34, Montemonaco, 63088, Italy
description: Clinging to the slopes at the foot of Monte Sibilla, Il Tiglio has returned to its original home after a few years based in Porto Recanati. The new modern, designer-style restaurant includes a few sections of the original building which was destroyed in the 2016 earthquake. Chef Enrico Mazzaroni describes himself as a “mountain chef”, but one with a weakness for fish specialities, so don’t be surprised to find rabbit in tempura, clams with potatoes or pasta, squid cream, pheasant ragù and tobiko on the menu. You can also choose between two tasting menus: “Ritorno”, where the dishes are chosen from the à la carte, and “Transumanza” which features more elaborate and experimental options using local specialities and ingredients such as chitterlings, fish and seafood.

name: La Palta
address: Località Bilegno, Borgonovo Val Tidone, 29011, Italy
description: Situated on the plain at the foot of the hills visible in the distance, this restaurant resembles a typical country house with an elegant dining room that extends into a kind of covered veranda, the windows of which open on to the garden and the greenery of the Bassa Piacentina countryside. The ambience here is pleasant and relaxed, perfect for an elegant dining experience and yet not too formal. Although the menu features local ingredients and recipes, such as the excellent focaccia (bread is a house speciality) served with ciccioli (pork scratchings), the cuisine is creative without being overly fussy, and aims to please rather than amaze the palate. Isa Mazzocchi, winner of the 2021 Michelin Female Chef award sponsored by Veuve Clicquot, is at the helm here.

name: Già Sotto l'Arco
description: A historic name among Puglia’s Michelin-starred restaurants, this refined property has an equally historic setting on the first floor of a Baroque palazzo in an elegant piazza. A fine staircase leads up to the simple yet stylish dining room which is typically Puglian in feel and which is skilfully run by a father and daughter team, occasionally assisted by the son when his medical studies allow. Delicious meat and fish dishes feature on the menu, prepared by the chef using regional ingredients alongside produce from further afield, weaving it all together in a style of cuisine that is creatively Italian. Excellent choice of wine, thanks to the owner’s passion for and involvement in wine (and olive oil) production over the past few years. There’s also an intriguing selection of spirits.

name: La Fermata
description: Situated in the countryside around Alessandria, this 18C farmhouse has a modern, minimalist decor which serves as a backdrop for traditional Piedmontese cuisine with a clever modern twist. The chef offers just the right amount of creativity, with a focus on meat dishes and satisfying, memorable flavours that appeal to the emotions as well as the palate. Adding to the appeal, the elegant and exclusive ambience is the result of careful refurbishment, which has transformed the dining room into a triumph of art and design.

name: El Molin
description: The sound of the creaking old wooden floor welcomes you to this old 17C mill, where owner-chef Gilmozzi acts as your culinary Alpine guide with his single tasting menu (guests also have the option of a slightly shorter menu) which showcases his love and passion for the mountains. Smoked produce and an incredible use of native herbs, bark, lichens and resins feature alongside unique cheeses, intensely flavoured wild game and freshwater fish, while the chef’s creativity and careful research guides his choice of cooking methods. Cuisine from a true artist!

name: I Tigli in Theoria
description: Situated just a stone’s throw from the lake in the 15C Palazzo del Vescovo, this restaurant boasts a charming inner courtyard embellished with a mature pittosporum tree. The dining room is equally delightful, with its coffered ceiling and paintings on the walls, all of which contribute to a setting that is perfect for a romantic evening. And there’s more: if you want to watch the chef at work, there’s a second room with an open-view kitchen, and then, in complete contrast, a series of Stube-style rooms arranged over two floors. And last but not least, a lounge bar. The menu is as enticing as the setting, featuring traditional dishes that are warm and comforting – the crowning glory of a great restaurant!

name: Il Cantuccio
description: This welcoming, beautifully kept restaurant in the heart of green Brianza has a romantic and elegantly rustic feel. Here, enjoy opulent and generous cuisine created by chef Mauro Elli who moves easily between classic Italian favourites, occasionally adding his own individual touch to the dishes. His imaginative reinterpretations demonstrate a fascination with the sea (despite the restaurant’s geographical location), while the menu also offers “daily game specials” throughout the year. The focus here is on serving dishes full of flavour, rather than following passing trends.

name: Gardenia
description: The beautiful wooden cart planted with herbs and flowers (especially in spring) that greets visitors to this restaurant gives a good idea of the cuisine served here. Mariangela Susigan creates solid Piedmontese dishes with a focus on vegetables that demonstrates her love of nature, often using ingredients grown in the property’s own kitchen garden. The interior dining rooms are very comfortable, especially the highly recommended rooms on the first floor which are decorated with arte povera furnishings that give them a warm and convivial feel. In this late-19C house surrounded by greenery, the glass- and wrought-iron conservatory provides a beautiful setting for interesting cuisine with a focus on vegetables and rare species. Not to be missed!

name: Coria
description: Situated in the historic centre of this unique city, just 200m from the famous Santa Maria del Monte staircase, this restaurant is named after Giuseppe Coria, a passionate expert on local cuisine and the author of the cookery book “Profumi di Sicilia” (Flavours of Sicily) – the very same flavours that you’ll find in the cuisine here. In two simple, contemporary-style rooms, owner-chefs Domenico Colonnetta and Francesco Patti, both of whom trained with Ciccio Sultano, serve confidently prepared and original cuisine which is far from ordinary.

name: La Trattoria Enrico Bartolini
address: Località Badiola, Castiglione della Pescaia, 58043, Italy
description: After a majestic picture-postcard approach via a long avenue lined with cypress trees and maritime pines, passing vineyards and Maremma cattle along the way, you finally arrive at this restaurant which serves trattoria-style cuisine full of intense, familiar and reassuring flavours. The decor here is elegant with the occasional rustic touch, while the service is of the highest level yet pleasantly friendly and informal. Welcome to Bartolini’s Maremma restaurant! Here, resident chef Bruno De Moura Cossio offers a choice of dishes with one common denominator, namely charcoal grilling. All the dishes served here have been grilled in some way, so that they have a distinctive barbecued flavour. However, although the chef’s Brazilian origins are obvious in many different ways, the ingredients are resolutely local, some even from the restaurant’s own farm. The friendly service makes guests feel completely at home, while the excellent wine selection is an added attraction – those produced on the estate itself are highly recommended.

name: Dal Corsaro
description: An address which showcases and pays tribute to Sardinia’s culinary culture, Dal Corsaro is an unmissable restaurant with a simple and elegant decor of arches, paintings and mirrors situated in the historic heart of the island’s capital city, just a stone’s throw from the port.The modern and imaginative cuisine is inspired by local ingredients and created by chef Stefano Deidda, the third generation to run this family restaurant, ably assisted by his wife front of house. The accomplished and thoughtful cuisine includes intriguing dishes that reflect and at the same time elevate the best Sardinian traditions on three tasting menus that feature meat and fish dishes alike.

name: Nove
description: It's difficult to imagine a more exclusive setting for Giorgio Pignagnoli’s restaurant than the Villa della Pergola, a splendid historic residence surrounded by a delightful botanic garden (which can be visited by prior appointment). Dishes are served in an elegant dining room or, when the weather allows, on a spectacular large balcony with views of the sea extending to the horizon. Originally from Milan and with plenty of experience in renowned restaurants behind him, this young chef has become an expert in Ligurian cuisine, creating a range of regional dishes alongside more imaginative options. Vegetables – to which he dedicates a whole menu – feature strongly in his dishes, many sourced from the villa’s own kitchen garden. Superb, exclusive guestrooms and tranquil surroundings, despite the proximity to Alassio which extends beyond the villa gardens.

name: Andrea Monesi - Locanda di Orta
address: via Olina 18, Orta San Giulio, 28016, Italy
description: Situated in the historic centre of one of the most romantic lakeside villages in Italy, and offering a picture-postcard view of bygone days, this small building houses a contemporary-style restaurant (including a recently opened private dining room) with just one table for two on its romantic outdoor terrace. The cuisine here is creative and precise, with a menu that features fish and seafood alongside top-quality meat from the Piedmont. Each recipe is personalised, often focusing on contrasting flavours and textures, while the wine list is overseen by an excellent sommelier who is happy to guide you in your choice. The imaginative desserts are also well worth a mention.

name: Colline Ciociare
description: Guests who make it to this restaurant situated some 60km from Rome on a road with plenty of winding bends show real commitment, probably because they’ve heard of the culinary delicacies that Salvatore Tassa brings to the table here. There’s a restricted choice but unlimited imagination in dishes which range from traditional Italian classics and recipes from Lazio to bolder, more innovative, fare typical of the culinary world of this chef-cum-poet who eschews all definitions and fashions. At the modern Nù bistro, enjoy some of the chef’s more traditional and long-established recipes.

name: LoRo
description: The cuisine served at LoRo is imaginative both in its presentation and its ingredients, which are combined in light, original and healthy (in the best sense of the word) dishes. There are two tasting menus of different lengths, one dedicated to fish and the other to meat, as well as an extensive à la carte for anyone who prefers more freedom to make their own individual choices. Following recent refurbishment of the restaurant’s dining spaces, the new “Sala Lab” is home to a large designer-style table that can be transformed to accommodate different numbers of guests, allowing chef Pierantonio Rocchetti to prepare his dishes directly at the table, in an ambience which is friendly and convivial while still maintaining an elegant feel.

name: Sapio
description: This restaurant symbolises the generational shift that sees young people from southern Italy finally able to find the right space in which they can set up on their own and express their culinary skills to the full. Sapio is a smart restaurant run by a young couple: Roberta Cozzetto provides a courteous, elegant welcome front of house, while Alessandro Ingiulla is in the kitchen preparing modern dishes that are a feast for the eyes as well as the palate, using fresh ingredients from this magnificent island.

name: Aqua Crua
description: Chef Giuliano Baldessari offers a classic menu – a sort of return to tradition that focuses on the essentials of culinary technique – and three tasting menus to be sampled in distinct order, called Iniziazione I, Iniziazione II and Iniziazione III. Guests are obliged to start with the first menu in order to get used to the chef’s style and fully understand the diversity of this experience. They can then move on to successive menus, slowly deepening their awareness of this new reality of the senses which becomes more and more passionate and extreme. Each culinary stage can be traced on the restaurant’s app and access to the third menu is completely at the discretion of guests who, at the end of this gastronomic journey, will be fully able to appreciate its impact.

name: Casa Vissani
description: Half-hidden along the main road and not immediately obvious if you’ve never been here before, this restaurant on Lago di Corbara is home to one of Italy’s best-known chefs. For almost fifty years, Gianfranco Vissani has been – and continues to be – one of the country’s most innovative chefs. Very few individuals have contributed as much to forging an image of Italian contemporary cuisine as he has through his many contributions and creative inventions. It could even be said that it is thanks to Vissani that Italian cuisine has reached such a high level of quality today. After arriving at the restaurant and being greeted by the chef’s son Luca, you can spend time in the lakeside garden before heading into the elegant dining room. This outdoor space is where guests can enjoy an aperitif and make their culinary choices, while the indoor dining room is the setting for elegant and impeccable service with open-view kitchens that are framed as if they were paintings. The tasting menus (Colori di Casa Vissani ) are named after colours: Gold (Oro) is traditional in style; Blue (Blu) is dedicated to fresh- and saltwater fish; Red (Rosso) to meat; and Green (Verde) to vegetables. Lastly, 7Black is a surprise menu chosen by the chef.

name: Trattoria al Cacciatore - La Subida
description: Situated amid beautiful rolling hills dotted with vineyards, this restaurant is perfect for anyone keen to sample authentic, traditional Friuli cuisine. One the most interesting restaurants in the region, the Trattoria al Cacciatore focuses on carefully chosen recipes and ingredients from this region, which has a rich and varied cuisine thanks to its location on the border with Slovenia and its historic links with Imperial Austria. The family owners will happily guide you through the options, which include wild herbs, frogs’ legs, mushrooms, radicchio, river fish, polenta and wild game, to name just a few of the delicacies on the menu. Among the main courses, the veal shank cooked in the bread oven, beautifully presented and carved in the dining room, deserves a special mention: for our inspectors, this dish is typical of the restaurant’s authentic, generous cuisine. As an alternative, Osteria della Subida serves traditional Friuli dishes and is open daily, including at lunchtime. The restaurant’s own wine and vinegar is available for purchase (also online).

name: Casin del Gamba
description: The journey to get here – a winding road through woods and hills – may be challenging at times but the warm welcome offered by the whole family at this delightful restaurant makes you feel completely at home and more than compensates for the effort. Owner-chef Antonio now shares the honours and duties of his role with long-established sous-chef Biolo. Together, they prepare cuisine that is perfectly balanced between classic flavours and modern trends, using local ingredients that respect the passing seasons. Game features on the menu in winter, while dishes are often seasoned with wild aromatic herbs (for example, the local “dormant” snails served with thyme and onion bread). For her part, Signora Daria determinedly takes on two roles: she not only prepares the desserts, but also skilfully supervises front of house, ably assisted by son Luca who is happy to advise guests on their choice of wine. The well-structured wine list also includes a good number of organic wines.

name: Fradis Minoris
description: Originally from Sardinia, chef Francesco Stara has returned home to his native island where he focuses on completely “circular” cuisine in this restaurant situated in a protected marine area. The fish is either local or from the Nora lagoon, which also provides the chef with a selection of wild herbs, while the vegetables are sourced from small-scale producers in nearby Campidano. On its two tasting menus (one fish and seafood, the other vegetarian), this excellent restaurant focuses on the best possible seasonal ingredients, as well as protecting the environment and showcasing the island’s traditions in its new, contemporary-style cuisine. Friendly, attentive service and a wine list featuring several regional labels complete the picture.

name: SanBrite
description: This restaurant has just a few tables amid a decor of elegantly recycled old wood, while a large window offers views of the stunning Ampezzo Dolomites outside. Your meal starts in a memorable way: waiters file into the dining room carrying mountains of creamy butter, which is served to every table accompanied by excellent bread with an incomparable texture. Owner-chef Riccardo Gaspari makes careful use of home-produced and regional ingredients, creating delicious cuisine in which mountain traditions are refreshed with modern touches, most noticeably visible in the desserts which are made without adding extra sugar. Sanbrite literally means “healthy pasture”, a name that definitely evokes the qualities of the cuisine served here.

name: Orto by Jorg Giubbani
description: The name of this restaurant situated within the Villa Edera hotel gives the best indication of the type of cuisine served here (“orto” is the Italian for vegetable garden). Chef Jorg Giubbani from Sestri Levante makes full use of the vegetables for which fertile Liguria is renowned, using regional produce to create technical, complex, elaborate and often highly imaginative dishes. Although there is also a concise à la carte, the best option here is to choose one of the three tasting menus, dedicated respectively to Liguria, vegetables (the restaurant has several kitchen gardens in the region) and a surprise menu designed by the chef. Excellent service, particularly from the young and talented sommelier, adds to the enjoyment of this dining experience.

name: San Martino
description: One of the best restaurants in the area, San Martino focuses on fish dishes including classic favourites inherited from the chef’s father as well as more creative fare introduced by the new generation. The Colleoni family never fails to impress! Our inspectors particularly appreciated the constant search for perfection demonstrated by owner-chef Vittorio. This perfection is also evident in the private kitchen garden where flowers and vegetables are grown, emphasising the importance that this chef places on the provenance of his ingredients. The chef’s brother Paolo is responsible for the wine list, which is extensive and well structured, with a slight preference for French labels.

name: Il Falconiere
address: Località San Martino a Bocena 370, San Martino, 52044, Italy
description: To get to this exclusive restaurant, you drive through an idyllic landscape of small lanes lined with dry-stone walls and fields belonging to the Baracchi farm estate, of which Il Falconiere and the magnificent hotel of the same name are a part. Many of the ingredients served here, such as wine and olive oil, are produced on the estate and the restaurant’s strong connection with its local landscapes is evident. Specialities such as Chianina beef, local garlic and pici pasta feature in dishes spiced with aromatic herbs and full of the strong flavours of Tuscany.

name: Pietramare Natural Food
address: SS 106, loc. Praialonga,, Isola di Capo Rizzuto, 88841, Italy
description: In an elegant setting of dry-stone walls and Mediterranean vegetation, this intimate and elegant restaurant is now, following recent renovation, also home to an attractive cigar room with a lounge and fireplace. Although the menu is seasonal in feel and influenced by the region’s maritime and rural traditions (thereby offering guests an authentic culinary voyage around southern Italy), the focus here is resolutely modern and creative in tone. The restaurant now has an additional attraction – its “orto dei profumi”, an aromatic garden which is home to herbs and thirty different varieties of chilli pepper. Good wine list, including an interesting selection of sparkling wines.

name: La Caravella dal 1959
description: La Caravella’s history is intricately linked to that of gastronomic tourism on the Amalfi Coast, so much so that it’s impossible to mention all the famous personalities who have dined here and fallen in love with the Dipino family’s cuisine. The food is proudly inspired by local and family traditions, while at the same time constantly seeking to reinterpret these traditions and create new imaginative recipes. Examples include pears cooked in Aglianico wine served with raw shrimps and cow’s ricotta cheese, and raw fish and seafood options accompanied by a careful selection of seasonal vegetables. Two important features here are the focus on simple, traditional cooking techniques and the speed of preparation. The menu showcases the best of the area’s fresh fish, including pezzogna (a variety of sea bream), swordfish and tuna, supplemented when necessary by options from the nearby Cilento region. Other ingredients include tomatoes (which feature in almost half the dishes), Amalfi’s famous lemons (the classic lemon soufflé is highly recommended), basil and Agerola bread – you’ll want to order almost everything on the menu! The excellent wine list features reds, whites, sparkling, sweet, young and vintage wines, with legendary labels such as La Tâche listed alongside smaller, unknown, rare and organic wines. Whatever your preference, sommelier Tonino has that rare talent (also found at the Enoteca Pinchiorri) of finding just the right wine for you.

name: Palazzo Petrucci
description: Just a stone’s throw from the historic Palazzo Donn’Anna, this restaurant housed in a new, modern building boasts views extending from the sea to Mt Vesuvius and from the Sorrentine peninsula to the famous islands facing the city. The cuisine here is of excellent quality, featuring modern, imaginative reinterpretations of local dishes created by chef Lino Scarallo. If you’re in the mood for a surprise and you’re willing to give the chef carte blanche, then go for the “Lino fai tu” menu. An aperitif in the piano lounge makes a pleasant start to your meal.

name: Atelier
description: The long-established Atelier is not only one of the leading restaurants in Domodossola, it is also the first ever in the Val d’Ossola to be awarded a Michelin star, adding to the tourist appeal of the town. Here, owner-chef Giorgio Bartolucci, flanked by his enterprising sister Elisabetta, has succeeded in skilfully and enthusiastically breathing new life into this restaurant which was founded by his parents, while his wife Katia oversees the impeccable service front of house with professionalism and a friendly smile. The bespoke open-view kitchen (made by local craftsmen and almost as big as the dining room) is definitely intended to be a distinctive feature which the energetic chef hopes will create a real connection between guests and his team. Flavour, variety and presentation are the keystones of the cuisine at Atelier, where the dishes are exciting, inspirational and occasionally feature intriguing reinterpretations of traditional local recipes.

name: Luigi Lepore
address: via Ubaldo de' Medici 50, Lamezia Terme, 88046, Italy
description: Although you hardly notice the door to this restaurant from outside, once inside you are immediately struck by the modern elegance of the decor with its vaguely Scandinavian feel. This mini gem occupying a 19C palazzo in Nicastro, the historic centre of Lamezia, is home to owner-chef Luigi Lepore who has returned to his native Calabria after gaining impressive experience in France and Italy. Here, he delights guests with the best regional ingredients which he precisely and skilfully transforms into contemporary dishes with a fine balance of bitter and acidic flavours, and an intriguing hint of citrus fruit. There’s no à la carte, just three tasting menus: Origini (five courses) and A Mano Libera (available with either seven or nine courses). Diners are warmly welcomed with a smile by the chef’s sister, Stefania, who oversees the front of house and describes her brother’s dishes to guests.

name: Bistrot
address: viale Franceschi 14, Forte dei Marmi, 55042, Italy
description: Despite the name, this restaurant is not a simple bistro but rather a gourmet restaurant in which the excellent chef focuses on two key elements. The first is the restaurant’s own farm which supplies it with olive oil, herbs, vegetables and some meat; the second is the presence of two wood-fired ovens in which the chef bakes different breads, as well as cooking some of his dishes (lobster, in particular). The hospitality here is of the highest order, with exceptional service and a wine cellar (a visit is highly recommended) that is home to a selection of superb Italian and international wines.

name: Linfa
description: This restaurant is situated right in the historic centre of San Gimignano, yet slightly away from its main streets. Culture and a strong connection to the region are perfect companions to the fine flavours that chef Vincenzo Martella translates into delicious fish and meat dishes, often casually combining these different ingredients in the same dish. The beautiful presentation and attention to detail is echoed in the contemporary works of art that adorn the walls. Highly professional yet friendly service, with staff happy to offer recommendations, including assisting with your choice of wine.

name: Zash
address: strada provinciale 2 I/II 60, località Archi, Archi, 95018, Italy
description: Once through the entrance gate, make your way through an orchard planted with citrus trees to get to this restaurant occupying a charming, carefully restored 19C “palmento” (a building once used for fermenting wine) that has retained its magical and romantic atmosphere. Here, Giuseppe Raciti’s top-quality cuisine is showcased on themed tasting menus from which dishes can also be chosen à la carte.
