The chef’s recipes are full of references to the island, as well as personal influences which he describes as “ricordi, viaggi, esperienze” (memories, travels, experiences). Elegant guestrooms dotted around the property add to the appeal of this truly idyllic property.

name: La Preséf
description: Overlooking an internal garden, this welcoming Valtellina-style Stube restaurant decorated in sweet-scented cembra pinewood is the perfect setting in which to enjoy local specialities and vegetables grown in the restaurant’s own garden. Zero-mile ingredients (the restaurant takes its name from the word for “manger” in local dialect and also boasts its own dairy) and visual experimentation are the distinctive features of the regional cuisine served here, with fish from the lake, game, DOP Bitto cheese and even local truffles all appearing on the menu. There are two tasting menus: a creative 7-course menu and a more traditional 4-course option. Comfortable, welcoming guestrooms and a modern spa complete the picture.

name: Re Santi e Leoni
description: Housed in a 19C palazzo in central Nola, this restaurant has a bright, airy and elegant feel with high ceilings and an open-view kitchen to the rear. Attentive service accompanies your meal throughout, with a choice of options in which the clean, simple flavours of fish and seafood take pride of place (including raw options) with a focus on elegant and colourful presentation. Luigi Salomone, a well-known name for gourmet food-lovers, is at the helm here, having returned home to just a few kilometres from his native town, Saviano, having gained experience in prestigious restaurants elsewhere. Well-stocked wine cellar with over 550 different labels, plus three tasting menus (Re, Santi and Leoni).

name: Casa Buono
description: Situated in the small village of Val Roia just inland from Ventimiglia, this unexpected Ligurian gem offers just one small dining room where the surprisingly high-quality service comes courtesy of the chef’s friendly wife, ably assisted by her professional and capable staff. There’s no à la carte here, just a tasting menu designed by the chef for his guests which offers a well-balanced choice of dishes prepared from the best ingredients, many sourced from small-scale farmers and producers from the region. Although the dishes are occasionally influenced by Ligurian traditions, they are for the most part creative, surprising and delightfully elaborate in flavour.

name: Rear Restaurant
description: The talented chef at this multifaceted restaurant serves a unique style of cuisine which ranges from raw seafood dishes to grilled meats. Rear’s modern, comfortable dining room allows guests to watch the chef at work in the beautiful open-view kitchen, in which maturing cuts of meat and a couple of tanks containing fresh shellfish can also be seen, all ready to feature in the chef’s delicious recipes. Professional service and a good selection of wines add to the appeal of this unmissable new restaurant on the road to Irpinia.

name: Gusto by Sadler
address: via Tavolara, località Lu Fraili di Sotto, San Teodoro, 07052, Italy
description: Situated within the exclusive Baglioni Resort to the north of San Teodoro, this restaurant carries the name of Claudio Sadler who, together with resident chef Park Kisung , creates light, Mediterranean-style cuisine with the occasional regionally inspired touch. This regional feel is especially evident in the use of typical ingredients from the island which are transformed into innovative contemporary dishes described as “edible works of art”. Our inspectors recommend the superb crudo di mare(raw fish and seafood), which offers an amazing variety of fish and shellfish. Last but not least, meals are served overlooking a beautiful garden and swimming pool to add a real holiday ambience.

name: Mec Restaurant
description: In the renovated high-tech setting of the Palazzo Castrone in the historic heart of Palermo, Carmelo Trentacosti serves up modern and elegant dishes with carefully selected flavours which are never overstated. Choose between two tasting menus (one of which is vegetarian) or à la carte options, including some dishes (such as the crêpes Suzette) prepared at your table

name: Il Palagio
description: Situated on the ground floor of the Palazzo della Gherardesca and surrounded by beautiful mature gardens, Il Palagio is a gourmet evening restaurant decorated in elegant, refined neo-Classic style. The cuisine focuses on Italian culinary traditions reinterpreted by chef Paolo Lavezzini, who describes himself as “Italian by heart and Brazilian by soul” (he spent many years working in Brazil). Although born in the region of Emilia, Lavezzini’s dishes fully respect Tuscan traditions embellished with the occasional Brazilian influence. Vegetarians are also catered for, with their own tasting menu.

name: Il Saraceno
description: This elegant, welcoming restaurant with a decor that shifts effortlessly from modern design to classic style provides the setting for serious Mediterranean cuisine with the occasional creative touch. The owner-chef here describes his cuisine as “simple”, although the ingredients are of excellent quality. Fish takes pride of place on the menu, alongside produce from Campania in tribute to Roberto Proto’s own memories and his parents’ native region. The extensive, well-chosen wine list offers a good selection of white and sparkling wines. At lunchtime a business menu provides an alternative to the à la carte options.

name: Storie d'Amore
description: This small, welcoming restaurant in the province of Padova is run by its two owners, one at the helm in the kitchen, the other overseeing the warm and beautifully decorated dining room. The cuisine is complex and elaborate rather than minimalist, with chef Davide Filippetto either creating different dishes from the same ingredient or preparing different ingredients in imaginative combinations. An abundant and generous menu, which includes an extensive wine list.

name: Felix Lo Basso home & restaurant
description: Brilliant chef Felix Lo Basso’s menu is inspired by northern Europe: he offers one single menu that changes regularly depending on market availability and that requires all diners to book ahead and eat at the same time. Although the dishes are inventive and occasionally elaborate, the chef often creates original reinterpretations of recipes and ingredients from his native Puglia. Beyond the small rooms used for private dinners, the main dining room features an elegant counter along which guests can sit and watch the chefs at work, with Felice cooking and entertaining his diners with all the skills of a friendly presenter.

name: La Capanna di Eraclio
address: Località per Le Venezie 21, Codigoro, 44021, Italy
description: Whenever we visit Capanna di Eraclio, we have the strange yet wonderful feeling of coming home, despite not being from this region! Opened in 1922 and now in the hands of the fourth generation of the family, this restaurant has changed little – to our relief – since the time when a kitchen was first added to the inn that already stood here. The atmosphere is that of a simple, traditional family trattoria, yet with unexpected touches of elegance, while the cuisine focuses on the best ingredients that the Po delta has to offer. The owner, who works front of house, is an expert on the local area, so the traditional dishes on offer here showcase the region’s meat and fish with an authentic, natural and yet modern touch. An all-round harmonious experience!

name: La Zanzara
address: via per Volano 52, località Porticino, Codigoro, 44021, Italy
description: The Bison family’s iconic restaurant occupies a large 18C fisherman’s house in the stunning natural setting of Porticino in the Po delta regional park – a magical setting accessed via a walk through trees and across little bridges. An elegant dining room with an open fireplace and a romantic, nostalgic ambience provides the backdrop for predominantly fish and seafood cuisine (mainly from the Upper Adriatic). Eel is the house speciality (sometimes served grilled over the wood-fired barbecue), while the excellent wine list stands out for its extensive selection as well as the detailed descriptions that accompany every bottle.

name: Oseleta
description: Situated just a few kilometres from Garda on gently sloping hills planted with vineyards, Villa Cordevigo, home to the Oseleta restaurant, is approached via a superb avenue of cypress trees. There are just nine tables in this old hay barn converted into a veranda, where the elegant ambience and impeccable service make for a pleasant dining experience. Chef Marco Marras demonstrates his culinary skills on a menu that features fish, seafood, vegetarian dishes, specialities from the lake and meat options, all beautifully presented and prepared with surgical precision. Cheese-lovers will appreciate the small yet well-chosen selection of Italian cheeses.

name: Da Gorini
address: via Verdi 5, San Piero in Bagno, 47021, Italy
description: This restaurant in San Piero in Bagno’s historic centre takes its name from its young chef Gianluca da Gorini, who prepares original and creative cuisine inspired by the traditions of this beautiful hilly region as well as his own more imaginative creations. Frequently used ingredients include mushrooms, game, freshwater fish and Mora Romagnolo suckling pig, often combined with other more exotic fare. There’s a particular emphasis on dishes cooked over the barbecue grill, which gives ingredients such as lamb, eel and pigeon a particularly pleasant texture and flavour.

name: Le Monzù
description: This restaurant is situated in one of Capri’s many iconic hotels, the Punta Tragara, which was designed by Le Corbusier and which stands in a superb panoramic location facing Marina Piccola and its surrounding cliffs. The same views can be enjoyed from the restaurant, along with cuisine featured on various tasting menus (including a vegetarian menu and a surprise option) with the possibility of choosing three different dishes à la carte. Whatever you choose, imaginative and skilfully prepared cuisine created by Luigi Lionetti and a truly magical setting make this an experience to remember.

name: La Buca
description: Situated alongside the picturesque canal port and its period houses, this restaurant has a few tables outside overlooking the water, while its indoor dining room with an open-view kitchen has a modern and elegant feel. The menu focuses almost exclusively on fish and seafood, most of which is sourced from local fishermen. Enjoy a wide selection of raw antipasti to start, then choose from an array of beautifully presented, elaborate dishes all of which guarantee a stylish dining experience.

name: Vecchio Ristoro
description: Despite its town-centre location and elegant ambience, this former 17C mill, which has retained its old wheel and millstone in the dining room, almost has the feel of the mountains. Here, the talented chef moves effortlessly between typical Aosta valley specialities, French dishes and international cuisine. The wine list offers well over 200 different labels, including carefully selected unusual wines alongside better-known options from leading producers. Excellent service.

name: Zur Rose
address: via Josef Innerhofer 2, San Michele, 39057, Italy
description: The long-established Zur Rose is a gourmet restaurant that has certainly made its mark along the romantic Tyrolean Wine Route. Here, chef Herbert Hintner serves his own version of creative contemporary cuisine which has a strong regional identity influenced by the Alto Adige, in an elegant building dating back to 1300 – the restaurant has been known as “La Rosa” since 1585. Ingredients and dishes change in line with the seasons, with two menus each season, one regional, the other vegetarian. Riding the crest of a wave for decades, Hintner’s cuisine never falters – especially now that his son has joined him in the kitchen. As a result, Zur Rose continues to offer an unmissable gourmet experience.

name: La Bottega del 30
address: via Santa Caterina 2, località Villa a Sesta, Castelnuovo Berardenga, 53019, Italy
description: There’s a story behind the name of this restaurant: on the 30th day of every month a travelling salesman used to stop in this small, delightful village. In the meantime, a young French chef, Hélène, arrived here and fell in love with Chianti and its cuisine. She named her restaurant after the travelling salesman and the name has been kept in his memory. In a typical setting of stone walls and old rural objects from bygone days, Hélène is now front-of-house taking care of guests, while Nadia Mongiat has replaced her in the kitchen, where she continues with the restaurant’s tradition of creating simple Tuscan cuisine. The focus here is on preparing ingredients in traditional ways, such as pork liver (the thinnest part of the liver is used) cooked at a low temperature and then stored in lard with fennel for a few days before being re-heated sous-vide in a bain-marie. As a result, the liver (served lukewarm on a bed of Tuscan green beans) is soft and delicious.

name: Tivoli
description: This restaurant occupies an attractive Alpine house outside the town centre on the road to the Falzarego pass and at the foot of the Tofane mountains. Here, the chef shows himself to be completely at ease with both traditional cuisine and more creative fare. Using top-quality ingredients from this mountainous region, as well as fresh fish sourced daily from the markets at Venice and Chioggia, owner Graziano Prest creates delicious dishes full of generous flavours. Wine is another of his passions, hence the top-quality labels, historic vintages and renowned French bottles that can be found in the wine cellar here. The panoramic terrace boasts picture-postcard views of Cortina, as does the dining room – but only if you request one of the two tables by the window when you book!

name: La Parolina
description: Although La Parolina is situated in Lazio, chefs Iside and Romano bring together the influences of three neighbouring regions in their simply prepared dishes, namely Lazio, Tuscany (the beautiful rolling hills of which can be admired from the restaurant’s summer terrace) and Umbria. Ingredients include mushrooms from Monte Amiata, truffles from the Sienese hills, asparagus from Canino and hazelnuts from Monti Cimini, as well as vegetables from Umbria and fish from the nearby Lake Bolsena and the Tyrrhenian Sea. Partners in life as well as in the kitchen, these two chefs skilfully balance local traditions with more modern influences. A few guestrooms are available at the restaurant’s La Letterina.

name: Il Parco di Villa Grey
address: viale Italico 84, Forte dei Marmi, 55042, Italy
description: Situated in the elegant Villa Grey hotel, this restaurant occupies a classic yet modern dining room with floor-to-ceiling windows facing the hotel gardens, where meals are served in a delightful setting in the summer months. At the helm in the kitchen, Roberto Monopoli prepares creative dishes with influences from Italy and further afield, with a focus on fish and seafood. The service is elegant and professional.

name: Caracol
address: via del Faro 44, località Capo Miseno, Bacoli, 80070, Italy
description: Once you arrive at the Cala Moresca hotel, a small shuttle bus takes you down to the rocks, where the sensation is one of being on the prow of a ship with the sea and the islands of Ischia, Procida and Capri standing proudly before you. This little gem of a restaurant boasts an outdoor space with a real southern Italian feel and owes its name to a snail-shaped feature on the ceiling (caracol is the Spanish for snail). Chef Angelo Carannante’s imaginative cuisine is full of Mediterranean flavours and successful combinations, while the wine list includes excellent wines from all over Italy, as well as international labels and sparkling wines, all of which can be enjoyed either in the restaurant itself or on the superb terrace jutting out over the sea.

name: Leon d'Oro
description: Situated in the historic centre of a small village between Brescia and Cremona in the Po Valley, this restaurant occupies a period palazzo with an interior full of history. From the exposed beams on the ceiling to the open fireplace, every detail here contributes to the traditional ambience in the dining room, which is enhanced by an outdoor space for alfresco dining in summer. The cuisine pays particular tribute to the region, with snails, delicious Brescia-style kid and game all featuring, although there’s also room for a few fish dishes and more creative options on the menu. The wine list clearly demonstrates how much care the owner has taken to quietly enhance his selection over the years, including only those vintages that he knows will delight his guests.

name: Poggio Rosso
address: località San Felice, Castelnuovo Berardenga, 53019, Italy
description: You cross a magical landscape of hills dotted with cypress and olive trees, woodland and vineyards to get to Borgo San Felice, the luxury hotel that is home to Poggio Rosso. Here, multi-Michelin-starred Enrico Bartolini has chosen his child prodigy Juan Quintero, originally from Colombia, as chef at the helm. Despite the chef’s origins, the cuisine is fundamentally creative and regionally influenced, with just a few South American touches here and there. Juan has fallen in love with Tuscany and he interprets the region’s cuisine with real elegance and contemporary flair. All of this in a luxurious yet unstuffy setting, with service which is impeccable and always accompanied by a smile.

name: Piazzetta Milù
address: corso Alcide De Gasperi 23, Castellammare di Stabia, 80053, Italy
description: Maicol Izzo’s vast gastronomic expertise is the result of influences from his native Campania as well as more exotic experiences further afield, all of which result in a wealth of ideas showcased on just one single tasting menu. This young chef’s creative talent is both surprising and ingenious, often completely overturning classic culinary conventions. He is ably assisted by his brothers Valerio and Emanuele, the latter a highly experienced and knowledgeable sommelier who is able to convey his passion for wine and explain the qualities of different labels in a way that few achieve. Maicol’s restaurant boasts an open-view kitchen, a charming cellar and an attractive dining room with fewer than 20 seats, where guests will enjoy exciting and well-balanced cuisine that will ensure a truly memorable gastronomic experience.

name: Il Refettorio
address: via Roma 2, Conca dei Marini, 84010, Italy
description: The cuisine served here is a far cry from the frugal meals that once provided sustenance to this former 17C monastery’s original inhabitants. Perched above the sea, Il Refettorio is now home to German chef Bob Christoph, who conjures up a selection of Mediterranean dishes reinterpreted with a light and balanced touch. The chef’s own definition of his cuisine seems to be a contradiction in terms, in that he describes his dishes as simple and yet complicated at the same time. Our inspectors would add that he pays careful attention to his ingredients and bases his modern cuisine on traditional recipes. Enjoy an aperitif sitting under the pergola of roses and Virginia creeper, surrounded by lush vegetation that creates a tranquil and meditative ambience.

name: Quadri
address: piazza San Marco 121 (primo piano), Venice, 30124, Italy
description: Situated on the second floor of the historic café of the same name, this elegant restaurant is run with consummate professionalism by the Alajmo family (also renowned for their three-Michelin-starred restaurant in Rubano), with chefs Silvio Giavedoni and Sergio Preziosa at the helm. With its ornate wallpaper bearing portraits of the owners, sumptuous chandeliers, view of St Mark’s Square and carefully restored 16C features, this is truly a restaurant for a special occasion. The opulence of the setting is deliberately lightened by the friendly service, which is occasionally playful and yet impeccable at all times. Skilful reinterpretations of Venetian and Italian classics feature on the tasting menus served here, although dishes can also be chosen à la carte. In addition to the historic Quadri café on the ground floor, the more informal Quadrino serves simpler, less expensive fare which is nonetheless interesting.

name: La Stüa de Michil
address: strada Col Alt 105, Corvara in Badia, 39033, Italy
description: It would be no exaggeration to describe this restaurant as one of the most romantic in Italy, where the traditional wood furnishings add a charming, intimate feel to the Stube-style dining rooms. The menu focuses on Alpine products, accompanied by a wine list featuring over 7 000 labels. Excellent service.

name: Bianca sul Lago by Emanuele Petrosino
description: The large windows at this restaurant allow guests to enjoy some of the most beautiful sunsets in the region, either from the dining room or perhaps while sipping an aperitif in the lounge bar – the chef has even dedicated a dish to this atmospheric occasion. Highly technical Mediterranean cuisine is to the fore here, with numerous dishes from Campania on the menu, accompanied by impeccable service and a good selection of wines that is still being expanded. Part of a smart hotel, the dining room is modern and minimalist in style. Definitely one of the best restaurants in the province!

name: Lunasia
description: One of the most original and imaginative chefs in the Versilia region is at the helm in the luxury Plaza e de Russie hotel’s showcase restaurant, where the bright, modern dining room overlooks Viareggio’s famous seafront promenade. Three tasting menus are available here: the first dedicated to fish, the second vegetarian, and the third focusing on meat, with guests able to choose courses freely from each menu à la carte style. Whatever you choose the dishes here are of a rare elegance, with occasionally striking presentations. Chef Luca Landi’s cuisine pays tribute to the region, using excellent ingredients such as local fish and produce from Tuscany’s inland areas.

name: Zia
description: Situated in a quiet residential part of charming Trastevere, this restaurant stands out among the district’s many typical restaurants for its fresh, elegant look, its professional approach and, last but certainly not least, its excellent cuisine. Guests are given a warm and enthusiastic welcome here, as they are introduced to the culinary world of chef Antonio Ziantoni. The chef’s recipes are accessible yet elaborate in their preparation, offering a real feast for the palate throughout the meal which will undoubtedly leave a lasting memory. The wine list boasts more than 350 labels and also includes an interesting selection of wines by the glass.

name: Impronte
description: A converted bus depot just outside the city has been transformed into this minimalist-style restaurant. Here, the chef works with carefully selected produce to create his own style of cuisine with a particular fondness for acidic and smoked ingredients, as well as the use of contrasting flavours. The options here include two tasting menus as well as the à la carte, plus a selection of raw fish dishes.

name: Kuppelrain
address: via Stazione 16, località Maragno, Castelbello, 39020, Italy
description: The many positive adjectives that can be used to describe the Trafoier family can be summed up by simply saying that they are unique! Their individual talents come together in the natural and engaging welcome they offer guests, demonstrating a warmth and professionalism that is typical of the Kuppelrain experience. Chef Kevin, who is as skilful as his father Jorg (now front of house), demonstrates precise, excellent techniques in his search for comforting and appealing flavours that bring out the full flavour of his ingredients with no frills or unnecessary fuss. Local produce takes pride of place, such as fruit and vegetables from the restaurant’s own kitchen garden, and meat and fish from the region. The desserts, as well as the imaginative pralines, are made by daughter Natalie. Wine-enthusiasts will also be in their element here, thanks to the excellent wine list (including a fine selection by the glass, as well as magnums and 3-litre double magnums) which is overseen by talented Sonya (the winner of the 2022 Michelin Sommelier Award!), who creates unique wine pairings. Bistro service only at lunchtime.

name: Al Gambero
description: Antonio and Mariapaola, the current generation at the helm of this restaurant (ably assisted by the next generation), have had huge success here, having achieved and maintained a Michelin star for decades. The couple have embraced a culinary approach that focuses on traditional recipes, bringing them back to life and adding the chef’s own original twist. His dishes demonstrate a personal and delicate touch in the preparation of carefully selected ingredients, such as wild game and fish-based recipes, all of which require great skill on the part of the chef. The end result is delicious – reading the menu you’ll want to try almost everything! Both the service and the table settings are classic in style, as is the excellent, fairly priced wine list.

name: L'Asinello
address: via Nuova 6, località Villa a Sesta, Castelnuovo Berardenga, 53019, Italy
description: Situated at the entrance to a romantic village in the Chianti region, this former stable has been converted into a quiet, elegant restaurant by a young couple, with a beautiful garden for summer dining. Here, guests can sit after dinner and enjoy the sound of neighbours calling to each other in the background, a pleasant reminder of life in Italy in days gone by. At the helm in the kitchen, the husband champions traditional cuisine which is minimalist in its choice of flavours and made from just a few well-balanced ingredients. The impeccably kept garden, which is as beautiful and well presented as his dishes, is also the chef’s work (he certainly has green fingers!). A real Italian culinary gem!

name: I Pupi
description: Although his name could easily be that of a theatre star, Tony Lo Coco is actually the owner-chef of the I Pupi restaurants, and the proud holder of a Michelin star. His wife Laura is at the helm in the small, elegant dining room with a modern and minimalist feel, which is dominated by a large gleaming cabinet-cum-sideboard. As for the cuisine, Tony demonstrates real care in his choice of local ingredients, working with the best local cheesemakers, fishermen, farmers and breeders – you can happily let him guide you through his imaginative and personalised Sicilian cuisine. We highly recommended the meat and fish tasting menus, the mixed menu to taste a bit of everything, and the chef’s stigghioladish (his own take on street food).

name: Materia
description: “I trained in traditional cuisine before moving to Noma in Copenhagen, which completely changed my ideas and perceptions and, in some ways, took me back to my origins in the valleys around Lake Como”, says Caranchini. “This is where my grandmother used to harvest wild produce in summer to preserve for the winter, when almost nothing grew at home”. The cuisine here is predominantly influenced by Italy and Asia, with a menu featuring plenty of vegetables, spices and aromatic herbs that the chef uses to create dishes full of concentrated flavours. If you enjoy innovative and original combinations, this is the restaurant for you as many of the dishes on the menu (including the desserts) offer something different, including recipes with more challenging and acidic and bitter flavours. The dining room is minimalist yet welcoming in style.

name: George Restaurant
description: This roof-garden restaurant in one of Naples’ most luxurious hotels (Grand Hotel Parker’s) boasts an open-view kitchen facing a breathtaking panorama that takes in Vesuvius, the Bay of Naples and the city itself, which extends below the hotel in an evocative display of sparkling lights. It’s a challenge for the cuisine to compete with so much beauty but young chef Domenico Candela is more than equal to the task. His cuisine showcases the culinary specialities of the city and further afield with extraordinary skill, combining superb produce and recipes from Campania with techniques learnt in France to produce truly remarkable reinterpretations of regional dishes.

name: Senso Alfio Ghezzi Mart
description: The talented Trentino chef at this restaurant has given his dishes a contemporary flavour – and how could it be otherwise given its location! Situated in the famous Mart (Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art), the restaurant offers just one tasting menu in the evening, which can also be reduced to four courses. The cuisine here has a real Italian flavour with its roots firmly in regional traditions, with dishes that are seemingly simple yet the result of sophisticated preparation and with a focus on elegant presentation. Although game and freshwater fish always feature on the menu, there’s also plenty of room for vegetables. At lunchtime, the bistro options are more streamlined.

name: Due Colombe
description: At this restaurant, the chef’s highly creative approach does not ignore his culinary roots, resulting in a successful reinterpretation of local peasant traditions and top-quality cuisine. Our inspectors highly recommended making your way to this thousand-year-old hamlet, where you dine in a deconsecrated church under a brick-vaulted ceiling. The fine cuisine celebrated here includes historic dishes that have become classic favourites, which can be chosen from the three tasting menus. A good example is the beef cooked with olive oil and served with polenta: “Nonna” Elvira made this dish in the post-war period and her grandson Stefano follows the same recipe today. The menu also includes a few fish dishes, while wine-enthusiasts shouldn’t hesitate to ask sommelier Federica for her recommendations – they won’t regret it!

name: Il Tino
description: Enjoying an attractive location in the Nautilus Marina, overlooking the Tiber and the boats moored along it, this restaurant decorated in a modern, minimalist style represents a childhood dream for its chef, who learned his craft from observing his grandparents, both of whom were excellent cooks. Following years spent gaining experience abroad and in Italy, including an informative period with Gualtiero Marchesi at L’Albereta, Usai now creates contemporary cuisine with a strong regional character, prepared from top-quality seasonal ingredients and enhanced with cutting-edge techniques. His cuisine is also open to more exotic influences, including from Asia, the aesthetic quality of which reflects the chef’s own love for elegant presentation. The restaurant’s kitchen garden, visible from the steps leading into the dining room, provides the many herbs that are used skilfully by the chef to add colour and even more flavour to his delicious fish and seafood dishes. Excellent wine list, plus the highly recommended option of starting your meal with an intriguing cocktail!

name: AALTO
description: Situated in the heart of Porta Nuova, the most modern district of Milan and an area that “is liked by people who are liked” (to use the words of an old advertising slogan), this restaurant occupies the first floor of the Torre Solaria. Take a seat in a dining room full of charm, where stone, wood and glass combine to create a warm, elegant and designer-style ambience. Chef Takeshi Iwai’s cuisine is hard to define, combining Italian and Japanese flavours in fusion-style dishes that embrace influences from both countries. The best option here is to savour the different dishes served on the tasting menus. The IYO Omakase sushi bar (a “restaurant within a restaurant”) shares an entrance with AALTO, although the two spaces are kept separate, and the food served at the bar is prepared by sushi master Masashi Suzuki.

name: Gambero Rosso
address: via Montezemolo 65, Marina di Gioiosa Ionica, 89046, Italy
description: Gambero Rosso was founded in the 1970s, when Anna Maria and Giuseppe Sculli decided to pay tribute to the sea that they had previously left as emigrants. Since then, the restaurant has become a focus for the whole family and today, a new chapter is being written with the arrival of sons Riccardo and Francesco at the helm. Fish-lovers will be in their element at this restaurant, which is one of the most popular in the region. The dishes are made from the best fish caught daily along the Ionian coast, with raw fish dishes, including excellent antipasti, attracting customers from all over Calabria. The fresh pasta options are also excellent, while the main courses combine fish and seafood with vegetables. The restaurant also makes a commendable effort to work as much as possible with local producers and suppliers.

name: Qafiz
address: località Calabretto, Santa Cristina d'Aspromonte, 89056, Italy
description: Although getting to this restaurant is not easy, the pleasant drive that takes you through Calabria’s beautiful countryside dotted with countless olive trees makes it even more worthwhile. At the end of your journey, you arrive at an elegant late-18C villa with its adjoining old olive-oil mill that houses this restaurant crowned by a typical cross-vaulted ceiling. In 2023, a revolutionary refurbishment moved the kitchen into the centre of the dining room where guests sit around the counter-style Chef’s Table or at the single table set slightly to one side, enjoying just one tasting menu which is served to all guests at the same time. The focus here is on Calabrian ingredients (pigeon and oysters are sourced from outside the region), with produce such as the excellent extra-virgin olive oil, aromatic herbs and vegetables produced on the property, all transformed into creative and original dishes in front of guests by the skilful chefs. After your meal, you may like to move to the beautiful Aspro Cocktail Bar for a coffee, a small pastry or a cocktail. If you wish to prolong your stay, accommodation is now available in Casa Qafiz.

name: Rossellinis
address: via San Giovanni del Toro 28, Ravello, 84010, Italy
description: Although the dining rooms at this restaurant are elegant and sophisticated, it is the summer terrace that steals the show thanks to its views of one of the most stunning stretches of the Amalfi coast – a striking picture of cobalt-blue sea and verdant mountains. This delightful, romantic experience starts with an aperitif in the garden, where the regional aspect of the cuisine is immediately obvious in the delicacies served. One of the dominant features of the chef’s cooking here is its light touch, where technique and balance go hand in hand in dishes made from local ingredients with the occasional influence from further afield. The sommelier assists guests with their choice of wines from an extensive selection which finds place for local labels alongside wines from outside Italy.

name: Locanda del Pilone
address: frazione Madonna di Como 34, Alba, 12051, Italy
description: Situated just a few kilometres from the town, this restaurant stands on a hill with 360° views of some of the most breathtaking vineyard scenery in the area, where vines stand in neat rows extending into the distance and take on extraordinary colours in autumn. Here, in a classic and elegant setting, the surprising and imaginative menu also includes a few regional specialities, all prepared by a chef who demonstrates remarkable skill and creativity. The excellent wine list offers a wide selection of champagnes in addition to the usual top-quality local labels. Delightful guestrooms make extending your stay in this charming setting a real temptation.

name: Pashà
description: This restaurant is housed in one of the most important historic buildings in the town – the Seminario Vescovile (Bishop’s Seminary). The austere, majestic exterior contrasts with the contemporary elegance of the dining room, while the cuisine continues to focus on dishes firmly rooted in the region, albeit with the occasional modern twist. Chef Antonio Zaccardi is at the helm here, creating various tasting menus on which he demonstrates skills and techniques acquired over the years, focusing on just a few ingredients so that every dish explodes with intense and generous flavours. His wife Angelica Giannuzzi is equally as talented, creating pastries and desserts that are out of the ordinary and full of personality. Antonio Magistà oversees the front of house with skill and elegance, fully confident in the restaurant’s excellent wine list which is dominated by champagnes and wines from Puglia and Bordeaux.

name: Sensi
description: All five senses will be satisfied by a visit to the gourmet restaurant of the Hotel Residence. Housed in a splendid 18C palazzo just a few metres from the famous cathedral, the restaurant boasts an interior design which combines modern and functional features with the building’s classic look, using a colour scheme which is typical of the Amalfi Coast. Although the cuisine focuses mainly on Mediterranean fish and seafood, the menu also features a few meat specialities.

name: Osteria del Viandante
description: Situated on the first floor of the 13C military fort in the centre of Rubiera, this elegant restaurant boasts five dining rooms, each one more delightful than the last and all frescoed, with the exception of the old limonaia which is decorated with wallpaper depicting its former function. This stylish and romantic setting provides the backdrop for young and enthusiastic chef Jacopo Malpeli who, having been born and raised between Parma and Reggio, creates cuisine that reflects the grandeur and opulence of local culinary traditions. Among his many interesting dishes, a particular favourite is the savarin di riso, which pays tribute to the legendary Mirella and Peppino Cantarelli and their former two-Michelin-starred restaurant in Samboseto. The extraordinary wine list includes several French wines alongside Italian labels and champagnes.

name: Nazionale
description: Situated in the hotel of the same name in a typical mountain-style property, this elegant restaurant offers two welcoming dining rooms with open fireplaces and a profusion of wood, where friendly service adds to the warm atmosphere. Specialities served here include char, snails, an excellent selection of game, Sambuca mutton and local butter, as well as herbs and vegetables from the restaurant’s own kitchen garden. A special mention should be made of the bread, in particular the delicious “pane sflogliato” (literally, layered bread). All in all, full marks for the remarkable cuisine, which succeeds in showcasing the valley’s gastronomic gems and which will appeal to even the most demanding of palates!

name: Don Alfonso 1890 San Barbato
description: A grand hotel requires a big name, so it’s only fitting that this elegant, stylish restaurant with floor-to-ceiling windows offering beautiful views of the garden and swimming pool is run by the Jaccarino family. The cuisine here is inspired by classic favourites, as well as reinterpretations of more regional recipes, all made from carefully selected and top-quality local ingredients such as “crusco” peppers. The modern, technical cuisine showcases small local producers and forgotten flavours. There’s also an excellent selection of wines from southern Italy (and elsewhere). Not to be missed!

name: San Giorgio
description: An elegant restaurant boasting careful attention to detail in its decor, San Giorgio serves top-quality local fish alongside a few meat specialities such as foie gras and suckling pig. The cuisine here is Mediterranean in style and full of colour and flavour, while the warm, professional welcome offered by the Scala brothers adds to the appeal. With a wine list of the same high standard as the food, this is a restaurant to come back to!

name: Dalla Gioconda
description: Between the blue sky and the Adriatic Sea, at the highest point of Gabicce Monte, Dalla Gioconda is the gourmet rebirth of a renowned dancing venue in the town. The design is warm, conceived and created with sustainability in mind. Thanks to a long experience at the Osteria Francescana of Massimo Bottura, the talented chef Davide Di Fabio creates precise and beautiful dishes, cooked with the best ingredients of the territory and of their own garden. The cellar hides real gems, and the summer terrace offers moments of sheer beauty.

name: Kitchen
description: Nestled amid the greenery of a private park, Kitchen is an elegant restaurant which serves creative Italian cuisine with a focus on seasonal ingredients and a perfect balance between produce, technique and flavour. The chef uses herbs and vegetables from the restaurant’s own biodynamic kitchen garden which can be seen in front of the entrance. This natural bounty provides the basis for the Green tasting menu; the other tasting menu is called Experience; there’s also an excellent à la carte. Service is attentive plus there’s an excellent selection of wines.

name: La Terrazza
description: A luxurious setting and breathtaking views make La Terrazza at the Eden hotel one of the most scenic restaurants in Rome. Situated on the top floor of the exclusive Dorchester hotel, the restaurant boasts soft lighting that allows the beautiful views of this historic city through the large windows to be enjoyed to the full. At the helm in the kitchen, Fabio Ciervo from Campania creates elegant dishes in which top-quality ingredients are transformed by careful preparation and skilful techniques. The à la carte offers a fabulous selection of delicious fish and meat options, while the new X Years tasting menu celebrates the long relationship between Ciervo and the Eden by showcasing his signature dishes.

name: L’Alchimia
description: The parquet floor, wood-beamed ceiling and exposed brickwork lend a warm ambience to this restaurant, which is bright and airy during the day and romantic in the evening thanks to its soft lighting. The cuisine here will appeal not necessarily for its creativity but for its honest dishes in which top-quality Italian ingredients are prepared with imagination, and occasionally transformed with intense flavours. Additional features include a small, beautiful brick-vaulted wine cellar (open to visitors), plus an adjacent bar-bistro which serves quick lunches and excellent aperitifs.

name: Alpenroyal Gourmet
address: via Meisules 43, Selva di Val Gardena, 39048, Italy
description: This is the gourmet restaurant at the hotel of the same name, one of the most luxurious in the Val Gardena. The elegant, contemporary dining room has an almost minimalist feel, with a softly lit ambience that would give the impression of a private home were it not for the huge garden (snow-covered in winter) visible through its windows. Although originally from Puglia, chef Mario Porcelli has been working in the Dolomites for many years and is equally at home with local dishes as he is with recipes from his native region. In both cases, his dishes are modern and beautifully presented in a manner that leaves nothing to chance.

name: I Castagni
description: In the countryside outside Vigevano, this rustic country house with a portico has the feel of a private villa, thanks to its antique furniture and paintings by local artists on the walls. For more than 30 years, Enrico Gerli, together with his wife front of house, has run this restaurant with dedication and professionalism, creating classic-modern cuisine which showcases the culinary traditions of Lombardy as well as a few fish-based dishes. A wine cellar home to around 600 labels from around the world adds to the appeal.

name: Zum Löwen
description: A charming restaurant housed in a skilfully restored old farm, where everything from the hay barn to the old stalls has been refurbished and enhanced, so that traditional old features can be seen alongside more modern additions. The cuisine here is in the capable hands of owner Anna Matscher, who creates gourmet dishes from the Alto Adige which can by now be described as “classics”. The combination of ingredients and the cooking methods used appear to offer a certain level of comfort, although given the precise preparation involved this is hardly a flaw. Examples include the traditional roast goat kid cooked with extra-virgin olive oil and aromatic herbs, served with roast potatoes and a second seasonal vegetable, along with its own delicious jus. Luis oversees the front of house and is always available to offer recommendations for the best wine pairings.

name: Vintage 1997
description: A hushed, stylish restaurant with a red velvet decor and tables covered with immaculate tablecloths, Vintage 1997 is one of the region’s finest addresses and has hosted some of Turin’s most famous personalities over the years. The cuisine focuses on classic-regional dishes reinterpreted using contemporary cooking and preparation methods, especially on the Luna Park menu (book in advance), while the Punt e Mes, menu showcases the specialities of Piedmont to the full. In this region renowned for its meat dishes, the excellent em>Gran Crudo di Pesce (raw fish specialities) comes as a pleasant surprise. Champagnes and other non-Italian wines are imported directly from producers.

name: Locanda Margon
description: Young chef Edoardo Fumagalli arrived in the small town of Ravina with plenty of international experience behind him. Now in his third year at the famous Locanda Margon, a restaurant with views of Trento and the Adige valley, he puts all his heart, energy and creativity into three tasting menus (one of which has been designed to combine perfectly with the Ferrari sparkling wine made by the winery that owns the restaurant). His menus showcase local ingredients, which he prepares with technical expertise, occasionally combining them with produce from other parts of Italy. Although the adjacent Bistrot is designed to be more informal in character, it offers the attraction of reliable Italian cuisine and the option of dining alfresco.

name: Spinechile
address: contra' Pacche 2, località Tretto, Schio, 36015, Italy
description: Situated in a magical location amid the wooded slops above Schio, this restaurant is not easy to find – even once you get to the village, you’ve still got a way to go! From here, you take a winding and occasionally narrow road, the last section of which is just a dirt track, continuing up to an altitude of 600m, where you eventually reach an elegant old mountain lodge. Corrado Fasolato, a talented and highly experienced chef, offers a menu that features classic dishes alongside more creative options. Guests flock here because of the restaurant’s reputation and leave delighted by new discoveries. The wine list is justly famous and is divided into three sections: one dedicated to white wines; another to red; and the third to sweet wines. Spinechile is run by life and business partners Corrado in the kitchen and wine expert Paola front of house.

name: Hyle
address: contrada Torre Garga SS 107, San Giovanni in Fiore, 87055, Italy
description: Located on the wooded Sila plateau famous since Greek times, this restaurant aims to take guests on a culinary voyage through the region, from the hills overlooking the sea to the high mountain peaks. Although spanning just a short distance, this covers a fertile area which boasts a rich diversity of ingredients. Enhanced by the experience of chef Antonio Biafora, the restaurant’s focus is on top-quality local produce (vegetables, aromatic herbs, walnuts etc) sourced from local farmers and growers, creating a chain which is both economic and socially responsible. In addition to its à la carte options, guests also have the choice of two tasting menus, the regional character of which is emphasised by their Calabrian names (Pùzaly and Chjùbica). The first, a seven-course menu, takes its name from the Greek word “pisseres” which means resinous, while the second refers to the ancient road that linked Paola to Cirò Marina and consists of eleven courses, all full of flavour. Excellent value for money!

name: Dattilo
description: In the world of haute cuisine still dominated by male chefs, Caterina Ceraudo stands out for her authoritative presence and large personality. Her restaurant is housed in a charming agriturismo which offers simple guestrooms decorated in attractive, rustic style, a beautiful swimming pool shaded by mature olive trees, and traditional produce such as wine, olive oil, orange and cedro marmalades and fruit juices. Add to this Caterina’s modern, creative and yet unfussy cuisine made from local ingredients and you have a winning formula.

name: La Speranzina Restaurant & Relais
description: A romantic, Mediterranean-style restaurant in the heart of Sirmione, La Speranzina has an elegant and minimalist-style decor in which light, discreet colours dominate in the comfortable dining room, while in summer the terrace boasts spectacular views of the lake and castle (a few of the tables stand right over the water). Whether you choose fish, meat or vegetables, Fabrizio Molteni creates dishes with excellent technique and precision, as you would expect from one of master-chef Gualtiero Marchesi’s last students (Marchesi himself is mentioned in some of the dishes). There is also an option to head into the kitchen, where you can watch the chefs prepare either your main course or dessert. A superbly stocked wine cellar, with an excellent choice of champagnes and renowned labels, and three stunning panoramic suites complete the picture.

name: Aroma
description: The open-view kitchen is the first thing guests see when they arrive at this delightful restaurant boasting views of Ancient Rome from the Colosseum to the dome of St Peter’s – a truly memorable sight! The name pays tribute to both the city and the aromas imbued in the Mediterranean cuisine served here. Local specialities also feature on the menu, often with a touch of creativity added by chef Giuseppe di Iorio. The Aroma Bistrò next door overlooks the Parco del Colle Oppio and serves simpler, quicker versions of the dishes offered at the main restaurant.

name: Imàgo
address: piazza Trinità dei Monti 6, Rome, 00187, Italy
description: Imàgo, the panoramic restaurant at the beautiful Hassler hotel (which stands at the top of the famous Spanish Steps in Piazza di Spagna), provides the stunning setting for young chef Andrea Antonini, who creates beautifully presented and imaginative cuisine inspired by ingredients and traditions from Italy (and occasionally Lazio). Antonini recommends his “blind” tasting menu, which selects what he considers to be the best dishes from his à la carte. The extensive and well-chosen wine list includes a good selection of non-Italian wines, with a particular focus on France, while the superb views of Rome are the icing on the cake, contributing to what is an elegant and unforgettable dining experience. Excellent service completes the picture.

name: Romano
description: Opened in 1966, Romano is a real culinary institution in the Versilia region, serving cuisine made from top-quality ingredients, with a particular focus on local fish. Although its philosophy has not changed over the years, current chef Nicola Gronchi should be applauded for adding a hint of contemporary flavour and technical expertise to the cuisine, while still retaining everything that this restaurant does best, namely serving fish of the highest quality (there are also a few meat dishes), including the occasional typical Versilian recipe.

name: Dolce Stil Novo alla Reggia
address: piazza della Repubblica 4, Venaria Reale, 10078, Italy
description: Housed inside the Torrione del Garove, this restaurant boasts an attractive terrace overlooking the Reggia di Venaria gardens with their geometrically sculpted bushes and hedges, as well as the palace’s Court of Honour. Here, chef Alfredo Russo serves regional cuisine with a modern and appealing touch, surprising guests with the occasional fish and seafood speciality on a culinary journey that spans Piedmont to southern Italy. Don’t miss the imaginative and carefully prepared desserts, while the well-structured wine list (on an iPad) also includes a good selection by the glass.

name: RistoranTino & C.
address: strada principale 63, frazione Rollieres, Sauze di Cesana, 10054, Italy
description: An elegant Alpine-style ambience in a beautiful stone building on the road to Sestrière, where Martino and Chiara offer a warm welcome to guests and serve contemporary-style cuisine with a modern twist. In addition to the good selection of wines (around 300 different labels), there is also a choice of special beers and saké.

name: 'L Chimpl
address: strada de Tamion 3, VIGO DI FASSA, 38039, Italy
description: The family-run Gran Mugon hotel offers guests a friendly welcome that extends to its gourmet restaurant (‘L Chimpl), where you’ll find an excellent and undeniably talented chef at the helm. Stefano Ghetta uses a multitude of ingredients in his dishes, which he skilfully brings together in coordinated combinations where flavours and textures sometimes blend together in harmony yet also sometimes offer striking contrasts. Many of the ingredients are sourced from the region or the valley itself, demonstrating the chef’s impressive knowledge of this mountainous region. By the end of your meal, you’ll be surprised by the unusual wealth and variety of ingredients that originate from this mountainous region, one that could be described as challenging for a chef, especially in winter. In a reflection of the menu, the wine list also focuses on regional labels, some of which are well worth discovering.

name: Due Camini
description: This is the most romantic restaurant in the Borgo Egnazia resort, where the soft candlelight creates a hushed, magical atmosphere that makes it perfect for a special occasion, dinner with a loved one, or simply a gourmet meal. Enjoy excellent service as you embark on a gastronomic journey that introduces you to specialities from chef Domingo Schingaro’s Puglia, dishes inspired by the region, and recipes influenced by the wider Mediterranean (depending on the menu). Many of the ingredients are sourced from the hotel’s own kitchen garden.

name: Re Maurì
description: Situated in the Lloyd’s Baia hotel between Salerno and Vietri, in an elevated location overlooking the port, this restaurant offers splendid views of the bay from the floor-to-ceiling windows in the dining room which become even more stunning from the terrace where meals are served in fine weather. Specialities from Campania feature on the menu alongside dishes with a more international influence and ingredients from outside the region. Make sure you leave space for dessert: the cook worked as a pastry chef before coming here and the care he takes with his desserts is truly remarkable.

name: Osteria Altran
description: Situated in a small village about 40km from Trieste, the Osteria Altran offers gourmet cuisine surrounded by the verdant landscapes of the Friuli countryside. In what was once a simple farm, owner Guido Lanzellotti has brought this seemingly rustic yet delightfully romantic restaurant to life, creating modern cuisine that focuses on top-quality ingredients and careful preparation. The new lounge-cum-library adorned with cookery books is available for small private events as well as pre-dinner or post-dinner drinks.

name: Osteria della Brughiera
description: Opened in the 1990s by Stefano Arrigoni together with his parents, the Osteria della Brughiera takes guests on a timeless culinary journey in a setting of rich brocade and linen tablecloths. Lulled by the melodic creaking of the parquet flooring and warmed by the crackling fire during the coldest months, guests enjoy surprisingly creative cuisine which includes traditional recipes and more elaborate dishes, from raw fish and seafood to offal. The wine cellar is as impressive as the cuisine, featuring a selection of labels from around the globe.

name: Pierino Penati
description: Surrounded by the greenery of the Brianza hills, this villa on the outskirts of the village offers a delightful garden and an elegant dining room with a veranda. Chef Theo continues the family tradition here, focusing on a culinary philosophy that has successfully adapted to modern trends around healthy eating while also remaining faithful to the traditional cuisine that has made the restaurant famous. Although in the past very few fish dishes featured on the menu, there is now an equal emphasis on varied meat and fish options, while the wine cellar boasts a selection of renowned labels alongside lesser-known – but often just as good – wines.

name: San Martino
address: piazza Cappelletto 1, località Rio San Martino, Scorzè, 30037, Italy
description: A smart, elegant restaurant with a bright, minimalist decor in which large tables are well spaced out to create an exclusive feel. The chef’s wife brings a touch of friendly informality to the restaurant, along with an impressive knowledge of the excellent wine list, which offers a wide array of sparkling wines and champagnes. The cuisine here is modern and personalised, with a slight emphasis on fish, although meat dishes also feature. “Food doesn’t just relieve hunger”, says chef Ros, “but also reflects culture”.

name: Terrazza Bosquet
description: Housed in the splendid setting of the Excelsior Vittoria, this restaurant has an elegant dining room for the winter months, plus a charming terrace overlooking the Bay of Naples which adds to the appeal in summer. Originally from Sorrento, chef Antonino Montefusco is totally at home here, creating dishes that draw from the region’s culinary traditions thanks to his in-depth knowledge of local producers and ingredients, which also includes the use of organic produce grown in the hotel’s own gardens, such as oranges, lemons and olive oil. Four tasting menus are available, including a vegetarian option and a menu dedicated to the restaurant’s “Greatest Eats”.

name: Il Buco
address: II rampa Marina Piccola 5, Sorrento, 80067, Italy
description: Housed in the cellars of an old monastery in the heart of Sorrento, Il Buco has long been one of the town’s leading restaurants thanks to its gourmet dining and homely ambience. In this brightly coloured setting with exposed tufa stone and elegant decorative details, owner-chef Peppe Aversa (an inspiration for so many of his colleagues) creates simple, unfussy cuisine with a blend of traditional and modern influences. Tasting menus are offered alongside an à la carte featuring fish, seafood and locally sourced meat, all of which are skilfully and simply prepared to preserve the ingredients’ authentic flavours. The restaurant has recently added a new dining room with a more contemporary feel, where an open-view wine cellar (with more than 1 000 labels and a good selection of wines by the glass) takes pride of place.

name: La Locanda del Borgo
description: Chef Luciano Villani creates menus that focus on simplicity, organic produce from the Sannio region and an uncompromising philosophy. The restaurant is situated within the Hotel Acquapetra Resort&Spa, once an old farmhouse transformed into a luxurious hamlet, where antique furnishings and modern cutting-edge facilities combine to ensure a delightful stay in elegant surroundings. The gourmet restaurant adds to its appeal, featuring cuisine that is delicious and always recognisably regional, albeit with the occasional influence from elsewhere. There are two tasting menus: Aqua (fish dishes only) and Petra (dedicated to meat dishes). Aperitifs and drinks are served in the charming bar next to the restaurant.

name: La Ciau del Tornavento
description: Housed in a typical building dating from 1931 situated amid the Barbaresco hills, this spacious restaurant boasts spectacular views through its floor-to-ceiling windows and – even better – from its terrace. Take the time in between courses to head out on to the terrace, from where you can appreciate magical views which extend as far as the Alps on the clearest days. The cuisine more than equals the beautiful setting, offering an extensive à la carte of meat and fish dishes that range from classic favourites to new creations, in a celebration of the past that is open to modern influences. The wine cellar is legendary – it is of such a high quality that really nothing could be added to improve it – and can be visited on request.

name: Suinsom
address: strada Puez 12, Selva di Val Gardena, 39048, Italy
description: Housed in the Tyrol hotel, the Ladin name of this restaurant means “at the summit”. The restaurant comprises two small, charming Stube-style rooms dating from the 18C, where the young chef serves creative dishes with a focus on Alpine produce.

name: Castello di Fighine
address: borgo di Fighine, San Casciano dei Bagni, 53040, Italy
description: A dirt track leads to this magical setting – an 11C castle perched among the Tuscan hills which is now privately owned and has been restored and renovated over the past 15 years. Situated in the hamlet surrounding the castle, the restaurant boasts a beautiful terrace shaded by wisteria where meals are served in fine weather. In the kitchen, the successful partnership between new resident chef Francesco Nunziata and three-starred Michelin chef Heinz Beck is immediately obvious. Two apartments are available in Casa Parretti for anyone wishing to prolong their stay here.

name: Marco Martini Restaurant
description: Marco Martini defines cuisine in three words: eyes, stomach, head – it is memories of flavours from bygone days that provide the impetus for his own creations. He is certainly not lacking in curiosity or a willingness to try new things, as he shows in his modern, imaginative dishes, each of which have their own story to tell, inspired by memories and emotions. The wine list is also intriguing, with a selection of little-known yet interesting labels from small producers appearing alongside more famous names. The dining room recalls a winter garden with a mix of styles, plus there’s a terrace-cum-lounge for aperitifs, imaginative cocktails and snacks. The gourmet menu is also available at lunchtime if you book ahead.

name: Venissa
description: Far away from the tourist hordes, Venissa is situated in a small walled vineyard dating back to the Middle Ages – complete with 14C belltower – on the small island of Mazzorbo, a magical setting which is perfect for a short stroll before settling down to eat. In addition to the Dorona di Venezia vineyard, the restaurant also has a kitchen garden which provides most of its vegetables, including unusual varieties such as “castraure”, a type of local artichoke. Once out of the garden, you come to a small wooden bridge which links Mazzorbo to neighbouring Burano, where you can complete your visit to the lagoon by exploring the lacemakers’ shops and admiring the colourful local houses. The main focus here, however, is the cuisine – and excellent cuisine it is too! Chefs Chiara Pavan and Francesco Brutto describe their dishes as “ambientale” (environmental) because of the close connection between the lagoon and the Upper Adriatic: the menu features plenty of fish and vegetables and almost no meat. Guests choose their number of courses and the dishes come as a surprise, accompanied by organic wine pairings. At the Osteria Contemporanea next door the dishes are simpler but still full of flavour.

name: Spazio7
description: Situated on the first floor of the Spazio Espositivo della Fondazione Sandretto Re Rebaudengo, an organisation dedicated to contemporary art, Spazio7 is home to talented chef Antonio Romano, who creates innovative dishes influenced by the region and the seasons that will appeal to all the senses. Two tasting menus are available, as well as an internationally influenced à la carte. There’s also a bistro-café on the ground floor that serves simpler options at lunchtime.

name: Umberto De Martino
address: via Madonna d'Argon 4/6, San Paolo d'Argon, 24060, Italy
description: The bright and elegant Umberto De Martino restaurant, located in the hills overlooking San Paolo d’Argon, is the perfect choice for cuisine full of the sunshine of the chef’s native Sorrentine peninsula. Whatever you choose, the cuisine prepared by this humble, determined and practical chef is excellent in every way. There are three tasting menus available (one of which is vegetarian), from which guests can choose combinations of individual dishes if they wish.

name: Laite
description: “Plissn”, “Asou” and «Verpai” are the three tasting menus (the latter a surprise menu) served at this restaurant run by Fabrizia Meroi. Laite occupies a beautiful, typical mountain property situated in a quiet district and featuring two Stube-style rooms (one dating from the 17C, the other the 18C) decorated with a profusion of wood. Regional recipes and seasonal local ingredients take pride of place in the cuisine, accompanied by wines chosen with enthusiasm by Elena, Fabrizia’s daughter (there’s also a good selection of wines by the glass). Careful attention to flavour is the focus here rather than overly complex dishes, so that every guest can enjoy the delicious food and head home with wonderful memories of this fabulous gourmet experience.

name: Del Cambio
description: Founded in 1757, Del Cambio boasts a combination of romantic period furnishings and contemporary artworks that come together to create a highly elegant setting. Here, Matteo Baronetto, a chef who has made a major contribution to the development of avant-garde Italian cuisine in the early 21C, skilfully offers modern and creative dishes alongside more traditional fare on a menu that is concise yet meaningful without being excessive. For a more direct gastronomic experience, our inspectors recommend booking the chef’s table to savour a menu created on the spot for a maximum of four diners. There’s also an excellent café-cum-bistro and pastry shop,Farmacia Del Cambio , and “Il tavolo della cantina” – located in the wine cellar, this spiritual heart of the restaurant is home to 19 000 bottles and is perfect for informal dinners and wine tastings.

name: Al Sorriso
description: Fans of Piedmontese cuisine will be in their element in this restaurant situated in the attractive Novara hills thanks to enthusiastic chef Luisa Marelli and her husband Angelo Valazza. The latter is constantly on the lookout for excellent local ingredients, while his wife (a literature graduate and self-taught chef who is passionate about cooking) creates dishes which have become classics, are influenced by tradition and prepared with seasonal ingredients such as aromatic herbs, game, mushrooms and truffles. The wine list is particularly extensive.

name: La Credenza
address: via Cavour 22, San Maurizio Canavese, 10077, Italy
description: With its welcoming dining room and touches of modern elegance, La Credenza is in fact a veranda with large windows letting in plenty of natural light and overlooking a charming garden where coffee and evening aperitifs are served. The cuisine (meat and fish) supervised by chef Igor Macchia is highly creative and clearly described by business partner Giovanni Grasso. The wine list is impressive : more than 1 500 labels are stored in two cellars, which are open to the public.

name: Oasis - Sapori Antichi
description: Run by the Fischetti family, this gastronomic oasis has been a stronghold for fine cuisine and regional flavours for almost 35 years now. The restaurant was opened in 1988, a year that is celebrated on the first page of the wine list with an extensive selection of fine labels from that year and also in the ricotta ravioli with walnut and seared garlic created by the restaurant’s founder – a dish still on the menu today. Now, as in the past, it is the women of the family who are at the helm in the kitchen: Michelina Fischetti and her granddaughter Serena Falco continue to conjure up delicious cuisine full of flavour which is prepared using carefully chosen ingredients (mostly organic) from the region with a focus on the passing seasons. The intention here is to create recipes that are open to new food trends and influences, while remaining faithful to a simple style of cuisine that is clean, ethical and inspired by traditional dishes from bygone days. Front of house, the friendly brothers of the family look after guests and oversee the courteous and attentive serving staff.

name: Balzi Rossi
description: This historic bulwark of Italian cuisine on the French border has had a facelift: there’s now a new, elegant and contemporary dining room, although the spectacular view of the Côte d’Azur from the small terrace remains unchanged. The cuisine has its roots in the past with dishes which have been served here for decades, now reinterpreted with a skilful touch of modernity.

name: Carignano
description: Davide Scabin, one of Piedmont’s most famous chefs who was also awarded two Michelin starts at his Rivoli restaurant, continues to reinvent and apply himself with as much enthusiasm as ever. His backdrop is one of the most prestigious hotels in Turin – the historic Grand Hotel Sitea – where he serves a tasting menu that is both bold and innovative, surprising guests with the order of courses: you start with intense flavours and the dishes become lighter as the meal progresses. Scabin offers a superb gastronomic experience on one long tasting menu that includes traditional Piedmontese recipes and more creative dishes, as well as the occasional more exotic influence.

name: Magorabin
description: The owner-chef at this restaurant focuses on recipes firmly rooted in local traditions, using ingredients sourced only in Piedmont. These are showcased on a single tasting menu (“Im-ma-gi-nà-re”) from which guests can choose either five or nine courses. A keen globetrotter, Marcello Trentini prepares regional dishes with a symphony of flavours and a rare combination of boldness, sensitivity, gourmet touches and techniques influenced by his many travels. Situated next to the restaurant, the “Casa Mago Lounge Bar” provides the perfect setting in which to enjoy top-notch cocktails accompanied by tapas and other delicious snacks prepared by the chef.

name: Condividere
description: “The enjoyment of eating” is the mantra of this restaurant, whose name (the Italian word for “to share”) refers to an original idea dreamt up by Lavazza in partnership with talented Spanish chef Ferran Adrià. At the helm here is Federico Zanasi, also from Spain, who focuses on two key elements in his cuisine, namely produce and technique. His menus I Classici, Festival, Gran Festival are served in a modern, contemporary-style dining room with a New York feel, created by the famous stage-designer Dante Ferretti, while the friendly, young and attentive staff are on hand to ensure that guests enjoy the experience to the full, accompanied by music in the background. Dessert and coffee are served in their own dedicated room.

name: Moma
address: via di San Basilio 42, Rome, 00187, Italy
description: Situated between Via Veneto and Piazza Barberini, Moma is a modern, multi-faceted restaurant that serves informal dishes at lunchtime and more creative traditional fare in the gourmet restaurant on the first floor, which also includes a small outdoor dining space that allows guests to make the most of Rome’s mild climate. The balance between textures and combinations and the attention paid to presentation and top-quality ingredients are the key features here, resulting in regionally inspired cuisine that also includes creative dishes such as risotto with camomile, smoked eel, honey and oregano. This focus on the region and its fine local producers is also evident on the wine list, which leans towards labels produced by small artisanal wineries. The young staff are attentive and keen to ensure that your evening is a resounding success.

name: Campo del Drago
address: Località Castiglion del Bosco, Montalcino, 53024, Italy
description: This top quality restaurant is strategically located in the centre of the village. It offers fine cuisine, an elegant ambience and attentive service, ensuring that guests enjoy a relaxing dining experience.

name: La Primula
address: via San Rocco 47, San Quirino, 33080, Italy
description: Situated between Pordenone and Aviano in the magical Magredi region, this elegant restaurant – still run by the Canton family – celebrates its 150th birthday in 2023. The attractive, comfortable dining room is dominated by a fireplace and provides the setting for delicious meat and fish dishes prepared by Andrea Canton, whose cuisine is carefully prepared, occasionally imaginative and full of comforting flavours. The excellent wine is divided into three sections: one dedicated to the Friuli-Venezia Giulia region, another to Italy as a whole, and the third to the rest of the world. The same building houses the Osteria alle Nazioni (also open at lunchtimes), where the cuisine is inspired by regional traditions.

name: Al Metrò
address: via Magellano 35, San Salvo Marina, 66050, Italy
description: Housed in what was once the family pastry shop, this restaurant run by the Fossaceca brothers is elegant and minimalist in style with a charming outdoor space for summer dining. Nicola’s cuisine is prepared using the best fish from the Adriatic combined with other carefully chosen seasonal ingredients from the region. Traditional fish and seafood recipes from the Abruzzo and the wider Mediterranean combine with modern culinary techniques to create carefully prepared dishes that are full of surprisingly simple and direct flavours. The three tasting menus also feature local specialities, such as saffron from Aquila, garlic from Sulmona and fresh produce from local farms. Front of house, Antonio and his talented team provide attentive service, putting guests immediately at ease with their friendly yet formal approach. Last but not least, the excellent wine list demonstrates an obvious focus on the Abruzzo while also offering a selection of international labels.

name: Arnaldo - Clinica Gastronomica
description: Housed in a 15C building next to the Aquila d'Oro hotel, this restaurant boasts an atmospheric dining room with a nostalgic feel. The cuisine has the same traditional focus and celebrates Emilian gastronomic traditions in all their glory, especially on the trolleys used to display selections of antipasti, roast and boiled meats and, last but not least, the desserts. A warm, welcoming and comfortable setting in which time seems to have stood still.

name: La Torre
address: strada Spicciano 7, Tavarnelle Val di Pesa, 50028, Italy
description: Il Castello del Nero, the spectacular 12C residence that is home to this restaurant, stands in a magical location that includes many of the attractions that make Tuscany such a special place to visit – a breathtaking view from its summer terrace, an elegant dining room full of history, and top-quality ingredients such as extra-virgin olive oil and wine (the attractive wine cellar boasts a generous selection of the latter). However, the main attraction here is the excellent cuisine made by friendly chef Di Pirro, which is technical, creative and at the same time full of flavour, and always beautifully presented as befits the charming setting. The property is home to a kitchen garden (cultivated organically although as yet not certified organic) which boasts up to 10 varieties of tomato alongside a number of fruit trees. The restaurant offers three menus: the “Evoluzione Vegetali” vegetarian option; “La Terra”, in which meat dishes take pride of place; and “Il Mare”, featuring fish and seafood specialities. Last but not least, the dessert menu is striking for its extraordinarily imaginative sweets, as well as delicacies such as mini cakes, chocolates and macaroons served with your coffee.

name: Primo Restaurant
description: With just a few tables in a small room crowned by a typical vaulted ceiling in Lecce stone, this candle-lit restaurant is home to young chef Solaika Marrocco, who was born in 1995 in nearby Gallipoli. Here, she creates modern, highly personalised dishes which are not only a feast for the eyes but also for the palate. Despite her young age, this chef produces refined, elegantly simple cuisine which is never dull, and which often showcases ingredients from Puglia and the Salento. She also happily uses old traditional recipes to inspire her, creating her own bold, original and decidedly contemporary interpretations of traditional regional dishes.

name: Ca' Vittoria
description: In the heart of this picture-postcard village, the Musso family has been welcoming guests with typical Piedmontese hospitality and professionalism for generations and delighting them with their interesting cuisine. Grandmother Gemma and mother Sandra always focused on regional traditions in their cooking; today, Massimiliano continues the theme while adding a touch of creativity and an international influence to his Piedmontese dishes. Examples include his innovative and original risotto cooked in onion water with eel and vanilla, and delicious Cherasco snails served with coconut cream, grilled home-grown leeks and fermented cabbage (the sweet flavour of the coconut provides a striking contrast to the acidity of the cabbage). There are just two tasting menus, from which dishes can also be chosen à la carte, plus a few classic favourites seasoned with white truffles (in season). The wine list features renowned Piedmontese labels alongside an array of younger wines, as well as a few bottles of Barolo from the 1970s.

name: Cannavacciuolo Bistrot
description: Although you’d expect a bistro to be relaxed and informal, this casually elegant restaurant just a stone’s throw from the Po river and the Gran Madre has a particularly lively atmosphere. Here, young chef Emin Haziri (formerly at Villa Crespi) serves meat and fish dishes that pay tribute to northern and southern Italy alike, offering cuisine that is inspired by the region, the Mediterranean and elsewhere in Italy with just the right amount of creative flair.

name: Oro Restaurant
description: For visitors not staying at the legendary Hotel Cipriani (home to Oro Restaurant), the excitement of this dining experience starts with your journey from St Mark’s Square. From here, the hotel’s private boat will take you to Giudecca island across one of the most spectacular corners of the lagoon which is overlooked by some of Venice’s most famous sights and monuments. Renowned celebrities have stayed at the Cipriani, where the cuisine at Oro is certainly worthy of its magnificent setting. Chef Riccardo Cannella aims to create a new culinary language in Venice, exploring and skilfully adapting nature’s incredible ingredients. Whether you choose the indoor dining room or the terrace, you’ll be treated to a splendid view of the lagoon which extends from San Giorgio island to the Lido.

name: La Capinera
address: via Nazionale 177, località Spisone, Taormina, 98039, Italy
description: “My cuisine reflects my region”, says owner-chef Pietro D’Agostino, “It’s full of sunshine, fresh, influenced by tradition and yet at the same time modern.” Our inspectors came to a similar conclusion: they describe this chef’s cuisine as innovative yet with regional roots, and his constant search for the best ingredients as endearingly obsessive.
