Fresh fish, locally grown vegetables, various types of local olive oil and snail caviar all feature on the menu which has a real Slow Food focus. The beautiful terrace overlooking the Ionian Sea adds to the appeal, as does the wine list which is impressive and surprising in equal measure.

name: Guido
description: Although from the outside this looks like a simple private beach club with views of the sea in the distance, the interior reveals an unexpected and hushed elegance. Guests flock to Guido’s for its excellent fish and seafood: the dishes sound simple on the menu, yet are actually refined, elegant and beautifully prepared, celebrating the Adriatic in all its glory, with a focus on top-quality fish dishes. The menu features long-established classics (“canocchia si ricorda il gratin”) alongside new dishes such as the pizza ai frutti di mare which are themselves destined to become staples here. There’s a good choice of sparkling wines, as well as a focus on excellent whites and renowned reds.

name: Abocar Due Cucine
description: Abocar (the word is Spanish for “to get closer”) demonstrates the Argentine origins of this restaurant’s young chef , who aims to offer his guests reasonably priced gourmet cuisine. Seasonal produce and South American influences are to the fore here, resulting in excellent cuisine focused around just a handful of recipes.The dishes are creative, yet with their roots in the classic foundations in which the young chef was trained in Michelin-starred restaurants in France, Spain and Italy – it was during this apprenticeship that he met his partner, Camilla, who assists him in the kitchen as well as overseeing the front of house. This welcoming restaurant hidden among the streets of old Rimini boasts a charming, youthful and unique atmosphere which is far from stuffy and which makes it an excellent choice.

name: Sadler
description: A stronghold of Milanese cuisine for over 30 years, Sadler now has a new location in the Casa Baglioni hotel, a beautiful Art Nouveau-style building dating from 1913. The restaurant has a contemporary feel with an elegant dining room featuring colourful armchairs. The cuisine is precise and distinctive, with a harmonious balance of traditional and innovative flavours as well as top-quality ingredients. The wine list is also top of the range, featuring excellent Italian and international wines, including some rare and interesting labels. Although the menu at midday is lighter, the cuisine is of the same high quality.

name: Accursio
description: Situated near the Duomo di San Pietro and the central Corso Umberto, this small, delightful restaurant occupies a historic palazzo and boasts a simple yet elegant decor including attractive floor tiles. Accursio offers three tasting menus with dishes also available à la carte. The restaurant’s symbol (an olive tree inside a boat) gives a good indication of the culinary focus here, namely a creative journey through Sicily’s cuisine on a menu that features both meat and fish options.

name: Gellius
description: Gellius boasts a unique and atmospheric setting within the Antica Opitergium museum, surrounded by archaeological remains that tell the story of the town from the beginning of the Roman period. It’s just a short hop from this historic past to the present day, where chef Alessandro Breda moves away from the culinary traditions of the region to create imaginative meat and fish dishes using ingredients from his surrounding area and the Adriatic Sea. The same ambience can be enjoyed at the Nyù bistro, which serves light lunches and more elaborate dinners. If you’re looking for a state-of-the-art cocktail or a glass of good wine, make your way to the Lounge Bar, which looks out over Piazza Grande.

name: Indaco
address: piazza Santa Restituta 1, Lacco Ameno, 80076, Italy
description: Housed in a long-established hotel (the Regina Isabella was founded in the 1950s by a famous publisher), Indaco adds to Ischia’s appeal thanks to its elegant atmosphere (there’s also a romantic candlelit lounge where guests can enjoy a coffee or digestif) and its top-quality gourmet cuisine. Overlooking one of the island’s most enchanting bays, the restaurant is home to chef Pasquale Palamaro (a native of Ischia) who takes guests on a culinary journey inspired by his love of the sea. The chef’s past experience and his passion for fish has led him to focus solely on fish-based cuisine. Starting with his dishes of dry-cured fish and seafood, you’ll enjoy an array of delicious dishes which combine flavour and creativity. Enjoy the best of the sea without getting your feet wet!

name: D.One Restaurant
description: The location of this restaurant is certainly unique, offering different spaces for different parts of your meal (aperitif, dinner, tastings etc). Here, chef Davide Pezzuto from Salento blends simplicity with creative experimentation, sourcing his fish from the nearby Adriatic and other ingredients from the restaurant’s own farm, including vegetables, wine, olive oil, cereals (ground in a water mill) and eggs. Demonstrating commendable personal involvement, the restaurant plays an important role in maintaining the gastronomic and historic traditions of the small town. The wine selection is also unusual: although it’s presented in the traditional way, it also highlights some of the local area’s “heroic” producers.

name: Amistà
description: Occupying a corner of the stunning Hotel Byblos, this restaurant is similar in style to the rest of the hotel with its colourful and harmonious blend of the old and the new, inspired by a real love of art. Echoing the decor, the cuisine served here plays with a combination of the traditional and the modern. The chef adds his own creative touches and interpretations to traditional recipes on three tasting menus which feature alternating meat and fish dishes, although guests can switch between the menus and dishes, giving them more freedom of choice. The interesting wine list includes a choice of excellent wines by the glass.

name: Schöneck
description: With over 30 years’ experience behind them, the Baumgartner brothers’ restaurant is an excellent choice for classic specialities from the Alto Adige, offering a menu that focuses on regional dishes yet also includes a few fish-based options. The most important feature here is that all specialities are made from top-quality ingredients (often locally sourced), prepared by chef Karl with an expertise that ignores modern trends and passing fashions. Meals are served in rooms that are elegantly decorated with local wood, including a beautiful lounge space with a piano in front of the bar, Stube-style dining rooms and a veranda, while in summer the cool, shady terrace is particularly appealing. Last but not least, the excellent wine list is as impressive as the cuisine.

name: Antica Osteria Nonna Rosa
address: via Laudano 1, loc. Pietrapiana, Vico Equense, 80060, Italy
description: The dining room at this restaurant has the warm ambience of an old country house, where two small niches with their own tables are perfect for a more private and romantic dinner. The decor includes dove-coloured walls, an array of lamps and even a typical nativity scene in which the chef and his mother (“Nonna Rosa”) make an appearance. The cuisine is original and creative with its roots in local traditions, and is prepared using ingredients from Campania and the restaurant’s own kitchen garden. Some years ago, owner-chef Giuseppe Guida purchased a large garden where he now grows all the vegetables used in his dishes. The restaurant describes its cuisine as “An exciting discovery of flavours from bygone days, with imaginative touches that are fully respectful of local traditions.”.

name: Paolo e Barbara
description: Paolo and Barbara have been serving excellent cuisine in San Remo ever since 1987, gradually increasing their focus on regional specialities over the years. This interest has culminated in two kitchen gardens that now provide most of the ingredients used in their dishes, including eggs and olive oil. Along with top-quality fish (including San Remo’s famous crayfish), vegetables form the basis of western Liguria’s cuisine, which Paolo combines in his reinterpretations of traditional recipes, while Barbara oversees the service front of house and provides guests with wine recommendations.

name: Guidoristorante
description: Lidia and Guido Alciati opened their restaurant in 1961, and Italian cuisine has not been the same since – their hard work signalled the beginning of a real change which revolutionised cooking in Italy. They were among the first to understand the importance of regional ingredients, sourcing excellent produce which Lidia then showcased in her superb dishes, while Guido was responsible for the attentive service and excellent wine list. Their teachings live on in the sumptuous dining rooms in Villa Fontanafredda, where their children continue the culinary traditions established by their parents. Ugo’s sensitive skills in the kitchen and Piero’s experience front of house contribute to the success of this restaurant, where the best food and wine from the region is served in deceptively simple dishes that have few equals. One of the highlights is the plin (stuffed agnolotti pasta closed with a “pinch” by Lidia), which has drawn visitors here from all around the world and which is as delicious as ever – the pasta is stuffed with meat and vegetables and served with a velvety meat sauce.

name: Casa Iozzìa
description: Situated in the countryside outside Viterbo, this restaurant boasts a minimalist design featuring neutral colours, just a few tables and a large fireplace. Chef Lorenzo Iozzia, who was born in Lentini in Sicily and has been in Viterbo for three decades, creates modern and creative cuisine with a strong focus on his native island. He admits that his connection with Sicily is still strong, as demonstrated by the typical Sicilian ingredients (fish, almonds, carob, prickly pear, oranges etc) used in his dishes. On the floor below, the Osteria Basilicò serves traditional Sicilian specialities, plus a selection of main courses cooked over the charcoal grill.

name: Prezioso
description: Once you leave Merano, a road running through the woods leads to Castel Fragsburg, a fairytale-like residence with traditional guestrooms and public spaces full of atmosphere. Meals are served either in the elegant dining rooms or, in fine weather, outdoors on one of the most spectacular terraces in Italy, perched high above the valley. In the kitchen, Egon Heiss demonstrates his culinary talent on a tasting menu of creative dishes which are made mostly from local mountain ingredients, including freshwater fish and wild game. The excellent desserts are particularly worthy of mention.

name: Zappatori
description: The restaurant is temporarily closed.Hidden in an alleyway in Pinerolo’s historic centre, this restaurant offers a timeless and relaxing space in which the play of light and shade creates a harmonious ambience. The atmosphere at Zappatori is certainly romantic, with a small private room and winter garden for intimate dining adding to the appeal. In the kitchen, Christian Milone skilfully creates classic Piedmontese favourites using produce from his own farm, as well as offering a few more modern dishes. The “Mercato” tasting menu combines the influences of past and present, while the title of the “Menu 1975, le mie origini…” (“Menu 1975, my origins”) gives an indication of what to expect on the menu.

name: Osteria del Povero Diavolo
description: This restaurant is situated in a picture-postcard setting in the foothills of Romagna, offering views of the gently rolling hills and San Marino perched on a mountain top just a few kilometres away. Here, a young chef is at the helm, breathing new life into this long-established restaurant with his creative cuisine. Meat and fish dishes feature on the 8-course menu, all prepared using local ingredients. A delightful outdoor dining space and welcoming guestrooms complete the picture.

For Flavio Costa, the brilliant chef at this restaurant named after the date his twin daughters were born, becoming a cook is a question of passion and patience. The restaurant is situated inland from the Ligurian coast on a wine estate that was producing wine as early as the 15C. Here, Flavio creates cuisine that harmoniously combines ingredients and recipes from Liguria and Piedmont (including fish and seafood specialities), often reinterpreted with a creative twist. The La Via del Sale osteria serves traditional cuisine and boasts stunning views of the surrounding hills and vineyards.

name: Sissi
description: Situated just outside the pedestrianised area of beautiful Merano, the main dining room of this restaurant has a welcoming feel and is decorated in attractive Art-Nouveau style. Here, owner-chef Andrea Fenoglio divides his time between the kitchen and front of house so that he can take time to chat with guests. His cuisine has solid classic foundations, with a good choice of dishes on the à la carte, plus a surprise tasting menu (Settepiatti ) which changes every year (as does the ceramic tableware on which it is served!). The cuisine is comforting and full of generous flavours, to which Fenoglio adds a light modern touch with his carefully chosen accompaniments and presentation. Whatever dish you choose, you can be sure of finding the perfect wine pairing for your meal on the skilfully constructed wine list.

name: La Tana Gourmet
description: In the summer of 2021, the two owner-partners at La Tana Gourmet, chef Alessandro Dal Degan and sommelier Enrico Maglio, opened this restaurant, a project which is dear to their hearts. Here, there are just five tables where guests can enjoy a gastronomic experience based on one tasting menu of more than twenty small courses (including appetisers and larger dishes) in which the chef showcases ingredients from the region combined with produce from further afield. Using skilful techniques and a bold approach, he plays with sharp, acidic and fresh flavours, along with the natural scents of dozens of aromatic herbs. As you can imagine, with such a personal approach to cuisine the best option here is to go for the wine pairing selected by Enrico Maglio, who has a wine list of over a thousand labels to choose from.

name: Impronta d'Acqua
address: via Aurelia 2121, Cavi di Lavagna, 16030, Italy
description: A modern, open space decorated in a minimalist yet warm contemporary style, with just a few tables. Situated on the straight road following the seafront and the railway line, this restaurant combines regional ingredients with new culinary techniques. The bold, thoughtful dishes showcase fish from the nearby sea, flavoured with herbs such as bay leaves, thyme, cicerbita and rapunzel which conjure up the scents and colours of the hills behind Lavagna, where owner-chef Ivan purchases his extra-virgin olive oil and high-quality meat from local producers. The three tasting menus – Pensieri, Goloso e Vegetariano - offer something for everyone.

name: Maeba Restaurant
description: Housed in a beautifully restored olive oil mill dating from the 18C and situated in the countryside just outside Ariano Irpino, this restaurant is an unlikely find in this mountainous region – elegant, decorated in contemporary style and with a menu featuring regional cuisine as well as fish and seafood dishes, all of which are decidedly modern in flavour. Good selection of wines and spirits.

name: Contraste
description: You ring the doorbell to enter this restaurant, which has the appearance of a private home – an impression which continues in the elegant dining room with its attractive mix of old and modern features, such as the 19C ceiling and fireplace and the contemporary paintings on the walls. This original decor echoes the cuisine, which is served on just one surprise menu made up of different courses. The dishes are playfully presented, with ingredients occasionally combined to resemble different produce so that guests are often surprised by the flavours of their dish, all of which showcase the chef’s remarkable technical expertise. At the end of your meal, the significance of the restaurant name becomes apparent: the meat and fish dishes are indeed full of contrasts – in both temperature and texture, making this a perfect dining experience for anyone fond of bold and surprising cuisine.

name: Bros'
description: Bros' is a synonym for a young, free spirit which is full of creativity and imagination: Floriano Pellegrino and Isabella Potì make the most of their extraordinary energy on two tasting menus that range from 20 to 25 small courses (note that the restaurant no longer offers an à la carte) which can be “tracked” in advance through a QR code. Their cuisine features innovative and surprising tasting dishes – many of which are finished with a theatrical flourish at your table – all the way through to the excellent desserts. To a background of modern music, guests are guided on a no-holds-barred journey through the personal gastronomic world of two exciting chefs. An interesting wine list which includes a selection of organic and biodynamic labels, and excellent service complete the picture.

name: Il Faro di Capo d'Orso - Andrea Aprea
description: Although it’s almost hidden from the road, once you step out of your car and head down the steps into this restaurant, you’ll be greeted by one of the most breathtaking views of the Amalfi Coast, which takes in Ravello, Amalfi and, on clear days, even Capri’s Faraglioni rocks. The three tasting menus on offer here feature technical, complex and experimental dishes with a focus on local and regional ingredients, often from the Amalfi Coast itself. The cuisine is overseen by the famous chef from Campania, Andrea Aprea, while the quality is guaranteed by resident chef Salvatore Pacifico. The service front of house is in the capable hands of Bonny, part of the fourth generation of the owner’s family. A la carte available at lunchtime.

name: Vitantonio Lombardo
address: via Madonna delle Virtù 13/14, Matera, 75100, Italy
description: Minimalist furnishings and lighting contrast with the unusual setting of this restaurant, which occupies a thousand-year-old cave in the centre of the Sasso Barisano district. Creative dishes feature on the menu alongside more regionally influenced options reinterpreted with a contemporary twist, as well as new recipes on a tasting menu of between five and twelve courses. Originally from Basilicata, owner-chef Vitantonio Lombardo has the distinction of holding the first Michelin star ever awarded in Matera, a long-held personal dream for him. “I’ve worked around the world,” he says, “and now that I’ve returned to cook in the place that holds so many childhood memories for me, I want to blend these global influences with regional traditions, while ensuring that this region remains the dominant character in my dishes”.

name: Il Cantinone e Sport Hotel Alpina
address: via A. De Giacomi 39, Madesimo, 23024, Italy
description: Working under the watchful eye of his namesake Stefano Masanti, Stefano Ciabarri is the young chef at the helm in this restaurant. He focuses on the use of natural, seasonal and regional ingredients in his cuisine, carefully seeking out small local producers for ingredients such as red bilberries from Madesimo and local beef and pork, as well as making use of the excellent homemade bresaola and other delicacies purchased from the village delicatessen. It’s well worth heading to Madesimo for two reasons: the famous gully attracts expert skiers, while the gourmet Il Cantinone is a must for food-lovers, where Raffaela, a skilful maître d’ and experienced sommelier, provides a friendly welcome front of house.

name: Locanda Tamerici
address: via Litoranea 106, località Fiumaretta, Ameglia, 19031, Italy
description: The Locanda Tamerici is being brought back to life with the return of chef Mauro Ricciardi, whose focus is on top-quality Mediterranean cuisine full of clean flavours and technical precision. The result is the best local fish dishes (alongside other options) brought to your table. Meals are served in a welcoming refurbished dining room, where the attentive service is overseen by the excellent master-sommelier, or in the garden where guests can enjoy the gentle breeze from the sea just a stone’s throw away. Good wine selection, which is gradually expanding. Welcome back, Mauro!

name: Ma.Ri.Na.
address: piazza San Gregorio 11, Olgiate Olona, 21057, Italy
description: You’ll find a friendly welcome and delicious, top-quality cuisine at Ma.Ri.Na, a long-established restaurant that has been in business for over 40 years. The menu features classic fish specialities alongside occasionally more imaginative and unusual fare, including daily specials that change depending on market availability. The wine selection is also excellent and includes a good choice of wines by the glass.

name: Glass Hostaria
description: In the heart of Trastevere, a chef from Puglia delights guests with cuisine which is a perfect balance of fusion, traditional, elegance and innovation in dishes that are highly original and never boring. Vegetarians are particularly well catered for, with one of the two tasting menus focusing entirely on vegetables. Ingredients are carefully chosen from the best, often small, local producers, while the service here is attentive without being overbearing. Last but not least, the wine list offers a good selection of labels as well as an impressive choice of excellent wines by the glass.

name: Malga Panna
address: strada de Sort 64, località Sorte, Moena, 38035, Italy
description: The story of the Donei family is intertwined with the history of the Alpine farm (“malga”) that was transformed into a restaurant in the 1950s when the parents of the current owner-chef, Paolo, used to prepare delicious dishes for the first holidaymakers to the region. The “malga” is also the symbol of what is now one of the best restaurants in the Fassa valley. All that remains of the “malga” today is its name and the panoramic location above the village and the valley, views of which can be enjoyed from the new veranda dining room decorated in minimalist Alpine style with floor-to-ceiling glass windows. The contemporary, regionally inspired cuisine served here is of high quality, prepared by the skilful owner who is a naturally talented chef. There’s also a tasting menu, which combines Trentino influences with Mediterranean touches. In a nod to the restaurant’s location (on the edge of the woods) and its history, simpler options are also available.

name: Zass
description: The legendary San Pietro is one of the jewels of the Amalfi Coast as well as one of the most famous hotels in the world. Zass, its Michelin-starred restaurant, is extremely popular with visitors (booking in advance is highly recommended) thanks to skilful Belgian chef Alois Vanlangenaeker, who has now been here for over 20 years. His cuisine showcases all the colours and flavours of the Mediterranean with harmony and elegance, focusing mainly on the traditions of Campania, especially in appetisers such as the small bites of lightly baked Pizza Margherita and in creative dishes elsewhere on the menu. Many of his ingredients are sourced from the hotel’s kitchen garden, which he uses to create dishes based on meat and, especially, fish, including his signature John Dory (flavoured with lemon and accompanied by mashed potatoes with bufala yoghurt, seasonal vegetables and his famous Champagne and truffle sauce), and other fish such as mullet, sea bass, scampi and squid. Excellent service, a pianist providing background music, and an idyllic terrace boasting stunning views all play their part in making this a truly memorable dining experience.

name: Vespasia
description: Situated in the historic centre of Noto which is slowly returning to life after the earthquake, this restaurant is part of the smart Palazzo Seneca hotel. You pass through a succession of small rooms to get to the elegant Sala del Vespasia, where a female Japanese chef now showcases the best of Umbrian gastronomic delights after many years working in Campania and renowned restaurants elsewhere in Italy. Olive oil, cured hams, lentils, Cannara onions, crayfish and river fish, lamb from the Sibillini mountains and, of course, the excellent local black truffle are used in her creative and occasional complex dishes. Our description would not be complete without mentioning the excellent service and warm, friendly welcome offered by the Bianconi, a long-established family in Norcia’s hotel and restaurant sector.

name: Johannesstube
address: via San Valentino 3, Nova Levante, 39056, Italy
description: The strictly regional ingredients used at this restaurant are sourced from local farmers and producers, with just a few exceptions such as sugar, truffles, salt, rice etc. Chef Theodor Falser is a purist where the region’s plentiful produce is concerned, although he does admit to a weakness for cooking and fermentation methods from further afield. He considers himself fortunate to have been born in these mountains and this good fortune is shared by those who are lucky enough to dine in this historic Stube-style restaurant built using vintage wood, which is the jewel in the Engel hotel’s crown. There’s also an excellent wine list with a focus on the Alto Adige.

name: Casamatta
description: Just a few kilometres outside Manduria, the capital of primitive wine, this restaurant is part of the Vinilia Wine Resort, which occupies an imposing early-20C castle surrounded by splendid grounds planted with mature olive trees. The restaurant is the jewel in the crown of this fine hotel, with its bright, airy dining room and large windows offering views of its outdoor dining space (highly recommended in fine weather). The furnishings are modern in design and the cleverly arranged lighting adds to the charm of the setting. With plenty of experience at leading restaurants behind him, chef Pietro Penna has returned home to his native region, to which he pays tribute in his cuisine. He makes full use of locally sourced produce, often using fruit and vegetables grown in the restaurant’s own kitchen garden in his modern and imaginative dishes. Three tasting menus are available, one of which is entirely vegetarian.

name: Dolada
address: via Dolada 21, località Plois alt. 870, Pieve d'Alpago, 32010, Italy
description: An idyllic picture-postcard setting in a panoramic location overlooking Santa Croce lake, surrounded by villages and mountain peaks. This is matched by an elegant interior with a mix of antique and modern furnishings, and a succession of stylish small dining rooms and lounges, including an open fireplace where many of the ingredients are cooked. For over a century, this restaurant has told the story of the De Pra family and their love for the mountains which is clearly evident in the cuisine served here. Chef Riccardo has strengthened this connection by intensifying his search for local ingredients (game, mushrooms, freshwater fish etc) and cultivating his own kitchen garden and vineyard. The fragrant ingredients are prepared simply yet with technical expertise, with flavour always the primary focus – an infallible recipe for resounding success!

name: Tantris
description: At this restaurant with just one modern and elegant dining room, guests are taken on a creative gastronomic journey with a menu that features meat and fish dishes alike. The cuisine here has its roots in the region, yet offers modern reinterpretations with original combinations, often with influences from other parts of Italy. A superb selection of over 600 wines completes the picture.

name: La Tavola
description: Riccardo’s dishes are based on balance, offering a harmonious combination of flavours, scents and textures that sum up all this chef has learnt in recent years. His cuisine is modern yet influenced by the culinary traditions of Italy and – especially – by the nearby lake and mountains. Elegant, imaginative cuisine created by a chef who is equally at ease with meat, seafood or fish from the lake. Although the restaurant now has a striking new look, its delightful lakeside terrace is still there, built right over the water and offering fine views over the lake.

name: Il Ristorante di Guido da Costigliole
address: località San Maurizio 39, Santo Stefano Belbo, 12058, Italy
description: Situated in a panoramic location surrounded by beautiful rolling hills, this restaurant occupies an old 17C monastery which has been converted into one of the region’s most elegant and exclusive hotels, namely the Relais San Maurizio. Here, Andrea Alciati continues with the story started by his parents, Guido and Lidia who, in 1961, opened a restaurant in Costigliole d’Asti which in a short space of time revolutionised and redefined modern Piedmontese cuisine. The adventure continues today in the capable hands of chef Luca Zecchin, who serves time-honoured local favourites such as ravioli del plin al sugo d’arrosto(a dish which made Lidia famous around the world) alongside more creative options, all prepared using top-quality ingredients, as is the trademark of this restaurant. Whether you dine outdoors or in the charming, elegant dining room housed in the palazzo’s former wine cellars, the service is excellent. The wine list is as impressive as the cuisine, offering an extensive selection which includes a huge choice of wines by the glass.

name: All'Oro
description: Situated within The H’All Tailor Suite, a smart “tailor-made” hotel which offers its guests bespoke services, this restaurant boasts a pleasantly sophisticated New York-style dining room plus a second room with a vaguely English decor, both of which serve as a setting for creative Italian cuisine. Chef Riccardo Di Giacinto’s culinary philosophy can be summed up in three adjectives: sincere, delicious and tenacious! The extensive and carefully chosen wine selection favours the regions of Piedmont and Tuscany. Enjoy alfresco dining in the welcoming outdoor All’Aria.in summer.

name: Josè Restaurant - Tenuta Villa Guerra
address: via Nazionale 414, Torre del Greco, 80059, Italy
description: Housed in an 18C Vesuvian-style house that is part of the Ville del Miglio D’oro, José Restaurant is the setting for creative dishes influenced by traditional recipes, as well as a lounge bar area serving interesting cocktails. The delicious dishes here focus on seasonal ingredients from Campania, including produce from the restaurant’s own biodynamic kitchen garden and orchard, regional specialities such as lemons and seafood, as well as carefully chosen ingredients from further afield. Young chef Domenico Iavarone’s imagination takes full flight on his dessert menu, which is rivalled by the equally excellent wine list that includes labels from around the globe. In summer, options include a lighter gourmet menu, outdoor dining, and a meat grill.

name: Lanterna Verde
address: frazione San Barnaba 7, Villa di Chiavenna, 23029, Italy
description: Thanks to its fireplace, the welcoming, classic-style dining room at this restaurant is perfect for winter dining, while its garden terrace attracts guests in summer. Whatever time of year you visit, you’ll enjoy cuisine which balances traditional recipes with more contemporary options, with a focus on local ingredients, especially fish from the lake. The Tonola family at the helm have been renowned throughout the province (and further afield) for their gourmet cuisine and welcoming hospitality for over 40 years. Their appeal is even greater today, thanks to young chef Roberto who provides a skilful modern touch in the kitchen, while his experienced parents oversee the front of house and make helpful wine recommendations.

name: Il Pellicano
address: località Lo Sbarcatello, Porto Ercole, 58018, Italy
description: After a period working in Paris, Michelino Gioia, a native of Campania with a weakness for Tuscany, has returned to Italy to work with the Sciò family, where he demonstrates a new focus on a “less is more” philosophy. He uses just a few ingredients in his dishes, allowing the flavour of these ingredients to shine through in imaginative reinterpretations of traditional recipes with contrasting textures, decisive flavours and an equal focus on meat and fish. With its terrace overlooking the sea and the scent of rosemary in the air, Il Pellicano is one of the most romantic addresses in Italy, enhanced by the friendly, professional service provided by its many staff.

name: Il Gallo Cedrone
address: via Cima Tosa 80, Madonna di Campiglio, 38086, Italy
description: Having just celebrated its 15th birthday, Il Gallo Cedrone at the Bertelli hotel is showing no sign of age! With ever-growing confidence, Sabino Fortunato continues to celebrate the mountains in his cuisine – through the use of game, freshwater fish, cooking with hay and cheese – as well as remaining open to influences from the Mediterranean and elsewhere in Italy. His dishes are always well structured and prepared from many different ingredients, which he skilfully combines to produce the best flavours. The excellent wine cellar is home to over 800 different labels carefully selected by owner Marco Masè, together with long-established sommelier Giuseppe Greco, plus a wide array of gin and tonics.

name: La Tortuga
description: Although the name of this restaurant may conjure up images of the Caribbean Sea and its beaches, La Tortuga is actually located on the square overlooking the harbour right in the centre of Gargnano – its owners, however, are full of the spirit of the eponymous Caribbean island! This small, charming gem of a restaurant is run by female staff in its kitchen and front of house. The cuisine here takes no notice of passing trends, instead focusing on simple and precise cooking methods, so that the flavour of the ingredients (especially the seafood and fish from the lake) really shines through. The wine list is extensive, carefully put together and skilfully explained, with a focus on international wines. La Tortuga has been the proud holder of a Michelin star for over 40 years!

name: Butterfly
description: Butterfly boasts an almost magical setting, with an impeccably tended garden for warm summer days and an elegant dining room in the beautiful 19C farmhouse. Here, Fabrizio and Andrea serve excellent, consistent cuisine with something for everyone on the menu – there’s a particular focus on the highly creative first courses. The management team here stands out for its friendly approach, while in the dining room Mariella oversees an enthusiastic and professional team who ensure that guests enjoy attentive service down to the smallest detail. Our inspectors particularly recommend the panna cotta with cherry jam served in a large glass.

name: La Favellina
address: via Cosari 4/6, località San Tomio, Malo, 36034, Italy
description: Signora Gianello fell in love with this delightful late-19C hamlet surrounded by the green hills north of Vicenza and bought a restaurant here, which she has renovated in an elegant, feminine style. She now runs the restaurant with her two sons: Riccardo front of house and Federico in the kitchen with his mother (the latter responsible for the delicious first courses!). The cuisine here is predominantly contemporary Italian, prepared from top-quality ingredients often sourced from the area immediately around the restaurant. Sweet chestnuts, virgin olive oil, strawberry tree berries, aromatic and even wild herbs are gathered personally by the chefs from the local area. Simple, modern cuisine which is full of flavour.

name: Relais Blu
description: Partially hidden along the road, this restaurant is accessed via a short descent which leads you to a breathtaking terrace boasting views of Capri and the Faraglioni rocks, Ischia, Procida, Naples and Vesuvius, all of which seem to be reflected in the beautiful Bay of Naples. In this stunning setting, Alberto Annarumma creates cuisine which is both new and traditional, regional and creative, in dishes which have solid Italian roots with the occasional nod to France and Japan. The chef’s surrounding area is a constant inspiration to him, and he even tends a kitchen garden in the hotel grounds – its citrus fruit, aromatic and wild herbs are liberally used in his recipes. There’s also an excellent selection of regional wines, a good choice of wines available by the glass, plus a fine array of liqueurs and Cuban cigars.

name: Vecchia Malcesine
description: Situated in a tranquil spot above Malcesine yet not far from the centre, this restaurant boasts fine views of much of Lake Garda. Originally from the Alto Adige, chef Leandro Luppi has been creating superb cuisine in this region for over 20 years and is now at the helm in the kitchen here. Renowned for his culinary skills and imagination, he offers three creative and highly personal tasting menus, one of which is entirely vegetarian. Most of the chef’s ingredients are sourced from the local region, while his legendary ability to transform fresh fish into delicious dishes remains unchanged.

name: Gagini Restaurant
description: Situated in the lively heart of Palermo between the Vucciria and the small Cala port, this restaurant boasts a modern design and bold colours which are all the more striking for the charming old building which it occupies, the 16C studio of sculptor Antonello Gagini. The Italian-Brazilian chef Mauricio Zillo settled in Palermo after stints working in restaurants around Europe. His cuisine is highly personal, yet well-balanced and rich in flavours – not surprising, given his past experience and his dual nationality! The service is elegant and attentive yet with an informal touch that puts guests at their ease, while the carefully compiled wine list includes several labels produced by small local wineries.

name: L'Erba del Re
description: Situated in a period palazzo near one of Modena’s oldest churches (the façade of Santa Maria della Pomposa dates from the medieval period and the church was rebuilt in 1717), this bright, modern and minimalist restaurant has just a few tables set some distance apart and is adorned with contemporary paintings on its walls. Talented chef Luca Marchini focuses mainly on creative cuisine, although fans of more traditional fare will also find a few Emilian specialities on the menu. The excellent sommelier is also able to recommend interesting and rare wines from small-scale wineries, including from outside Italy and often by the glass.

name: Stube Hermitage
address: via Castelletto Inferiore 69, Madonna di Campiglio, 38086, Italy
description: Situated in a tranquil and secluded location, this restaurant occupies an early-19C Stube-style dining room in the Biohotel Hermitage. Decorated with a profusion of wood and offering just a few tables, the setting is perfect for a romantic evening with a focus on fine dining. The cuisine makes good use of local produce, such as the excellent beef, game and freshwater fish which the chef transforms into imaginative and beautifully presented dishes. Elegance is the key word here, both in the ambience and the cuisine. The excellent selection of cheeses is also worthy of note.

name: Sarri
address: lungomare C. Colombo 108, Borgo Prino, Imperia, 18100, Italy
description: One of the best Michelin-starred addresses in the region, this attractive restaurant is situated in the charming Borgo Prino, a row of houses facing the sea and painted in the pastel shades typical of the region. Liguria’s legendary mild climate means that meals can often be enjoyed outdoors, but if that’s not an option there’s also a charming dining room in an old warehouse decorated in impeccable contemporary style. The faultless, elegant service here is overseen with skill and charm by the chef’s wife Alessandra. We’ve left the real reason for our enthusiasm until last: owner-chef Andrea Sarri delights guests with his superb cuisine, which features light and imaginative reinterpretations of Ligurian fish and seafood specialities, inspired by the extraordinary quality of his ingredients. Examples include a perfect yet simple shellfish casserole, as well as his raw fish dish with black garlic from Vessalico and other Ligurian flavours.

name: Il Flauto di Pan
description: It would be no exaggeration to say that this restaurant (part of the Villa Cimbrone hotel) is situated in one of the most romantic and exclusive spots in Italy, surrounded by luxuriant Mediterranean vegetation and with stunning views of the Gulf of Salerno. Once at the restaurant, you make your way to the terrace, where views of the sea with the Cilento mountains in the distance are framed by a beautiful wisteria. The chef from Campania offers guests a superb selection of local produce, prepared in traditional and reinterpreted dishes that are full of the intense and explosive flavours of this extraordinary region. Make sure you book a table in advance!

name: Signum
address: via Scalo 15, località Malfa, Salina, 98050, Italy
description: Situated in the Aeolian Islands, this charming inn is home to young chef Martina Caruso who, having practically grown up here, has returned home to take up the reins at Signum after formative experiences elsewhere. Today, this young chef leads a team of nine in the kitchen, while her brother manages the charming hotel built to resemble a typical Aeolian hamlet. Martina knows exactly how to bring out the best of the vibrant ingredients sourced from the region, her own kitchen garden and the nearby sea – she allows the power of these ingredients to shine forth yet manages to make light and playful use of their intense flavours, showcasing their qualities instead of trying to hide them. Luca and cousin Raffaele enhance this gourmet experience with excellent wines (some home-produced), also available by the glass, and superb cocktails.

name: Le Trabe
address: via Capo di Fiume 4, Paestum, 84047, Italy
description: The source of the Trabe river lies in the grounds of this restaurant (hence its name), from where it gushes into a small lake and then flows silently alongside the outdoor tables, creating a delightful space for summer dining. In addition to this beautiful setting, the restaurant also offers inviting dining rooms and champions an environmentally friendly approach, adopting various sustainable practices. However, more than anything it is Marci Rispo’s cuisine that is truly memorable. Whichever of the two tasting menus you choose, your fine-dining experience will start with a welcome aperitif and canapés offered by the chef in the beautiful wine cellar. Once at your table, you’ll enjoy a series of elegant dishes which are full of flavour, inspired by the culinary traditions of Campania and made from seasonal, regional ingredients such as the famous mozzarella di bufala, including the spaghetti dish known as “Bufala, bufala, bufala”. An excellent wine list and attentive service complete the picture.

name: Nostrano
description: Situated just a few metres from the famous spherical sculpture by Arnaldo Pomodoro, this welcoming restaurant is now even more appealing following its recent refurbishment. Here, owner-chef Stefano Ciotti serves highly individualised cuisine which has its roots firmly in local traditions (the word “nostrano” means local or home-grown), combining modern techniques with regional flavours and ingredients from the Marche and Romagna on a menu that embraces fish and meat dishes alike. The excellent wine selection includes labels from all over Italy, including wines by the glass and even a few cocktails.

name: Lido 84
address: corso Zanardelli 196, Fasano del Garda, 25083, Italy
description: Once you’ve left your car in the car park, a slight descent leads to this small corner of paradise boasting one of the most beautiful views of Lake Garda. Run by two brothers (one in the kitchen, the other front of house), this elegant restaurant is striking for its many decorative details. The cuisine here is full of flavour, with generous portions that give the impression that every meal at Lido 84 is Sunday lunch – joyous, festive and served in a relaxed and informal atmosphere. There’s also plenty of contact with the chefs, who often bring the dishes to the tables themselves. For a special occasion, we recommend booking the table in the small stone building in the splendid garden, with its classic decor and breathtaking views.

name: Villa Maiella
address: via Sette Dolori 30, località Villa Maiella, Guardiagrele, 66016, Italy
description: Way back in 1966, Ginetta and Arcangelo probably never dreamed for a moment that their modest tavern would become so famous. Nowadays, the Tinari family comprises mother-and-son Angela and Arcangelo in the kitchen, and Peppino and Pascal front of house, all of whom offer guests a warm welcome in their restaurant on the edge of the Parco della Maiella. Here, you’ll enjoy authentic Abruzzo dishes with the occasional surprising and creative twist on three tasting menus (chosen when you make your booking). A good choice also for beer-lovers, with over a thousand different labels available including a wide selection by the glass.

name: Il Convivio Troiani
description: A long-established restaurant that was opened in the early 1990s by three brothers from the Marche: Angelo in the kitchen, and Giuseppe and Massimo front of house. Since then, this restaurant has become one of Rome’s leading restaurants thanks to its personalised cuisine with influences from Lazio and elsewhere in Italy, with more traditional dishes served alongside recipes reinterpreted with imagination, flair and the occasional bold twist. The excellent wine list boasts around 3 600 labels (wines and spirits), including fine vintages and a good selection of wines by the glass.

name: Berton
description: Situated in the heart of Porta Nuova, this restaurant has one wall made entirely of glass, allowing plenty of daylight to permeate its elegant, contemporary-style dining room which is perfectly in tune with the character of this new, futuristic district. The cuisine here continues to focus on just a few ingredients, so that it is deliberately simple in style without being minimalist. Creative and modern, the dishes are prepared with ingredients from all over Italy with no particular emphasis on any one region: the same is true of the excellent wine list. Professional, attentive and efficient service completes the picture.

name: Joia
description: This restaurant in one of Milan’s historic districts is home to the chef who first introduced the concept of natural, vegetarian cuisine to the world of Italian fine dining. Pietro Leemann is the man (and great philosopher) behind this “vegetarian restaurant” where the menu is 80% vegan and gluten free. This chef’s imaginative and dream-like dishes bear witness to the philosophical and spiritual transformation he has undergone over many years, with recipes that showcase the essence of their ingredients in colour, flavour, texture and presentation. The restaurant is minimalist and elegant in style, while its Joia Academy  aims to introduce participants to all aspects of the chef’s philosophy.

name: La Serra
address: via Marconi 169, località Belvedere Fornillo, Positano, 84017, Italy
description: Although you already get glimpses of the splendid views from the dining room, it is well worth waiting for fine weather to dine outdoors on the terrace at this restaurant in the Le Agave hotel, which boasts a truly breathtaking panorama of this magical coastline. In this delightful natural setting, chef Luigi Tramontano creates imaginative and beautifully presented Mediterranean dishes with his own individual touch, all prepared using top-quality, locally sourced meat and fish alongside vegetables which are often grown in the hotel’s own kitchen garden. Together with an excellent front-of-house team, Nicoletta Gargiulo takes care of guests’ wine choices. Passionate about wine for many years now, she has also developed her expertise thanks to different management roles held within the AIS (Italian Sommelier Association).

name: Cannavacciuolo Cafè & Bistrot
address: piazza Martiri della Libertà 1, Novara, 28100, Italy
description: The historic Coccia theatre now houses a café serving sweet treats and simple, delicious salads on its ground floor, while the mezzanine and first floor are home to an attractive, well-appointed bistro with – the jewel in the crown – a spacious balcony with tables and sofas for summer dining. The menu features modern Mediterranean dishes full of creative, contrasting flavours and prepared with careful attention to different cooking methods. Our inspectors highly recommended the Ad Occhi Chiusi menu – a surprise 7-course tasting menu designed by chef Vincenzo Manicone, a “gentle giant” with real culinary skills!

name: Acquerello
description: The word “modern” sums up the cuisine here, although more than one word is needed to do justice to this restaurant. Housed in an old courtyard typical of Lombardy, Acquerello focuses on flavour rather than colour, with dishes created by a chef who enjoys being in the kitchen away from the spotlight. Although the restaurant offers an à la carte, our inspectors recommend the tasting menu with its fine balance of delicate flavours and original combinations that offer a hint of Eastern influence and pleasing contrasts in cooking methods and temperatures. The wine selection reflects the owner’s tastes: a slight emphasis on sparkling wines from the other side of the Alps, but also something for everyone.

name: Borgo San Jacopo
address: borgo San Jacopo 62 r, Florence, 50125, Italy
description: Housed within the Hotel Lungarno, one of the most charming hotels in the city, this restaurant boasts the same elegant and exclusive style as the hotel. Chef Claudio Mengoni is at the helm here, having gained experience working in various Michelin-starred restaurants before returning home to Florence about three years ago. Here, he transforms carefully chosen Italian ingredients into refined fish, meat and vegetable dishes which respect the seasons and are beautifully presented. Sommelier Salvatore Biscotti is responsible for the excellent wine selection, which includes around a thousand different labels featuring renowned estates and small producers alike. It’s well worth booking one of the few romantic tables overlooking the Arno.

name: Locanda Don Serafino
description: Situated on the ring road which runs around Ibla, one of the most charming and picturesque historic districts in Sicily, this restaurant is as delightful as its surroundings. Despite being partly built into the rock, the dining room here is elegant rather than rustic and the service highly attentive, making this the perfect choice for a romantic, gourmet dinner. Vincenzo Candiano is an extraordinary chef who continues to experiment with new dishes, combining classic favourites with other more innovative recipes (still with a Sicilian influence) on his menu. There’s also a renowned wine list with some superb vertical tasting options, plus one guestroom on the premises and others within walking distance in the charming hotel of the same name.

name: Il Cappero
description: Il Cappero on the island of Vulcano is the perfect Mediterranean dream: a location nestling on Vulcanello’s promontory, perched over the sea, with a terrace boasting incomparable views of all the Aeolian islands, often with a blazing sunset in the background, plus a tasting menu (8, 10 or 12 courses) created by chef Giuseppe Biuso. The menus feature technical, modern dishes, all of which are enthusiastically described by the young, friendly staff, with alternating vegetable, fish and meat courses followed by delicious desserts made truly memorable by the talented young pastry chef. An interesting wine list completes the picture.

name: Porta di Basso
description: Considered to be the best restaurant in the Gargano for some years now, Porta di Basso continues to demonstrate how a serious and determined approach leads to constant progress, year after year, one step at a time, quietly and without fuss. Owner-chef Domenico Cilenti offers a choice of two tasting menus: one dedicated to classic dishes that tell the story of the restaurant and the other a “blind” menu that changes daily depending on the ingredients available in the market. Whichever you choose, the cuisine served is deliberately simple and precise, allowing the full flavours of Puglia’s vibrant produce to shine through. Each dish consists of just a few ingredients arranged in a colourful and elegant presentation on ad hoc porcelain. The restaurant also offers five guestrooms in carefully restored fishermen’s cottages with terraces perched over the sea, plus a cooking school in the village.

name: Viva Viviana Varese
description: The most popular tables at this restaurant on the second floor of the Eataly complex are the large fossil wood tables facing the open-view kitchen and the tables by the glass wall with views of the square. A desire to surprise combined with the chef’s culinary skill results in vibrant and original dishes which are always colourful and beautifully presented, with many ingredients sourced from the restaurant’s new kitchen garden. At lunchtime, choose between the simple à la carte or the gourmet tasting menu. An interesting selection of cocktails completes the picture.

name: Osteria Arbustico
description: Housed within the Royal Paestum hotel, Osteria Arbustico is one of the most interesting Michelin-starred restaurants in the province, if not the region. Cristian Torsiello’s cuisine is full of authentic character: although his dishes are simple and minimalist in appearance, this belies the careful preparation that the chef puts into every dish. His original cuisine is neither banal nor overly fussy but cleverly prepared to showcase the quality of his ingredients, which are presented and combined in occasionally unexpected ways. This simplicity begins with the menu, on which the names of the dishes are no more than a list of their ingredients, and yet the flavour on the palate is astonishing. The elegant dining room echoes the simple character of the cuisine with its understated decor.

name: Giglio
description: Housed in a beautiful 18C palazzo, Giglio was founded in 1979 and is now run by three young men who took over just a few years ago. These three friends form a real team, who have come together to inject new life into the restaurant which stands on one of the many squares in Lucca’s charming historic centre. In fine weather, guests can enjoy the lively summer atmosphere outdoors, while those who prefer a quieter ambience can book a table in the more austere and elegant dining room indoors. Modern cuisine with a very Italian feel, combined with French techniques and the occasional use of international ingredients.

name: Atman a Villa Rospigliosi
address: via Borghetto 1, località Spicchio, Lamporecchio, 51035, Italy
description: You climb up into the hills, along winding roads and past olive groves, to the spectacular 17C Villa Rospigliosi (designed by Bernini) which boasts breathtaking views. From here, you’re accompanied through various period-style rooms to the restaurant, where another surprise awaits: a modern, designer-style dining room with a few tables facing the stage-like open-view kitchen. Here, chef Marco Cahssai (whose grandfather emigrated to Italy from Eritrea) creates a single extensive tasting menu which offers plenty of flexibility, allowing guests to choose the number of courses they want or even to order the exact dishes that appeal to them, as if ordering à la carte. This talented chef’s imagination and creativity allows him to combine regional ingredients with surprising touches from further afield. The wine list is excellent, overseen by a new sommelier who – just like his predecessor – suggests superb wine pairings.

name: Franco Mare
address: via lungomare Roma 41, Marina di Pietrasanta, 55044, Italy
description: This typical, elegant Versilian beach club with an open-plan feel extending from the car park to the beach serves top-quality cuisine to guests. Its facilities include an entrance lounge, stylish dining room full of character, a swimming pool and a second lounge space. The menu is simpler at lunchtime, except during the low season when you can request the gourmet menu (normally only served in the evenings) when booking. Fish and seafood take pride of place on the menu, with classic dishes reinterpreted with a modern twist by a chef who takes particular care with presentation.

name: Andreina
description: Sixty years after this restaurant was opened by his grandmother Andreina, Errico Recanati continues to add his own distinctive mark to the family business. Following the complete renovation of the farmhouse interior, the dining rooms are even more elegant and welcoming than before. Here, the excellent staff offer attentive and discreet service, while the cuisine, rooted in local traditions, focuses especially on game and grilled dishes. The only features that have survived in the dining room are the grill and the fireplace! Recanati’s distinctive style makes full use of fire, charcoal embers and the afore-mentioned grill and spit: he is a real expert in the latter, enabling delightful grilled flavours and aromas to make their way into most of his dishes, which he often personalises by adding fruit and vegetables from his own garden. All of this contributes to what the chef himself describes as his “neo-rural” style of cuisine, which is beautifully illuminated by new lamps arranged on the tables with the precision of a stage set.

name: essência
description: Portuguese chef-owner Tiago and his Hungarian wife Éva have created a warmly run and deliciously different restaurant in the heart of the city. A small, bright front room with arched windows leads past the prized tables by the open kitchen to a more intimate room where patches of blue and white tiling remind you of Tiago’s heritage. Choose either the Portuguese or the Hungarian menu, or a tasting menu which combines the two – literally the best of both worlds. Dishes are poised and elegant, and Tiago has a deft touch when it comes to seasoning and balance.

name: Babel
description: Babel represents the perfect blend of tradition and modernity. Its walls still show marks from the 1838 Great Flood of Pest, yet it’s also a chic, stylish place thanks to passionate owner Hubert and interior designer Annamaria Dekany. Cooking follows in a similar vein: the multi-course tasting menu comprises refined, delicate modern dishes with subtle, carefully balanced flavours, which at the same time exhibit references to their Hungarian heritage.

name: Borkonyha Winekitchen
description: This unassuming-looking restaurant sits not far from the Basilica, and while its traditional dining room may not promise all that much, to pass it by would be a mistake. The kitchen here sources top-class ingredients, treats them with the utmost respect and allows them to shine. Subtle Hungarian influences run throughout dishes which are well-conceived and skilfully executed, and have a notable intensity of flavour. Wines are key here too: they offer 100 labels, including around a quarter by the glass.

name: Costes
description: Elegance and sophistication lead the way at Costes, from the smart décor to the well-orchestrated service. Ask for a seat to the front of the main room for a feeling of space, then enjoy the eager anticipation as the sommelier presents an exceptional, mostly Hungarian wine selection. The modern six-course tasting menu skilfully combines flavours from around the globe to create memorable dishes which not only look stunning with their bright colours and artistic style, but are packed with vibrant, complementary flavours.

name: Salt
description: Within a boutique hotel sits this small, sophisticated restaurant, whose open kitchen forms an integral part of the stylishly lit room. Shelves are full of jars containing colourfully preserved foraged fruits, vegetables and herbs, and the butter, lardo and Mangalitsa ham are all produced in-house. The surprise set menu is made up of intricate, exquisitely constructed dishes – many of which are updated versions of classic Hungarian recipes – and tables all face the wooden-clad ‘pass’, where the chefs assemble the dishes with skill and dexterity.

name: Rumour
description: After travelling the world, Chef Jenő returned home to open this unique restaurant. Located in the heart of the city, it comes with concrete walls, mirrors and a 21-seater counter which wraps around a large open kitchen; red leather stools and placemats provide colour, and a trendy soundtrack adds to the vibe. The creative set menu showcases flavours from Jenő’s travels via a series of refined, sophisticated dishes which culminate in two superb desserts. His passion and expertise are slowly revealed as he presents and explains each course.

A colourful city centre townhouse with a striking glass cube extension plays host to this series of intimate dining rooms. Like the building itself, the philosophy they follow here is one of constant evolution; the kitchen likes to spark curiosity and creativity, so, while the assured, skilful cooking has a Hungarian heart and honest flavours, it is also modern, interesting and playful. They offer two tasting menus: go for ‘The Way We See The World’ – and choose the Hungarian wine parings to match. Upstairs, luxuriously appointed bedrooms await.

name: Kissa Tanto
address: 263 E. Pender St., Vancouver, V6A 1T8, Canada
description: Inspired by the jazz cafes of 1960s Tokyo, Kissa Tanto seduces with a moody vibe complete with white mosaic floors, antique Japanese panels and steely colored walls loaded with artwork and photos. If the stack of vinyl records by the bar didn't offer enough of a hint, the terrific music certainly will. There is a definitive laidback vibe here, but the ambitious kitchen pulls no punches with its mingling of Japanese and Italian cuisine. The region's bounty is on full display in dishes such as roasted and fried celeriac served with  onion and mushroom dashi. The cultural collision is best seen in dishes like the Tajarin, hand-cut pasta dressed with butter, miso-cured egg yolk and parmesan. Tiramisu takes an Eastern turn with an ethereal, plum-wine soaked tofu-filling.

name: Published on Main
description: Timing is everything, but Chef Gus Stieffenhofer-Brandson and his team have a preternatural ability for sensing when produce is at its peak. Whether showcasing it on the plate or pickling and preserving it (those jars even double as decor), they're sourcing and foraging from local farms and forests.The contemporary fare bears the chef's distinct imprimatur. This is food that is at once familiar and surprising. A small dish of asparagus with brown butter crouton and a sauce gribiche is the very essence of spring, while an artful bowl with a pinwheel of side-striped prawns, refreshing apple and cucumber and a cool touch of horseradish delivers a sweet-tart, one-two punch. The roasted halibut's lush and buttery "broth" is unlike anything you anticipated.

name: Barbara
address: 305 E. Pender St., Vancouver, V6A 0J3, Canada
description: Chef Patrick Hennessy spent time at many top spots, including Eleven Madison Park in New York, but he is clearly at home at Barbara. The kitchen feels like a stage, with guests perched at the L-shaped bar watching with bated breath as he performs culinary magic. Should you wonder where each item hails from, Chef Hennessy is happy to oblige (hint: it's local and sustainable), but most are focused on the here and now thanks to his refined techniques and sensational flavors. Oysters with local Northern Divine caviar are impeccable; crisply fried slices of Japanese eggplant with local honey and chimichurri are delightful. Simple-sounding broccolini is cooked to precise tenderness, then plated with perfectly toasted almond romesco sauce for a sensational bite.

name: Masayoshi
description: Chef Masayoshi Baba brings Japan's luxurious, jewel-box sushi counters to Vancouver with this eponymous restaurant. The best seats are always at the counter, and guests seated there are in for a treat as the chef ceremoniously crafts each course. Fret not if you're seated at one of the four tables though, as the meal will be equally enjoyable. Chef Baba lets British Columbia's bounty guide this omakase, spotlighting locally sourced fish in his Edomae-style nigiri. But first, a chilled dish of uni, junsai, mountain yam, crab and tomato dashi gel starts things off. Supple sea bass folded over snappy wakame; steamed monkfish in a tart broth; and abalone rendered soft as pudding—it's one hit after the next.

name: iDen & QuanJuDe Beijing Duck House
description: It has a pedigree that traces back to an original location in Beijing from 1864, but the latest outpost in Vancouver proves that this legacy hasn't lost any of its luster. Indeed, the gold-accented dining room is a feast for the eyes, blending classic opulence with strikingly modern design.They are best known for their superlatively crispy and juicy duck. Delicious as the signature fowl may be, there is plenty more: a bevy of other delicacies are on offer, including bird's nest, sea cucumber and even a whole king crab if you're up for a splurge. It's not all razzle-dazzle, though. The cooking displays a deft hand with ingredients of all stripes from simple stir-fried mustard greens with garlic to a broth of abalone and matsutake.

name: Burdock & Co
description: This Mount Pleasant charmer straddles a corner of Main Street in an area rich with top spots, but Burdock & Co stands out with its rustic appeal and Chef Andrea Carlson's farm-to-table cooking. The concise menu highlights the best of the season. First, grilled sourdough, herb-flavored gougère and nori cornbread with aged sake kasu butter prove that this is not your average bread basket. Then, miniature Hazelmere radishes roasted with house-made shio koji deliver unexpected glee. Morels stuffed with halibut mousse resting beside delicate gnocchi in a green garlic sauce embody the fleeting beauty of spring. Finally, the deconstructed chocolate soufflé with miso caramel and smoked mascarpone is a decadent delight.

name: St. Lawrence
description: There is so much to love about St. Lawrence with its textured walls, mosaic-tiled floor, antiques and open kitchen. A hit ever since opening, this charming Québécois bistro shares a true sense of place—it's even named for the region's mighty river. Sit close enough to Chef/owner Jean-Christophe Poirier's kitchen to experience the heady aromas of his rustic and hearty French-Canadian cooking. Begin with oreilles de crisse, a plate overflowing with crispy pork ears tossed in maple syrup and Montreal spices. Here, split pea soup takes on next-level flavor thanks to the addition of smoked bacon and foie gras. Finally, tarte au sucre is buttery and flaky, but it's that sweet maple syrup, vanilla and brown sugar filling that wins your heart.

name: AnnaLena
description: Don't be fooled by AnnaLena's unassuming atmosphere, as dining here is a polished experience from top to bottom. Beginning with the graceful service and carrying through to the impeccably prepared dishes, this is a restaurant that aims to impress—sans the fuss.Begin with an expertly prepared cocktail or opt for their wine pairings, which display unusual care and thoughtfulness. The seasonally inspired tasting menu highlights exceptional ingredients prepared with an outward simplicity that belies technical precision. The cooking employs pitch-perfect flavor combinations lifted with modern touches, like a delicate olive-oil-poached Chinook king salmon paired with crunchy dill-marinated kohlrabi and an airy hollandaise enhanced with the subtle sweetness of koji.

name: Song Yun Ze
address: No. 8, Block 2, Jade Lane, Crland Plaza, 8 Liuli Road, Chengdu, China Mainland
description: Zhang Songyun is a legendary Sichuanese chef and his protégés opened this restaurant in a quaint courtyard house in his honour. There is no main dining room and no à la carte menu – all diners must reserve a room and have their set menu tailored in advance. A typical set includes over 20 expertly crafted courses, all made with top notch ingredients and underpinned by traditional techniques. Early reservations are recommended.

name: Fang Xiang Jing
address: No. 1, Courtyard 5, China Railway Ludao Art City, 16 Majia Garden Road, Chengdu, China Mainland
description: Sitting nicely in a Japanese stone garden, this three-storey restaurant offers private rooms only. The kitchen team re-creates old-time Sichuanese recipes as faithfully as possible, covering classics like fuqi feipian, mapo tofu, and snowflake minced chicken. Cabbage in chicken consommé takes hours to prepare, boasting a rich, crystal clear broth with exceptional depth. Only set menus of different prices are served.

name: Silver Pot
address: No. 532, 5F, M6, ICP Office Building, 300 Jiaozi Avenue, Chengdu, China Mainland
description: The owner’s collection of souvenirs from her trips around the world gives this spacious dining room an endearing quirkiness. Her wanderlust also translates into her quest for quality seafood and other ingredients from around the globe, to be cooked in an authentic Sichuanese style. Roast pigeon smoked with Sichuan pepper leaves is simply unmissable. Cold appetisers like lamp-shadow sliced grass carp are also well made.

name: Chengdu Restaurant
address: 2F, North Building, Shangshan International, No. 46-1, Section 4, Renmin South Road, Chengdu, China Mainland
description: The hanging lamps are a nod to the Golden Sun Bird, an ancient artefact unearthed in Chengdu, while the back-lit, perforated brass wall reminds one of basket weaving. The head chef from Guangdong built the menu on traditional Cantonese lines but spices it up with Sichuanese touches. Fried 18-day pigeon boasts succulent flesh and crispy skin. The signature misua soup uses a rich fish-pork broth, topped with dried shrimps, salted pork and shredded omelette.

name: Fu Rong Huang
description: The restaurant prioritises privacy, with its tables separated by wood slat dividers. The experienced kitchen team specialises in traditional Sichuan dishes, many of which are painstaking to prepare, such as the signatures snowflake minced chicken and scrambled egg white with fish tripe. Round it off with the quintessential Sichuan sweet twice-cooked shaobai – pork belly slices layered with red bean paste over glutinous rice.

name: Ma's Kitchen
address: 1 East Kangshi Street, Chengdu, China Mainland
description: This hugely popular shop in the bustling Taikoo Li area started out as a stall in Weishan in 1923. A far cry from its humble beginnings, this only branch of the chain in Chengdu features vintage hipster decoration and Sichuan classics on the menu. Popular items include kung pao prawns and eggplant, duck blood curd with pork offal and sliced eel, dan dan noodles, and ice jelly dessert. Expect to see a queue form the moment it opens.

name: Mi Xun Teahouse
address: The Temple House, 81 Bitieshi Street, Chengdu, 610021, China Mainland
description: Nestled in a quiet hotel next to Daci Temple, this restaurant is an oasis of calm amid the bustling Taikoo-li shopping hub. The courtyard house imparts historical charm, while the open kitchen creates an airy feel. Hand-picked local ingredients are used to create light, refined and inspired vegetarian dishes, such as vegan mapo tofu with chanterelles, and spicy hot pot. For afternoon tea, pick an artisan cake and pair it with your choice of Chinese tea.

name: Chaimen Hui
address: 2F, China Overseas Uni Elite, 289 Jiaozi Avenue, Chengdu, China Mainland
description: A premium brand of the chain, Chaimen Hui goes for an understated luxe feel in and out. Creative Sichuanese dominates the menu, using top-notch, seasonal ingredients from around the world; many dishes can be ordered in individual portions. Mapo tofu rice is jazzed up by diced Angus beef, while kung pao grain-fed beef short ribs with dried tangerine peel tastes tangy and sweet. Consider booking one of the private rooms for a fee.

name: Young Art · Yong Ya He Xian (Tongzilin East Road)
address: 1-1 Tongzilin East Road, Chengdu, China Mainland
description: As the chain’s flagship, this restaurant showcases live river fish such as long snout catfish, cavefish, and yellow head catfish cooked in Sichuanese style or in hot pots; the owner even acquired a fish farm to ensure their quality. The signature duo hot pot broth features a spicy base made with chicken, pork bones, chillies and pickles, and a tangy tomato base of Xinjiangese tomatoes. House-pickled bamboo shoots from Mount Tianmu are a must.

name: Xu's Cuisine
address: No. 1, Block 8, Building & Greenwich Plaza, 1 Wangjiang Road, Chengdu, China Mainland
description: This was the first restaurant of the chain and has been in business for over a decade. The main dining room is traditionally furnished and there are a further 16 private rooms spread across three storeys. The menu is categorised by style, such as bean paste based and home-style dishes. Start the meal with deep-fried braided dough – a crispy light snack – followed by the made-to-order signature ji douhua in a clear broth that takes 2 days to make.

name: Denis Martin
description: Experimental and playful: such is the ethos of Denis Martin. A genuine wizard in the realm of molecular cuisine (cryonics in particular) without ever falling into the trap of gimmicky, the chef adds a new spin to Swiss family favourites with dishes such as “Fribourg concrete”, “sii de Saviese” (an iconic local dessert), cryogenic black pudding or langoustine… Each bite surprises, disconcerts, amazes, delights…, all of which in a tastefully and voluntarily unshowy interior, to ensure that the food enjoys the full limelight.

name: Table de Mary
description: Maryline and Loïc Nozahic have been at the helm of this house, which idyllically overlooks Lake Neuchâtel just a few minutes from Yverdon-les-Bains, since 2007. Rather than haphazardly creative, the food is legible, straightforward and carefully executed with a strong bias on aromas and seasonal produce. Examples include pan-fried scallops, black pudding and warm potato espuma; smoked arctic char with green peas and lemon thyme flavoured kefir or mullet with black garlic, courgettes and Beluga lentils. When the weather is fine, the flower-decked, tree-lined patio attracts diners like bees to honey and commands a fantastic view over the Jura mountains and countryside. Prices that make sense. Well done, Mary!

name: the K by mauro colagreco
description: The fine dining restaurant in the distinguished Kulm Hotel St Moritz is only open to guests during the winter season. This is a great pity, for seated here at exquisitely set tables under a beautiful white vaulted ceiling you can indulge in some first-class food, brought to you by an extremely friendly and professional service team. It goes without saying that one would like to be able to sample this multifaceted, perfectly balanced and always surprising cuisine more often, delivered as it is under the supervision of Argentinean culinary grandmaster Mauro Colagreco, but without having to travel all the way to his three-star restaurant in Menton on the Côte d'Azur. It's best to opt for the surprise menu – but you can also order à la carte. Reservations are a must!

name: Lucide
description: The central location on the first floor of the Lucerne Culture and Congress couldn't be better – not least because of the view of the lake and the city. The interior is stylish and chic with an open kitchen. A friendly front-of-house team serves you dishes that are pleasingly pared down and based on first-rate produce. In the evening there are two set menus, one of which is vegetarian. At lunchtime, you can order à la carte. Excellent wine selection.

name: Ackermannshof
description: Housed in a lovingly restored and converted printing house that dates back centuries, this restaurant is run by a well-coordinated team that many guests will be familiar with from Osteria TRE in Bubendorf – chef Flavio Fermi and maître d' Roland Tisch. Seated in the extremely chic and tastefully decorated interior, you can look forward to their fine, thoroughly Italian take on Mediterranean cuisine; made with a wealth of Swiss ingredients, it is served as a set menu. This is accompanied by on-point wine pairings or your own choice from the extensive wine list, which includes a nice selection of champagnes. The stylish bar area is the perfect spot for a nightcap. There is also a lovely terrace.

name: Les Montagnards - Le Sommet
description: At the small fine dining restaurant of the hotel Les Montagnards, you can enjoy a modern set menu that hits the mark without any need for contrivance, thanks to top-notch ingredients and precise know-how. The service is competent and the wine recommendations spot on. The chic interior, all warm wood panelling and clean lines, affords lovely views from the seats near the windows.

name: Des Trois Tours
description: In this 19C patrician house near the centre of Fribourg, diners can savour a harmonious set menu comprising five to seven courses. Stripped back to home in on the essentials, the dishes are also pleasing to the eye. The food is served in a stylish, refined and modern atmosphere, and the service is professional. The interesting wine list focuses on Switzerland and France.

name: Sihlhalde
description: The location is somewhat rural, with the drive there taking you down a small road that leads past green pastures and grazing cows... But the journey to this idyllic little hamlet is well worth it, for Gregor Smolinsky has a special talent: his ability to strip things down to the bare essentials. The focus is squarely on the produce. His style of cooking is classic, clear-cut and free of unnecessary frills; nothing distracts from the superior quality of the ingredients. Only a few components are ever used, and they are always brimming with intense flavours. You should definitely try his brasato ravioli or his soufflé – they almost have cult status! It's no wonder that the cosy restaurant in this charming historical farmhouse (which was actually once his parents' farm) is often fully booked.

name: Bel Etage
description: Lovely old parquet flooring, beautiful double doors and high ceilings with crystal chandeliers, as well as decorative art on the walls... Here on the first floor of Der Teufelhof hotel, the stylish salons of the Bel Etage blend harmoniously into the historical setting. In the kitchen, the focus is on the classics. Since Michael Baader opened the place in 1989, he has maintained impeccably high standards. He steers clear of culinary fads; instead, the chef at the helm wins diners over with straightforward, produce-led dishes full of expression and flavour. The front-of-house team is friendly and professional, providing savvy wine recommendations – the fabulous list is very well put together. In good weather, make a beeline for the pretty terrace and grab a table under the sun awning in the hotel's garden.

name: Il Lago
description: The iconic Four Seasons hotel, Geneva’s oldest luxury hotel (1834), dripping with pilasters and frescoes, is the setting of Il Lago, or Lake Geneva’s classy remake of the dolce vita.
