Italian chef Massimiliano Sena, whose star-studded CV features a dazzling line-up of world-class establishments, curates high-flying Italian cuisine, with the odd Mediterranean accent, rich in aromas, subtlety and delicacy. The quintessence of fine dining.

name: La Table d'Adrien
description: This smart stylish chalet overlooking Verbier serves tasty, inventive Italian cuisine in a cosily appointed elegant hotel. Chef Sebastiano Lombardi, who hails from Puglia, pays particularly attention to the quality of the noble ingredients, which he crafts into superlative dishes. A treat for the eye and the tastebuds, each dish reveals consummate precision, high-flying creativity and spot-on flavours. Insightful wine-food pairings, dutiful service and a knock-out view add the final flourish to this snug, yet swish chalet in the mountains.

name: Brasserie Uno
description: A bustling little restaurant of the sort you could easily expect to find in Berlin or New York. The tables are set close together, in a pleasingly laid-back atmosphere. You can peek into the open kitchen, where the two chefs prepare a surprise multi-course tasting menu. They cook with regional ingredients, attach great importance to seasonal references and are mindful of the origin of the produce they select. The dishes are cleverly devised and their flavours and aromas are convincing. Vegetarian and vegan tasting menus are also available by advance booking. N.B. There is no À la carte menu and no children's menu.

name: L'Atelier Robuchon
description: The gourmet restaurant of the luxurious Woodward hotel on the banks of Lake Geneva is the epitome of swanky. Dark wood fixtures and crimson set the scene in the cosy interior, flanked by an open kitchen. The counter seats offer a fine view of the kitchen and elsewhere diners are seated at high tables. Choice of a menu (also vegetarian) and à la carte dishes. Delightful, dedicated staff.

name: The Japanese by The Chedi at Gütsch
description: For those who wish to enjoy Japanese cuisine high up in an Alpine setting, this restaurant, located 2 344 m above sea level is the perfect choice – a table on the gorgeous terrace is a must! Where bold architecture meets beautiful scenery and spectacular views, they offer an "Omakase Kaiseki menu" that combines local produce (including their own Wagyu beef) with Japanese culinary techniques. Their sushi and sashimi selection is also excellent. The service is friendly and attentive, and the setting is minimalist yet warm and inviting. The open kitchen is an eye-catcher. A lunchtime favourite is their "Shidashi Bento". There is also a children's menu.

name: La Table du Lausanne Palace
address: Rue du Grand Chêne 7, Lausanne, 1002, Switzerland
description: This lavish, long-standing luxury restaurant of Lausanne is now the lair of a high-profile couple, Franck Pelux and Sarah Benahmed (united in work and in life) from Strasbourg. Examples of the chef’s gutsy, expressive cuisine include lightly seared langoustine in delicate Asian spices with mango; wild venison roasted in the hearth, melt-in-the-mouth beetroot, pepper sauce; soufflé of prestige dark chocolate, Tonka bean ice cream. The service, as smooth as a silky béarnaise sauce, is both charming and casual, which further highlights the luxurious setting and drop-dead lake view.

name: La Chaumière by Serge Labrosse
address: Chemin de la Fondelle 16, Troinex, 1256, Switzerland
description: Feel like a breath of fresh air and getting out of the town centre? This Cottage by Serge Labrosse (who also gives cookery lessons in Geneva) is just the ticket. An elegant, contemporary vibe sets the scene for artfully presented dishes based on painstakingly selected ingredients by a chef who has knocked around a bit…, without forgetting the pretty terrace in fine weather and very convenient private car park. Whether you prefer traditional fare or more modern creations, there is something for everyone.

name: The Japanese Restaurant
description: A Japanese enclave in the heart of Europe... This restaurant belonging to luxury hotel The Chedi is located at an altitude of almost 1 500m and boasts a chic interior that brings together Asian minimalist design and high-end furnishings. Diners come to indulge in the flavoursome, produce-led cuisine in the form of the modern Kaiseki-Kappo set menu. There are around 20 dishes to choose from, including a few made with Wagyu beef bred in the valley. To round off the experience, you can marvel at the dexterity of the sushi masters at work at the sushi bar!

name: Osteria TRE
description: For years, Osteria TRE has been a renowned address, known and appreciated for its cuisine rooted in Italian culinary tradition. They offer a modern take on "cucina italiana", put together by a dedicated kitchen team who are adept at bringing out the best in fresh, select produce. You can look forward to the extensive wine list that accompanies the fantastic set menu. The wine rack takes centre stage in this upscale, stylish restaurant adjoining the Bad Bubendorf hotel.

name: Panorama - Cayenne
description: This establishment has been run by the Fuchs family for 35 years, and these days, it is Rolf and Manuela Fuchs who are in charge. The modern, elegant restaurant atop Hartlisberg boasts not only a chic atmosphere but also a truly magnificent view of Thun and the mountains – a spot on the terrace is a must! The chef-patron's cuisine is no less of a draw. It is modern, yet clearly classical in its foundations, making for dishes that are robust and expressive. As a matter of course, the ingredients are sourced locally as possible. There is a decent wine selection, and astute recommendations come courtesy of the friendly, professional waitstaff.

name: Steinhalle
description: This hotspot of the capital's fine dining scene is undoubtedly a new take on high-end gastronomy! "Casual dining" is the name of the game here. In the evening, diners take their seats in a lively bistro setting to sample an exceedingly interesting and creative surprise menu that is constantly exploring different themes, countries and regions. This is where chef-patron Markus Arnold draws inspiration from his travels. To complete the picture, this undisputedly cool establishment boasts a fine historical interior complete with high ceilings, a gallery and large arched windows – the open kitchen is the real attraction. The menu is completely different at lunchtime, when the concept is called "easy lunch".

name: Segreto
description: You may be surprised to discover such a fine place on company premises, but you will immediately be transported to the Mediterranean. You can enjoy an aperitif in the relaxed lounge looking out over the pretty garden. In keeping with the setting, Martin Benninger cooks up traditional Mediterranean cuisine, which he enhances with Asian touches. The interior is modern and elegant – in summer, with its glass front open, the conservatory almost feels like a terrace. The attentive and experienced front-of-house team also provide excellent wine recommendations, and the digital wine list is really well curated. Al Covo is a charming alternative – for pizza, pasta etc (Fri-Sun evenings).

name: Maison Manesse
description: A wonderfully down-to-earth restaurant! It enjoys a somewhat inconspicuous location, at a remove from the city centre, and its pared-down, unpretentious decor is almost pub-like, a little on the rustic side, but also modern – "vintage" probably sums it up best. The service is relaxed but well drilled. The "Menu Surprise" comes in a vegetarian, vegan or "I-eat-everything" version. There is also a small selection of à la carte dishes. The kitchen team uses top-notch ingredients to cook up dishes brimming with original ideas – creative, but not outlandish. A great example is the red cabbage in a salt crust, served with Jerusalem artichoke, morel and apple. As well as fine wines, they have some interesting alcohol-free alternatives. Reduced lunchtime menu.

name: Traube
description: Since chef-patron Arno Sgier took over the reins in 1993, this establishment in the little town of Trimbach has developed into a real gem of the fine dining scene. Traube is a really lovely place to be, with its chic and modern interior done out with high-quality furnishings, and its well-trained front-of-house team attending to your every need. Then there is Arno Sgier's technically ambitious cuisine. His dishes give a modern twist to classic fare – he enjoys putting his own spin on traditional recipes. Those who like a glass of good wine or two to go with a first-class meal are in for a treat, because the wine list really does have many treasures in store, especially in the bottles section. In the evening, you can choose between the "Traube" set menu and a set menu of appetisers. At midday there is the three-course lunch menu.

name: Seerestaurant Belvédère
description: Since Fabian Inderbitzin and Yvonne Chapuis opened this modern and elegant establishment in 2011, it has gone down a treat with diners. The fantastic view of Lake Lucerne alone makes the visit worthwhile – head out to the wonderful terrace to make the most of it! Happily, you don't have to miss out if you're seated inside either – thanks to the floor-to-ceiling windows. Fabian Inderbitzin's cuisine focuses on the region and takes the outstanding quality of the produce as its starting point. This gives rise to dishes brimming with sophisticated touches and original ideas. The service is professional, friendly and attentive. Good to know: there are five spaces available at the jetty.

name: META
description: Situated near the lakefront with stunning views visible through its picture windows, Meta is a friendly restaurant with an informal atmosphere and an attractive modern and minimalist decor. A partially open kitchen allows guests to watch the excellent chef at work as he prepares gourmet Mediterranean cuisine with the occasional local influence and impeccable technique, while the informal yet professional service gives the impression of a private residence. In fine weather, the attractive outdoor dining space is an appealing option.

name: LA CHAVALLERA in der Krone - Säumerei am Inn
description: The pretty Swiss pine dining rooms range from traditional to modern minimalist. What better to accompany this regional Gemütlichkeit than flavoursome Swiss specialities such as home-made capuns (stuffed chard leaves), as well as fish and meat from the Swiss-pine smoker?

name: Epoca by Tristan Brandt
description: Tristan Brandt (also known from the restaurant OPUS V in Mannheim) is in charge of the fine dining restaurant at the Waldhaus Flims hotel, which occupies a stunning location above the village. Chef Niklas Oberhofer can be seen at work in the visible kitchen, where he produces modern cuisine by building Asian influences into classic French foundations – precise craftsmanship, finesse and interesting ideas. There is a set menu composed of four to six courses, as well as a small à la carte selection. The interior is stylishly modern and pleasingly lively but by no means distracting, and the large floor-to-ceiling windows command a lovely view. Fun fact: the crystals on the tables come from the chef's personal collection.

name: tobias buholzer
description: Temporarily closed. This 400-year-old timber-framed house is full of atmosphere! The fine dining restaurant on the first floor combines rustic charm with sophistication in its tasteful interior – the warm wood and tiled stove make for a cosy ambience. The concept proposed by owner Tobias Buholzer is something special: a set menu of vegetarian canapés. And it goes down very well. You also have the option of ordering fish and meat dishes on top of that – here, too, you can be sure of quality, as in the flank steak of Holzen beef, for example. There is a fine selection of wines – the "Sipping" menu gives you the opportunity to pair wines with each course. Their range of non-alcoholic pairings is also impressive. If you like things a little more rustic, there is also the charming Taverna Rosa on the lower ground floor.

name: Löwen - Apriori
description: You can feel the dedication of hosts Rita and Domenico Miggiano-Köferli, who have been running this lovely historical inn since 2000. As well as tasteful, individually decorated rooms and the Gaststube, Löwen is also home to Apriori, a fine dining restaurant that has held a Michelin star since 2018. The modern and elegant interior is characterised by warm dark tones, designer lamps and exquisitely laid tables. Chef-patron Domenico Miggiano puts his heart and soul into his cooking. His style: classic with Mediterranean touches. There is a gourmet set menu in the evening and the popular business lunch at midday. The wine list is beautifully put together and features a brief profile of each winemaker. Your charming and accomplished front-of-house team is supervised by the lady of the house.

name: Tsé Fung
description: Born in Shenzhen, Frank Xu is the third generation of a family of chefs and Cantonese and Chinese culinary arts have found a matchless ambassador in this veteran chef. His authentic, flavourful creations are meticulously curated using top-notch ingredients and the memory of his dimsum of langoustine, fillet of seabass with ginger or Peking duck with Sichuan aubergine will linger with you long after your meal… The interior sports a classy, exotic slant with a black, red and gold colour scheme, while bay windows command a view of the pool and the lake.

name: La Riva
description: If dining out on the terrace isn't an option, you should opt for one of the tables next to the huge front windows, so you can enjoy the view of the Heidsee and the mountains as you sample Dominique Schrotter's ambitious classic-cum-modern set menu, which is also available in a vegetarian version. Hailing from a family of restaurateurs, he spent some years teaching and travelling, which led him to Bangkok, among other places. Consequently, he has developed a real soft spot for East-Asian cuisine, hence the regular "Sushi Festivals". The dedicated service staff are also able to provide savvy wine recommendations.

name: Aux Trois Amis
description: A narrow road leads up to this wonderful restaurant surrounded by vineyards and boasting a pleasantly shaded terrace overlooking Lake Biel – dining al fresco here is an absolute joy! Excellent service comes courtesy of a charming front-of-house team headed up by the lady of the house. Diners are treated to a "menu surprise" featuring modern dishes that are sophisticated and delicious. Alternatively, you can order à la carte. Tip: it's best to park in their own car park and walk the last few metres.

name: Le Berceau des Sens
description: The kitchen of this cradle (‘berceau’) of fine dining that is part of Lausanne’s iconic Hotel School is in the competent hands of a pedigree chef, Cédric Bourassin. In charge of a crack white-jacketed brigade, including Meilleurs Ouvriers de France and faculty members, together with students themselves, Cédric orchestrates a score whose coherent flavours are far from academic! Perfectly poised between classicism and modernity with just the right balance of technique, each dish is heroically wondrous and hunger obliterating. For example, squid stuffed with chorizo, fillet of sole with nori seaweed, without forgetting the exquisitely entitled “Honey Delight” dessert which reveals an explosion of citrus fruits – the ingredients are outstanding. Each bite is bliss from start to finish, further enhanced by the elegant dining room overlooking a jaw-dropping mountainscape. Hat’s off!

name: Jägerhof
description: Jägerhof is an establishment steeped in culinary history! Since 2016, former sous-chef Agron Lleshi has been at the helm, delivering modern seasonal cuisine that seeks inspiration in the local region and abroad. The chef's mother makes the fresh bread rolls. At lunchtime, the food is somewhat simpler. When you enter the elegant restaurant, take a peek into the kitchen – this is also where the "Küchentisch" (Kitchen Table) is located, which diners can book. An attentive service team does sterling work, and impressive wine advice is also dispensed. A large selection of home-made chocolates is served with coffee.

name: Vivanda
description: Vivanda hits all the right notes: as well as its views of the national park and the garden, it boasts a chic interior comprising modern design and warm wood. Indeed, the Cadonau family has its own woodworking shop – hence the hotel's name: "IN LAIN", which means "made of wood". The affinity for the region makes itself felt in the decor as much as it does in the cuisine, which is based on local produce and presented in the form of a modern surprise tasting menu. Chef-patron Dario Cadonau is intent on implementing his own unique style here, showcasing excellent ingredients in unusual combinations. There's a wonderful assortment of cheeses – head to the ripening cellar yourself to make your choice! The attentive and charming service is second to none.

name: Le Café Suisse
description: This former village café has morphed into a vibrant, friendly eatery that reflects the colourful, tongue-in-cheek personality of its youthful and exuberant chef, Marie Robert. Marie conjures up uninhibited, creative dishes washed down with excellent local wines. At the head of a women-only kitchen brigade, she has a flair for spontaneously showcasing seasonal ingredients. Examples include Red Label Scottish salmon with Aquitaine caviar and pearls of vodka or succulent snails in a butter, garlic and parsley sauce served with pan-fried frog’s legs and a foamy purée of sweet garlic. Her surprise menu is a hit with the locals, which is always a guarantee of quality!

name: Capri
description: Sophisticated classic Italian food is not only available at the Capri Palace on Capri, because in winter the staff from this Italian ristorante decamp to Zermatt. On the fourth floor of Le Petit Cervin (adjoining the Mont Cervin Palace), the kitchen team brings flavour, punch and aromas to your plate. The choice ingredients are top-notch. As for the atmosphere, in an elegant interior, premium materials and warm, light-toned wood combine to create a pleasant and stylish feel to go with the attentive, professional and very slick service. Tip: Be sure to take in the view from the tables by the window!

name: Alpine Gourmet Prato Borni
description: You will find this elegant gourmet restaurant in the magnificent Grand Hotel Zermatterhof, located in the centre of town. The classical setting done out with fine wood panelling affords a splendid view of the church. Choose between two appealing set menus: "Heimat" ("Home") and "Fernweh" ("Wanderlust"). One seeks inspiration in the region while the other looks to foreign climes. Chef Heinz Rufibach, who previously worked in this kitchen years ago, incorporates interesting ideas and skilfully brings out the flavours of the top-quality ingredients. The well-coordinated front-of-house team ensures attentive and competent service and the sommelier's recommendations are excellent – the wine list here is impressive.

name: THE VIEW
description: Not surprisingly, the highlight of this elegant and modern restaurant – which bears the same name as the hotel to which it belongs – is its panoramic terrace. Modern and creative cuisine, with a more informal choice available at lunchtime.

name: Tosca
address: Rue de la Mairie 8, Geneva, 1207, Switzerland
description: Tosca, an emblematic address of the Eaux-Vives district, famous for its fountain, takes la cucina very seriously! The interior by a contemporary Italian artist pays a distinctive tribute to the art and culture of the Italian Renaissance in a Florentine-inspired romantic setting. The food is the inspired work of Ivan Baretti, born and bred in Florence, who trained at Arpège in Paris and was a former chef at Il Lago, no less! With a magnificent supporting cast of top-class ingredients, his delicate, refined dishes unveil a strong Tuscan bias and hit the spot every time. Amiable, professional service and knock-out selection of Tuscan wines.

name: OZ
description: OZ, another restaurant by Andreas Caminada, is to be found in the beautiful grounds of Schloss Schauenstein. The name is derived from the Romansh word for "today" and refers to the contemporary food on offer. The entirely vegetarian cuisine is something of a novelty in the star chef's portfolio of eateries. It is made with produce grown in the restaurant's own permaculture garden or sourced from long-standing partners. You will certainly not miss meat as you savour the vibrant and delicate dishes in the extensive set menu. Chef Timo Fritsche injects variety according to what is on offer at the market and is happy to explain the dishes and produce. Diners sit at a U-shaped counter and watch the chefs in action – it's a great place to strike up a conversation.

name: Bad Balgach by Schützelhofer
description: Bernd Schützelhofer is well known for his work in the kitchens of Kronenstübli, in Pontresina, and Paul's, in Widnau. Since late 2020, the Vorarlberg-born chef has been managing this inn steeped in history. Here, diners feast on a truly typical and unpretentious take on classic cuisine; focused entirely on flavour, it is prepared using excellent produce. The chef-patron's style, cultivated over the years, is distinctive and expressive. Friendly hostess Jackie Pedregal, Bernd Schützelhofer's partner, is also on hand front of house. This smart establishment is elegantly done out in a chic and modern style, and boasts a lovely terrace in summer.

name: Neue Taverne
description: Nenad Mlinarevic, who is also the man behind Bauernschänke, has called for reinforcements at the helm of his second Zurich restaurant: Fabian Fuchs, previously of EquiTable, is now head chef at the Neue Taverne. This pleasingly straightforward restaurant is done out in the style of a modern inn. The open kitchen turns out vegetarian cuisine – some of it 100% vegan – that is designed to be shared. The menu features 12 wonderfully creative dishes that change with the seasons – opt for three to four per person. For those who have trouble deciding, there is a surprise menu on offer in the evening. Choose from a selection of organic wines, homemade lemonades and kombuchas to accompany your meal. The service is extremely friendly and well-trained. At lunchtime the choice is more limited, but you will also find one or two dishes from the evening menu.

name: Talvo by Dalsass
description: Martin and Andrea Dalsass are a congenial father-and-son duo: Martin, a longtime dedicated Michelin-starred chef, likes to keep things simple, delivering unfussy dishes that are full of flavour; his son Andrea is the ideal host, with a passion for wine – here you have a fabulous selection to choose from. The beautiful setting is provided by a delightful Engadine farmhouse dating from 1658, which boasts a remarkable culinary history. Talvo successfully brings together cosiness and rustic elegance. Some of the seating is in the gallery overlooking the lower restaurant area. Good to know: both the pretty decorative cows adorning the tables and a range of delicacies are available for purchase. Closed Mon to Tue in summer.

name: KLE
description: Zineb ("Zizi") Hattab proposes something out of the ordinary in her charming pub. Not only is the modern-creative food entirely vegan, but it also draws on interesting Moroccan and Mexican influences. The chef – the daughter of Moroccan immigrants – was born in Spain and grew up in Barcelona. Originally an engineer, she followed her passion for cooking, gaining work experience with Andreas Caminada in Switzerland and in Mexican restaurant Cosme in New York, to name but two. Choose three to five courses for the surprise menu served in the evening. Great importance is attached to regionality and sustainability, and that also applies to the wine.

name: Truube
description: Very inviting from the outside, this typical Appenzell country inn is no less beautiful on the inside. Come here to enjoy Silvia Manser's classic cuisine with Mediterranean influences in a pleasingly simple yet upscale setting. This is a chef who isn't averse to spicing things up, infusing her refined dishes with the perfect balance of potent flavours. It goes without saying that her ingredients are of the highest quality. Silvia Manser runs this place together with her husband Thomas, and the two of them work together like a well-oiled machine: while she is at the helm in the kitchen, he competently and cordially takes care of service, making suitable wine recommendations from their excellent selection.

name: Le Murenberg
description: Denis and Melanie opened Le Murenberg in March 2012, fulfilling their dream of running their own restaurant. He is in charge of the kitchen, while his wife – a pastry chef by profession – is not only the charming head of service, but also takes care of the desserts. As a native of Alsace, the owner feels a close connection to French cuisine – and the "Breton Weeks" in October are well received. His classic dishes, which draw on modern influences, are as much about the excellent craftsmanship as they are about the high-quality produce. Incidentally, the chef hails from a winemaking family, so you can look forward to a splendid selection – the half bottles are definitely a good option.

name: UniQuisine Atelier
description: This restaurant certainly achieves its goal of making guests feel they are "dining at a friend's place". The "unique" location alone ensures this: the relatively small dining area is laid out in a modern apartment done out in a minimalist chic style on the third floor of a residential and restaurant block. A pleasingly informal and intimate atmosphere prevails, not least thanks to the central open kitchen. Diners are in good hands with head chef Christoph Oliver Aebersold and restaurant manager Agron Tunprenkaj – two consummate professionals who provide friendly, high-quality service. The meticulous cuisine is pared down to the essentials and served in the form of a five- or seven-course set menu drawing on excellent, seasonal ingredients. Enjoy an aperitif on the lovely balcony terrace as you take in the view of the Pilatus and Stanserhorn mountains.

name: Sonne
description: The idyllic setting alone makes the trip to this remote hamlet worthwhile. A pretty historical farmhouse bordering fields and meadows is home to this gourmet restaurant, whose stylish yet comfortable decor extends onto the terrace with its pergola and great view of the surrounding greenery. Then there are your warm and friendly hosts, Iris and Kurt Mösching. While the lady of the house adds a personal touch to proceedings front of house, heading up the professional yet appealingly relaxed service team, the chef-patron focuses on producing modern cuisine that draws on classic foundations. He wins diners over with quality ingredients, technical skill and attention to detail. The fabulous wine list boasts some 600 labels. Alternatively, you can order from the excellent bistro menu in the rustic Gaststube.

name: Regina Montium
description: A great place to experience nature untamed – in a sensational location at an altitude of 1 550m! Under the direction of Benedikt Voss, the cuisine is well devised and very technically sophisticated; refined yet brimming with ideas, it steers well clear of gimmicks and ostentation. Only high-quality, mostly organic produce from Switzerland is used, as well as over 400 different herbs from their own garden. Opt for the alcohol-free drink pairings, which include house-made lemonades. Why not book one of the simple but well-kept guestrooms at the Kräuter Hotel Edelweiss, in which the restaurant is located? To get here from Vitznau, take the Rigi-Bahn railway, which stops just outside the building (station: Staffelhöhe).

name: Löwen
description: Tanja and Franco Körperich run this traditional inn – she ensures the warm and friendly service, while he is at the helm in the kitchen. They propose a classically oriented surprise menu that draws on top-notch ingredients. Guests are served in a charming and elegant wood-panelled dining area. You can also dine al fresco in the pretty "stone garden" located on the opposite side of the street.

name: Locanda Orico
description: A focus on sustainability is much more than a simple slogan at this restaurant housed in a historic palazzo in the old town. Since 1998 here, the owner-chef works with excellent local suppliers in order to provide the best possible experience for his guests, talking them through each dish and the provenance of its top-quality ingredients. There’s nothing mysterious about the process, which results in healthy Mediterranean cuisine with a combination of French and regional influences, and where the menu changes at the beginning of each season and the tasting menu every month. Dishes here are carefully presented, with meticulous attention to detail and a perfect combination of colours. An interesting selection of renowned wines adds to its appeal, including an excellent choice of local and international labels. A simpler business menu is available at lunchtime, when dishes are announced at your table. A stronghold of fine Ticino cuisine! The restaurant has recently installed a recharging point for electric cars.

name: Auberge de la Croix Blanche
description: The epitome of calm, serenity and good food. Located in a village called Villarepos, which loosely translates as Restful villa, overlooking Lake Morat, this inn is a haven of the tranquillity that is so emblematic of Switzerland. The flower-decked window boxes, green shutters and white-washed walls and gables of this picture postcard house seem to have stepped straight out of fairy tale… Christa and Arno, who bend over backwards to make you feel at home, usher you into an elegant, wainscoted dining room. Classical cuisine and premium regional produce are the watchwords of the menu, illustrated by consommé of tomatoes and fillets of smoked fera from Lake Mora, or carpaccio of Villarepos rabbit with roasted pine nuts and quail’s egg. An establishment whose chef, Aächerli, quietly feeds us well, thanks to dishes that combine blessed familiarity with flawless execution.

name: GÜTSCH by Markus Neff
description: High up on the Gütsch, at an altitude of 2⁣ 344m above sea level, is this restaurant of the same name, where the team led by head chef Markus Neff as well as trio of restaurateurs Müller, Gruß and Neumüller put their heart and soul into their work. The best place to sit is on the spectacular terrace – you could even call it a viewing platform! And if the weather isn't playing ball, it's just as pleasant to sit inside. The decor is modern and simple, which is entirely in keeping with the informal and relaxed atmosphere and no-nonsense culinary style. The chef became known for classic cuisine at his previous place of work in Saas Fee and here he delivers his French haute cuisine dishes as well as more regional fare – to be enjoyed with wonderful wines. Note: get here by taking the Gütsch Express cable car from the lower terminus.

name: Fahr
description: Clad in Swiss hardwood, the building housing this tasteful restaurant stands right by the recreation area and close to the Reuss River. Chef Manuel Steigmeier skilfully toes the line between classic and modern, resulting in convincing, unpretentious dishes that make an impression. You will find the right pairing on the decent wine list. The intense sauces and delicate desserts are also worth a mention! They use first-class produce, the majority of which comes from Switzerland. The interior is sleek and chic – the impressive designer lamps by the owner's son draw the eye – and outside there is a wonderful terrace. On weekdays there is a simpler menu at lunchtime, and on Saturdays and Sundays some dishes from the evening menu are served.

name: Sushi Shin
description: In the centre of Zurich, right next to the historical Münsterhof square, this compact sushi restaurant is tucked away in a side street. Seated at the counter in a sophisticated yet informal interior, guests are treated to a seasonal omakase menu. The charming proprietress will guide you through the evening (in English), and you can also watch chef Masami Okamoto prepare the sushi. In the evening, the set menu is served at two sittings. At lunchtime, there is also a short sushi and sashimi menu. Whether you prefer wine or sake with your meal, there are some real gems to be had – but with a price tag to match. Be sure to reserve, as the restaurant has only eight seats! Given the location just a stone's throw from the River Limmat, you should not miss the opportunity to take a stroll while you are here.

name: After Seven
description: A lift takes you up to the fine dining restaurant of the Backstage Hotel. After a relaxed aperitif on the comfortable couch stationed beneath an originally designed chandelier made up of musical instruments, you can look forward to a creative surprise menu composed of four to seven courses, which is prepared in the open kitchen by Florian Neubauer's dedicated team. You will be handed a menu listing some of the main ingredients of the evening – it's up to you to just choose the number of courses! The modern and elegant interior is brimming over with artworks – this is the hallmark of the owner, artist and hotelier Heinz Julen. The centrally positioned fireplace also adds atmosphere. You might like to opt for one of the dishes given the finishing touch at your table!

name: Le Flacon
description: A local lass, Marie-Laure Chuard founded this restaurant in 2012 and obtained her first star in just 2013. The loft-inspired dining room sports high ceilings and bare stone walls with splashes of red. Admire the talented team at work in the theatrically visible kitchen as they execute subtle, delicate dishes rich in gutsy flavours and clear, legible aromas that showcase top quality ingredients. Slick, friendly and efficient service. Delightful summertime patio. Quite irresistible!

name: Les Ateliers
description: After having been deserted for some 25 years, this former stainless-steel workshop just behind the railway station has been revived by Jean-Sébastien Ribette and Sahondra Verdan (ex-Auberge de la Veveyse). An off-kilter, smart industrial vibe sets the scene for a superlative culinary show: brasserie fare to the front and more ambitious, surprise menus in the gourmet section. Market availability dictates the menu, hence the freshness of the ingredients. For example, scallops, roasted and tartare, with pumpkin and cloves, roast monkfish in cider butter with textured vegetables, perfectly roasted Bresse pigeon with apple molasses. The desserts are to die for!

name: Verve by Sven
description: This restaurant subscribes to the interesting concept of health-and-lifestyle cuisine, which places the emphasis on sustainability and fair trade. Here, they make a point of using seasonal produce sourced from the local region and are keen to exchange ideas with local growers and producers. Their international produce also comes from sustainable farming. The dishes, which are inspired by nature, can be ordered à la carte or enjoyed as a set menu. Then there is the friendly, attentive and professional service, and the modern and refined decor with its soothing, warm tones and pleasing natural materials – the design also reflects the establishment's connection to nature. The glass-walled wine cellar is particularly elegant.

name: Le Pérolles
description: Chef Pierrot Ayer is the darling of the residents of Fribourg, whom he dazzles with his talent and flair in this elegant, designer venue. Downstairs in a striking contemporary setting, he crafts delicate, high-flying dishes, whose expressive generosity reflects his personality, particularly in his inspired reinterpretations of Gallic classics. At lunchtime, there is a more accessible 3- or 4-course menu and, in the evenings, there is also a vegetarian menu. Splendid cheese trolley. For a “simpler” experience, head upstairs to the bistro-cum-grocery store, le Petit Pérolles, and dig into fresh regional produce in a more casual vibe.

name: La Miranda Gourmet Stübli
description: Complex, elaborate and visually gorgeous – this is how chef Bernd Fabian's dishes come across. His craftsmanship, original ideas and skilful approach to balancing the flavours of his individual ingredients are showcased in dishes such as Norway lobster served with tomato, celery and vanilla cream, purple gnocchi and dashi. The surprise menu, available in three, four or five courses, creates a real sense of anticipation! Here in the beautiful fine dining restaurant of Hotel Chasa Montana, the head chef is apt to head to your table in person and talk you through the story behind his creations. You might like to peruse the very well-put-together wine list, which offers a top-class selection. Your host and sommelier, Daniel Eisner, embodies the passion for wine that the whole team here shares.

name: Principe Leopoldo
description: Situated in a panoramic location outside the town centre, Principe Leopoldo is the gourmet restaurant of a classic-style hotel with an intimate ambience. Whether you’re here for lunch or dinner, enjoy incomparable views of the lake and mountains from the veranda or take a seat in the elegant dining room in winter. The cuisine here is based on solid traditional techniques and prepared from local and (especially) Mediterranean ingredients which are enhanced by delicious sauces. The wine list has something for all tastes, including a selection of memorable vintages.

name: Torkel
description: With its winning combination of historical and modern features, this restaurant has a really appealing look. The dominant feature of the dining room is a lovingly preserved old wine press (or "Torkel" in the local dialect), which blends in well with the modern decor that surrounds it. There is a fantastic conservatory-like dining area to the front, whose walls can be opened up. The gorgeous terrace affords magnificent views of Vaduz and the mountains. Owner Ivo Berger and his team propose a contemporary take on modern cuisine. Presented without fuss or frills, the dishes are replete with first-class produce and harmoniously balanced flavours. An attentive and charming front-of-house team provides excellent wine recommendations.

name: Schlüssel - Nidbergstube
description: A real institution in the canton of St Gallen. Since 1974, the Kalberer family name has been synonymous with exquisite fine dining. Son Roger has now taken over the reins and continues to run the kitchen in the same vein. Dishes brimming with robust flavours are complemented by a fabulous wine list including a decent selection of Swiss wines and an abundance of French labels. Friendly and well-drilled service team. The cosy, refined interior also hits the right notes, with the small Nidbergstube doing full justice to the historical setting of this elegant patrician house dating back to 1811. This restaurant is named after the Nidberg hill in the village, where wine has been grown since the 15C.

name: Le Cigalon
description: Judging by the fresh fish on the menu, you could be forgiven for thinking that this restaurant is on the doorstep of the Brittany coast. For over 20 years, the Bessire couple has been shining the spotlight on produce that comes straight from the fish auctions of Roscoff and Audierne, without forgetting scallops fished by divers in Norway. A dedication to excellence that has earned Le Cigalon star status for some 25 years! Intelligently crafted, generous dishes that highlight first-rate produce. In fine weather, meals are served on the terrace. Table d'hôte meals for five guests, served in the kitchen, can also be booked for an extra special experience.

name: LeMontBlanc
description: The restaurant’s extensive semi-circular windows boast a panoramic view of the Swiss Alps of breath-taking proportions. The subtle, high-flying cuisine merges the very best produce of Switzerland, including treasures from the surrounding countryside, with traditional Gallic recipes that have been treated to a modern spin. Now in charge of the cooking, chef Yannick Crepaux (who trained with Guy Martin and Christian Constant) continues to uphold the establishment’s fine dining ethos, to the delight of the regulars! If the weather is sunny, make a beeline for the terrace, be it summer or winter. Slick, professional service and a stupendous choice of excellent wines by the glass.

name: Wirtshaus Zur Säge
description: The "Sägi" has long been known for its great food, and Michelin-starred chef Patrick Zimmermann, who has been running this long-established inn for years together with his wife Corinne, is continuing this tradition. He prepares classic French cuisine, sets great store by seasonality and has a knack for contrasts and textures. His fine sauces also testify to his cooking skills. Excellent produce forms the basis of his delicious dishes. And the atmosphere? In addition to the cosy, rustic and elegant interior with its wooden panelling and old ceiling beams as well as pictures and pretty floral decorations, there is also the attentive front-of-house team headed up by the charming lady of the house – who will also be happy to recommend wines by the glass. In summer, make a beeline for the charming terrace with its vines and chestnut tree!

name: Alpenblick
description: This quintessential Swiss inn makes for a seriously appealing culinary experience. It is all down to Richard and Yvonne Stöckli, who have been putting their heart and soul into this long-standing establishment since 1980. Friendly and efficient, she heads up the service team in the charming little dining room (judicious wine recommendations from a great selection), while he showcases his skills in the kitchen, conjuring up dishes distinguished by their craftsmanship, quality ingredients and punchy flavours. His interesting modern and seasonal set menu comprises four to seven courses. Delightful garden terrace – ask for one of the seats beneath the old plane tree. Tip: Cheese lovers should try the Nessleren Alpine cheese! The rustic bistro and pretty guestrooms complete this charming picture.

name: Château Attisholz
description: This is a rather grand establishment located just outside Riedholz. A truly splendid historical property houses the exquisitely elegant and tastefully designed fine dining restaurant le feu, with the garden and courtyard outside being a draw in themselves. Chef-patron Jörg Slaschek proposes a sophisticated modern-classical set menu (also available in a vegetarian version), but there is also an à la carte selection. It goes without saying that the Bavarian-born chef uses only select produce. A well-curated selection of European wines makes for the perfect accompaniment to your meal. Overnight accommodation is also available: There are two really appealing guestrooms that fit perfectly into the overall picture of sophistication.

name: Wein & Sein
description: Hostess Daniela Jaun and chef Pascal Melliger (partners both professionally and privately) put their heart and soul into running this pleasant restaurant, nestled in a cellar space with a beautiful vaulted ceiling. The chef cooks modern cuisine with vim and vigour, but also finesse; plus he has a knack for coming up with clever combinations. He uses select produce (preferably produced regionally and sustainably) to prepare an evening set menu comprising four to six courses – a vegetarian version is also available if you pre-order. When it comes to wine, you can rely on the charming and extremely committed young owner to help you choose – her recommendations from the interesting selection are excellent.

name: Sommet by Martin Göschel
description: As if the exclusive The Alpina Gstaad were not an impressive enough hotel, it also comes up trumps with this appealing restaurant. Sommet is something special in several respects: first, there is its distinctive decor, which is an elegant blend of rustic charm and modern elegance; second, the fantastic panoramic terrace and, last but not least, the elaborate seasonal "Signature" set menu created by Martin Göschel. The Mannheim-born chef, who previously earned Michelin stars at the Paradies hotel in Ftan and the Alte Post in Nagold, successfully combines classic cuisine with modern influences. As an alternative to the set menu – which is also available in a vegan version – you can order classics à la carte.

name: I Due Sud
description: Housed within the beautiful Splendide Royal hotel, this small, welcoming restaurant serves gourmet cuisine from Ticino and Calabria, the latter the chef’s native region. The cuisine here is highly technical and full of specialities from the two regions – the use of bergamot, an intensely flavoured citrus fruit, adds an exciting touch to the complex dishes. In the dining room, the excellent maître-sommelier will guide you through the extensive wine list which is full of useful background information, especially on wines from Ticino. Make sure you book ahead to guarantee a table with a view.

name: L'OURS
address: Route du Pas de l'Ours 41, Crans-Montana, 3963, Switzerland
description: A modern, stylish vibe, depicted by high-quality fixtures and fittings and a profusion of wood and stone, sets the alpine tone of this luxurious mountain venue. The quality of the ingredients is equally superlative and chef Franck Reynaud reverently respects the seasons. His classical recipes with a modern twist are proposed in a surprise menu of 5 to 8 courses. Enticing list of Valais wines. The slick service is as smooth as a silky béarnaise sauce without being stuffy or starched.

name: Zur Gedult
description: This place goes to show that a simple setting and upscale cuisine don't have to be mutually exclusive. In one of the oldest inns in Burgdorf (dating back to 1716), diners sit at bistro tables in a pleasingly relaxed and informal atmosphere and are waited on by a friendly, professional and well-organised service team. The building may be historical, but the menu proposes contemporary cuisine. This is the domain of Lukas Kiener. The young chef has a modern and creative culinary style that sets great store by using seasonal produce that is sourced from the region. A four- to six-course menu is on offer, and for those who would rather skip the meat, there is also an alternative vegetarian set menu.

name: La Table du Valrose
address: Place de la Gare 2, Rougemont, 1659, Switzerland
description: Some 1 000m above sea level, in the triangle formed by the cantons of Fribourg, Bern and Waad, this restaurant takes you to heights of culinary enjoyment and refinement. Surrounded by a magnificent mountain landscape, the chic decor is an artful blend of Alpine wood, contemporary furnishings and designer lamps, chef Benoît Carcenat creates modern and seasonal French cuisine that embraces both tradition and innovation. He astutely makes sure to highlight produce from the Pays-d'Enhaut, Saanenland and Intyamon, so many ingredients that are locally produced in the mountain air! List of 700 different wines for you to choose from.

name: Stéphane Décotterd
description: Exquisitely located on the heights of Montreux, the restaurant of the Glion Institute of Higher Education commands a fantastic view of Lake Geneva and the mountains. The interior is modern and elegant and the slick, friendly service is under the watchful eye of Stéphanie Décotterd. In the kitchen, Stéphane Décotterd consummately conjures up uncomplicated, no-frills cuisine, starring premium Swiss produce.

name: Alpenblick - Stuba
description: Alpenblick proposes two exciting dining options: there is the lively bistro, where you can tuck into down-to-earth cuisine such as steak tartar or Wiener schnitzel, or you can head to Stuba for its ambitious, high-quality set menu of four to seven courses, including vegetarian options. Here, chef-patron Björn Inniger serves up cosmopolitan modern fare, sourcing much of the produce from the region. His dishes feature subtle nuances, bold contrasts, and they are packed with flavour. The atmosphere is pleasantly laid back, and the setting is warm and welcoming with a touch of elegance. Friendly and attentive service comes courtesy of the charming waitstaff.

name: Du Cerf
description: Established in the heart of the peaceful village of Sonceboz, this establishment is a culinary landmark in what is known as the Jura Arc and also throughout Switzerland. Chef Jean-Marc Soldati, at the helm for many years now, has played a major role in the restaurant’s success. Jean-Marc, who boasts a spell at “Crissier” with Fredy Girardet and Philippe Rochat, is nothing if not serious about tradition. His consummate classical cooking calls mainly on local and French produce, whilst also delving freely into the chef’s own cottage garden. A splendid selection of regional, Swiss and French wines, including by the glass.

name: Neue Blumenau
description: What a lovely place! This is largely down to two factors: first, the wonderfully stylish and modern setting in this pretty inn that is typical of the region, along with its gorgeous wisteria-covered terrace and idyllic garden, and second, your dedicated and charming hostess, Bernadette Lisibach. Not only does she have an appealingly warm and natural manner (she heads out of the kitchen to assist the friendly and attentive front-of-house team), but she also pours that same commitment into her cooking. Her various set menus put the spotlight on quality produce and seasonality. And that is no coincidence, seeing as she grew up on a farm. This is classic cuisine replete with Mediterranean influences that eschews any unnecessary frills. To round off your meal, try the excellent selection of Swiss cheeses.

name: L'Etoile - Nova
description: This nova star brings the promise of impeccably judged and delicately balanced cuisine by a subtle, talented chef in a warm décor of untreated wood, enhanced by delightful service. Devised by Alexandra Müller, the carte and menus reverently keep pace with the seasons, changing regularly in line with market availability, thus guaranteeing fresh flavours and an element of surprise that is appreciated by the regulars. Let’s not forget the bistronomic-inspired brasserie in the same establishment which specialises in well-crafted, feelgood regional classics.

name: Bayview by Michel Roth
description: With its thoughtfully designed urban chic vibe and jaw-dropping lake view, the President Wilson’s restaurant offers an idyllic setting to sample the bang-on yet delicate dishes of chef Michel Roth, MOF and Bocuse d’Or with stints at the Ritz and Lasserre. Michel creatively adds a new twist to polished French classics, such as Swiss Beef Rossini, silver thorny cardoon and Périgueux sauce or curry flavoured crab from Brittany served with Sologne caviar – exquisitely and intelligently modern.

name: Chesa Stüva Colani
description: Absolutely up to the minute in technical terms, Paolo Casanova's cooking is elaborate and anything but "off the peg". This is a chef who is extremely dedicated to his cause, seeking inspiration in the region and the seasons, gathering and growing his own herbs, fermenting and pickling... All of which gives the dishes a personal touch as well as extremely interesting nuances of flavour. The setting in this gem of a hotel is fantastic too. The restaurant showcases an exquisite blend of warm, local wood furnishings and elegant minimalist design. The upmarket and stylish guestrooms with their chalet charm are fully in keeping with the atmosphere. As an alternative to the fine dining restaurant, there is also a bistro.

name: Schlüssel
description: A meal here is a real pleasure, thanks to Felix Suter and Sandra Marugg Suter, who are truly passionate about what they do – he in the kitchen, she front of house. There are no menus: your extremely cordial hostess will acquaint you with the set menu and explain the dishes. Always on hand, she has a delightfully natural way with guests. Chef-patron Felix Suter (who might be familiar from Säge in Flüh) shows the same passion in his cooking, delivering down-to-earth dishes that prize one thing above all else: flavour! His cooking draws on classical foundations and spurns fleeting modern trends. At lunchtime, a three-course lunch set menu is served. Lovely garden terrace.

name: La Rôtisserie
description: Located on the first floor of the Hotel Storchen, La Rôtisserie is every bit as tastefully decorated as the establishment that houses it – which was first mentioned in the 14C. It has a beautiful dining room with high ceilings, large arched windows and elegant, high-quality furnishings – this is a traditional yet contemporary affair. In the kitchen, the chefs work with precision and great skill to produce their own modern, international take on classic cuisine. In fine weather, be sure to head out onto the fantastic terrace – from this wonderful old-town location you can take in views of the Limmat River and the historical buildings laid out on the other side of the water.

name: Aqua
description: The Alex Lake Zürich hotel enjoys a fantastic location by Lake Zurich, meaning that its intimate restaurant also boasts a gorgeous view. Given that the restaurant seats just 14 diners per service, do book in advance if you wish to treat yourself to their modern menu of four to seven courses. Chef Michael Schuler was previously Stefan Heilemann's sous-chef at Widder, the restaurant at the partner hotel of the same name. Some dishes have international influences, others are based on classic French cuisine, and the produce is excellent. Experienced service team, and from time to time the dishes are also announced by the chefs. The wine list includes labels from The Living Circle (of which the hotel is a member).

name: Eden Kitchen & Bar
description: "Upscale brasserie" is a good description of this restaurant in the elegant hotel La Réserve Eden au Lac. The atmosphere is relaxed, the interior chic and elegant, and the focal point is the visible green-tiled kitchen… not forgetting the windowed front overlooking the lake! Classic Italian, French and internationally influenced cuisine is concocted by a professional team from Italy. They operate under the direction of Marco Ortolani, previously at the Tuscan Trattoria Enrico Bartolini, as well as Alain Ducasse in London and Hong Kong. For fans of the classics, there are also dishes such as Zürcher Geschnetzeltes (stew) with sweetbreads. In addition, the front-of-house staff are well-trained. Take your pick from an exclusive wine selection or great cocktails.

name: L'Aparté
description: The Hotel Royal is home to a minimalist, Lilliputian restaurant with seating for only 15. Take a seat at one of the four tables and let yourself be guided. The chef personally serves his elegant, delicately crafted dishes, taking the time to describe and explain the ins and outs of each ingredient. A culinary pageant of outstanding produce including Swiss veal and beef, fish straight from Brittany and Bresse poultry, at the service of food sodden with rippling ambition and character. Book well ahead, particularly in the evenings as the handful of tables are snapped up fast. Bogie’s Bar next-door is ideal to begin or finish this superlative fine dining experience.

name: Locanda Barbarossa
description: Food-lovers and fans of elegant gourmet dining will be in their element at this restaurant, which is one of the best in Ticino. Made from seasonal produce (much of which comes from the restaurant’s own land), Mattias Roock’s cuisine is a successful mix of local dishes and Mediterranean influences which nonetheless remains fundamentally rooted in classic recipes, both on the à la carte and on his two delicious tasting menus. Our inspectors also highlighted the pleasant, tranquil ambience of the setting and the wide choice of wines offered by sommelier Sergio Bassi. Excellent service.

name: Du Bourg
description: This 16C town house is one of Biel's architectural monuments. After careful renovations, it became the premises of this restaurant run by Fiona Liengme and Christian Aeby, both of whom previously worked at the restaurant Eisblume, in Worb. They serve vegetable-based cuisine that is full of finesse; you can opt to add in freshwater fish or selected meat from Switzerland, or stick with the set menu in its vegetarian version. Wherever possible, produce from the immediate vicinity is used. The manager has up her sleeve interesting wine recommendations and tasty non-alcoholic accompaniments made on site. It also has a fantastic "aperitif cellar", which dates back to the 12C.

name: Njørden
description: In addition to an exquisite boutique hotel, “Hemma” and the “Njørd Café”, Philippe Deslarzes also owns a gourmet restaurant, “Njørden “, where he mingles Swiss and Swedish influences. His cooking is modern and highly contrasted, featuring many regional as well as Scandinavian ingredients and culinary techniques. The service is enthusiastic and professional, as is the savvy sommelier.

name: Le Chat-Botté
description: This amusingly named restaurant (‘Puss in Boots’) is set in one of Lake Geneva’s luxury hotels (the Beau-Rivage) which sports a blend of Art nouveau and baroque styles. The culinary focus is on polished French fare tailored to modern appetites: pike quenelles, imperial caviar and green asparagus, arctic char from Lake Geneva, line-caught trout with fleur de sel and beetroot juice. French chef Dominique Gauthier, with spells in the company of the likes of Joe Rostang, Fernand Point, Georges Blanc and Jacques Chibois, signs this consummate culinary score. Local producers are regularly highlighted on the menu and the entire feast is exquisitely enhanced by the competent sommelier who guides you through the stonking 1,400-bin wine list.

name: EquiTable
description: Here it's all about sustainability. Fairtrade, organic and – wherever possible – locally sourced produce is used to create imaginative dishes featuring innovative combinations that are full of expression and punchy flavours. The set menu composed of four to seven courses also comes in a vegetarian version. In addition to fine wines, you can opt for alcohol-free pairings in the form of high-quality juices. In keeping with the modern cuisine, this small corner restaurant has an appealingly pared-down interior. Indeed its urban and international feel attracts many younger guests. The front-of-house team is extremely attentive while remaining unobtrusive. Some of the dishes are brought to the table by the chefs themselves, who talk you through the ideas behind them.

name: Wirtschaft im FRANZ
description: Etwas versteck in einem Innenhof liegt das «Franz» - der Name steht für «Frauen im Zentrum» und ist ein Ort für Kultur, Arbeit und Essen. Letzteres bietet man in der «Wirtschaft im Franz» in Form eines durchdachten Überraschungsmenüs. Die ambitionierten modern-kreativen Speisen sind angenehm reduziert und legen den Fokus auf Produktqualität, wobei Gemüse im Mittelpunkt steht. Schön auch das Ambiente dazu: Mit seiner offenen Küche und dem trendigen Bistro-Stil versprüht das Restaurant eine sympathisch-unkomplizierte, freundliche und urbane Atmosphäre.

name: La Micheline
address: Avenue de la Gare des Eaux-Vives 3, Geneva, 1207, Switzerland
description: This restaurant opposite the new station sports a magnificent bistronomy concept over two floors. The Mediterranean cuisine has been stripped of superfluous frills so shine the spotlight on the ingredient and flavour. The service is as smooth as a bearnaise sauce and the vibe is smart and upmarket. La Micheline refers to the first train from Annemasse to Eaux-Vives – equipped with Michelin tyres.

name: Le Pont de Brent
description: Chef Antoine Gonnet, who had a MICHELIN star at Le 42 restaurant (in Champéry in the Chablais region), has now set up shop in the heights of Montreux, in a legendary establishment that has been newly refurbished. He serves two tasting menus that change every month according to his inspiration and the season. Amandine Pivault, his partner, takes care of the service and welcomes customers cordially and professionally. The terrace is the ideal spot for an aperitif or a coffee, with the sound of a babbling brook in the background.

name: Damien Germanier
description: After consulting with tattooed chef Damien Germanier as to the number of courses of our meal (4-10), we then give him carte blanche. His culinary hallmark reveals a strong weakness for veggies and a creative streak that hits the spot every time. You can expect to taste inventive, bold, even surprising dishes in a stripped-back setting, adorned with striking photos that is as off-kilter, vibrant and buzzy as the food and its chef. Slick, yet unstuffy service.

name: Gasthaus Zum Gupf
description: Perched 1 083m above sea level and reached by a steep, narrow path, this place is a little slice of heaven! The pretty inn with a wood-panelled interior exudes regional charm and boasts a view of the mountains or the lake, plus a wonderful terrace. Walter Klose cooks up aromatic classic cuisine that follows the seasons and combines finesse with a certain unpretentiousness. When it comes to the service, you are in good hands thanks to the excellent team led by the lady of the house, who serves diners with a warm and easy manner. The wine list is sensational – a tour of the wine cellar with over 30 000 bottles is a real experience! You can also spend the night in the pleasant guesthouse.

name: Sternen - Badstube
description: Located in the sleepy town of Wangen, this pretty inn with its attractive 16C barrel vault is a wonderful meeting of the historical and the modern. A committed couple have been plying their trade here since 2005 – Matthias Brunner is in charge in the kitchen, while Bettina Brunner-Schill oversees the friendly front-of-house team. Choose between the seasonal tasting menu (omnivore or vegetarian option) and classic dishes, made with only the finest ingredients. Savvy wine recommendations. The cosy, rustic-style Gaststube, serving traditional cuisine, is a nice alternative to Badstube. Comfortable guestrooms at Gasthof Sternen.

name: Krone
description: This long-established restaurant is all about Italian food, and this is entirely down to Samuel Carugati. The young chef takes it right back to basics, a philosophy that extends to the pleasingly unostentatious presentations. The classic sauces are elegant and have great depth of flavour, which, along with the subtle aromas, hints at the French foundations of the dishes. In short, the chef combines the best of Italian and classical cuisine, and does so using excellent-quality produce. The attractive interior comprises charming dining spaces, and the cordial front-of-house team overseen by proprietor Fabio Rovisi provide competent and attentive service. Very good wine list including numerous large-format bottles.

name: Eatanic Garden
address: 36F Josun Palace Hotel, 231 Teheran-ro, Gangnam-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: Eatanic Garden is a wordplay since, amusingly, both “botanic garden” and “eatanic garden” are pronounced the same way in Korean. As the name suggests, the space evokes a beautiful urban garden that awakens the five senses. There is no menu here; instead, you'll receive an illustrated guide depicting the main ingredients. Chef Son Jong-won, who is also the head chef at L’Amant Secret, helms the kitchen, reinventing Korean food with a creative twist and reflecting the aesthetics of fermentation and aging. Eatanic Garden offers seats for couples providing a commanding view of the cityscape from the 36th floor.

name: Ilpan
address: 2F Cheongdam square B side, 420 Dosan-daero, Gangnam-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: This eatery embodies art on a sizzling griddle heated to 130–180 °C. Ilpan is a restaurant where cooking at precise temperatures meets visual delight for ultimate culinary pleasure. Using Korean, Japanese, and Western cooking techniques, the chef creates a multitude of menu items. Since every section of the counter has its own griddle, each diner can enjoy their meal at their own tempo. From the chef’s pre-dining introduction of ingredients to his cooking unfolding right in front of you, each step of the culinary process at Ilpan makes your gastronomic journey that much more adventurous.

name: KANG MINCHUL Restaurant
address: B1F, 18 Dosan-daero 68-gil, Gangnam-gu, Seoul, 06064, South Korea
description: Chef Kang Min-chul has been greatly inspired by time spent with master chefs, instilling in him a pride and passion for cuisine and culinary philosophy. It's also helped him find his own direction and the fare at this namesake restaurant genuinely reflects his attitude toward gastronomy. The menu comprises dishes offering a kaleidoscope of flavors while highlighting the diversity of refined French cuisine. The restaurant’s small space makes reservations a challenge, but once you secure a table, prepare to be rewarded with an unforgettable dining experience.

name: Kojacha
description: Kojacha — Korean (“Ko”) chefs’ Japanese (“ja”) and Chinese (“cha”) cuisine. The shared culinary ambition of Chefs Choi Yu-gang and Jo Yeong-du, who previously cooked at The Shilla Hotel, has given rise to a distinct culinary genre. From its vintage lighting and furniture from the 50s and 60s that creates a singular vibe to a course meal that alternately features Chinese and Japanese dishes, this is a true icon. Signature dishes include chilled abalone salad, served in a replica of the peacock-shaped soap dish used by an empress of the Qing Dynasty, and shark fin braised in thick Chinese Superior Stock. The chefs’ performance-inspired table is a veritable display of their culinary narratives and enriches the eatery’s appeal. All dining spaces are in the form of private rooms.

name: Soul
address: B1F, 35 Sinheung-ro 26-gil, Yongsan-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: Located in a quaint part of Seoul, this operation is Chef Yun Dae-hyun’s bold experiment in stylish fine dining. Here, the diverse culinary traditions and ingredients one may encounter in modern-day Korea converge with the familiar tastes found in everyday life to form unique fusion creations. Among the many connotations of the establishment’s name is the chef’s desire to serve soul-filled food, and this is palpable in every dish. Along with his wife, Chef Kim Hee-eun, this husband-and-wife duo have partitioned their establishment into several distinct sections, creating impeccable dining spaces for disparate cuisines.

name: L'Amant Secret
address: 26F L'Escape Hotel, 67 Toegye-ro, Jung-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: Located on the 26th floor of L'Escape Hotel, L'Amant Secret (French for secret lover) is an intimate space inspired by Parisian sensibilities. Chef Son Jong-won, who honed his culinary chops in the United States, strives for a style which he refers to as Korean-style Western cuisine. His modern interpretations are based on local ingredients blended with Western cooking techniques, resulting in creations that are both original and familiar, respectful of the symbiosis between the producer and the ingredients as well as the kitchen and the diner.

name: Exquisine
description: Chef Jang Kyung-won at Exquisine has a knack for reinventing flavors. His creativity is driven by his knowledge of local ingredients and understanding of the balance between each component, which leads to dishes that are ultimately his own invention. The restaurant offers a single course menu for lunch and dinner that changes frequently depending on the availability of ingredients. The fresh herbs are from the restaurant's garden. The space is small so make sure you call ahead to reserve a table.

name: Sushi Matsumoto
description: [This is the new address updated as the restaurant moved.] Chef Matsumoto Mizuho is renowned for replicating authenticity in local settings. Rather than chasing after gastronomic trends, this sushiya strives to faithfully reproduce the authentic sushi of mainland Japan amidst the Korean milieu. Such efforts are unmistakable—from the composition and arrangement of shari (rice) and neta (fish topping) to the knowledgeable service provided. The impressive line of tsumami (appetizers) and the progression of nigiri sushi —reflecting the natural cadence of flavors — remain the main culinary appeal.

name: Myomi
address: 5F Arario Space, 83 Yulgok-ro, Jongno-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: Myomi’s second act, set in a gorgeous space with a view of Changdeokgung Palace, is an experience that diners eagerly await. Chef Kim Jeong-muk's use of Korean ingredients and cooking techniques remain unchanged, but the chef has added subtle new inflections to his dishes as the venue’s name Myomi (“subtle charm”) fittingly suggests. To sample these modern touches, opt for the restaurant's punch—a mixture of fruit syrup, radish water kimchi broth, as well as fresh fruit like peach and watermelon.

name: Solbam
description: Visit Solbam to enjoy modern cuisine that offers an outstanding balance of tastes, aromas and flavors. Here, Chef Eom Tae-jun’s wide range of culinary experience and expertise meet Korean elements. His study of local ingredients (guided by his respect for nature and Korea’s four seasons) and his knowledge of Korean cooking techniques culminate in an uncanny synergy that gives rise to the restaurant’s unique modern dishes. With each course, the chef’s passion and exemplary effort delivera singularly rewarding gastronomic experience to guests.

name: Onjium
description: The elegant stonewalled-path of Gyeongbokgung Palace and a modern residential neighborhood stand directly across from each other. A road is all that lies between Seoul's past and present, coexisting side by side. The same contrast is, again, evident in the modern façade of Onjieum Matgongbang and elements of tradition one discovers inside. Helmed by Cho Eun-hee, certified trainee of Korean royal court cuisine, and researcher Park Seong-bae, the space is both a research institute and restaurant. The food it offers clearly reflects the four distinct seasons and the refined beauty of Korean cuisine.

name: Bicena
address: 81F Lotte World Tower, 300 Olympic-ro, Songpa-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: Towering above Seoul on the 81st floor of the Signiel Seoul Hotel, Bicena is trying to stay true to the spirit of traditional Korean fine dining. Bicena continues to respect the most fundamental details of slow Korean cuisine such as Jang (fermented sauces) and kimchi, the outcome of time and nature doing their work. The views from the restaurant - officially the tallest traditional restaurant in the world - are unrivaled.

name: L'Amitié
description: Since 2006, Chef Jang Myoung-sik has welcomed diners with his consistently warm and comforting French cuisine. At this new location, Jang continues to serve up his passion for French cooking on a plate. Signature dishes include steamed Wando abalone served with abalone intestine espuma, fragrant garlic purée and pickled celery as well as crispy saffron arancini.

name: 7th Door
description: Chef Kim Dae-chun’s cooking continues to diversify and deepen over time. The menu at this restaurant embodies the culinary direction he wishes to pursue, largely thanks to his modern Korean preparations. Under the theme of fermentation and aging, the essential attributes of Korean gastronomy, the chef prepares ingredients with care and expertise. The 7th Door symbolises a gastronomic entrance to “the seven tastes of food,” the first five being the five basic tastes; the sixth, the taste of fermentation and aging; and the seventh, the culinary sensibility of the chef.

name: YUN
description: [This restaurant is temporarily closed.] Walk past the bustling streets near Hongik University subway station, Here you will find Yun Seoul—on the second floor of a renovated house. The space has adopted a lab-like design, and therefore, features a wide array of cooking utensils as well as fermented ingredients. The Korean cuisine is an intriguing mixture of the familiar and bold, with each dish showcasing the inherent flavors of products and reflecting the chef’s firm belief in cooking from scratch using only fresh, raw ingredients. In particular, the house-made perilla oil noodles and dishes cooked with fish fermented on-site, highlight the culinary direction. One can experience the delicate yet robust nature of Korean food in this spot that flaunts a one-of-a-kind charm unseen in other conventional dining rooms.

name: HANE
description: When it comes to gastronomy, savoring the freshest natural ingredients that capture the essence of the season is undoubtedly one of the greatest delights. At Sushi Hane, Chef Choi Ju-yong’s quest for natural ingredients is well reflected and can be fully appreciated. When making sushi, he focuses on bringing out the inherent flavor of each product and recreating authentic tastes. The fare itself exudes a unique charm during the entire culinary process – from selecting ingredients to serving sushi to patrons – and genuinely reflects the chef’s gastronomic beliefs. Relishing this food in an elegant fine dining space decorated with modern interpretations of traditional materials also adds to the overall allure.

name: Soseoul Hannam
address: B1F, 21-18 Hannam-daero 20-gil, Yongsan-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: Inspired by local culinary traditions but dedicated to expressing the modern-day sensibilities of Seoul cuisine, Soseoul Hannam serves up contemporary Korean food using ingredients that are most familiar to the local palate. The chef's creations are an homage to some of the more typical dishes and preparation techniques, including seasoned salads, pan-fried and braised dishes. Kelp chips, rich soybean paste stew, sliced raw fish with gomchwi (Fischer's ragwort) and aged kimchi, and chargrilled webfoot octopus are some of its signature offerings. The restaurant also offers traditional liquor pairings.

name: Goryori Ken
description: This intimate setting, with the main bar seating only eight, allows patrons to watch the chef's every movement. The eponymous restaurant has opened its second chapter in a new location. While preserving its unassuming façade on the second floor of the premises, Chef Kim Geon showcases highly seasonal ingredients in creations inspired by the freshness of the produce and his own creative intuition. Consistency and care are things Kim takes very seriously when serving his customers. The drinks menu features an impressive variety of sake produced by small Japanese breweries.

name: Restaurant Allen
address: 2F Center field EAST E205, 231 Teheran-ro, Gangnam-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: Chef Allen Suh has opened a restaurant named after his name.  The chef and his veteran culinary team create dishes, based on seasonal ingredients, that illustrate the beauty of Korea’s four seasons. His mastery in utilizing a wide variety of tableware for the art of plating adds visual delight to the restaurant’s delicate flavors. In particular, diverse amuse-bouches served on a wooden tray, such as a small pie topped with caviar and smoked sturgeon, beetroot hardened with gelatin, and flavorful horse mackerel aged with kelp, are amongst the gastronomic wonders that change seasonally. Ice cream made with 24 month-aged Parmigiano-Reggiano, blue cheese puree, and other scrumptious dishes are dinner-only specialties. Chef Suh’s new culinary venue is roomier than his previous one, has a wine bar, and offers a pasta menu. Be sure to check it out!

name: Mitou
description: From the simple elegant interior to the refined details that highlight the seasonality of the menu, chefs Kwon Young-woon and Kim Bo-mi are devoted to providing their customers with an authentic Japanese dining experience. The omakase menu at Mitou changes on a monthly basis as they showcase some of the best local ingredients at the height of their freshness. The restaurant's two signature courses are the soup dish owan and the seasonal rice dish gohan. The warm and engaging nature of the chefs, meticulously plating up the dishes behind the open counter, is part of the restaurant's charm.

name: Muoki
description: South African dialect for oak tree, Muoki is Chef Park Moo-hyun’s restaurant. The name is a nod to the chef’s cosmopolitan background as well as his straightforward attitude when it comes to cooking. Park has a knack for incorporating new cooking methods into creating a mélange of unpredictable flavors and textures. Tomatoes seven ways, five different kinds of carrot-based desserts, and his take on Jeju-style hairtail and pumpkin soup are good examples of his creativity and insight. Be sure to book ahead.

name: Pierre Gagnaire
address: 35F Lotte Hotel, 30 Eulji-ro, Jung-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: Internationally celebrated French Chef Pierre Gagnaire opened his eponymous contemporary fine dining restaurant on top of Lotte Hotel’s New Wing in 2008. The elegant dining space, adorned with Murano chandeliers and gold trim walls, exudes classic French luxury. The artfully presented food, made with 80% local ingredients, is respectful of the Paris-based chef’s creative style. With more than 250 labels, the wine cellar display also impresses.

name: Muni
description: Tucked away in a back alley of glitzy Cheongdam-dong, Muni is helmed by Chef Kim Dong-wook, who started working in kitchens to make ends meet. To quench his growing thirst for knowledge in Japanese cuisine, Kim left for Japan to hone his skills, which would one day lay the foundation for this restaurant. To describe his style of cooking as textbook kaiseki is overkill, but his respect for tradition is evident, including in the way he utilizes seasonal ingredients and the way he plates his creations. The chef is a certified sake sommelier (Kikisake-shi), so ask for recommendations.

name: Zero Complex
description: [This is the new address updated as the restaurant moved.] Increasingly assertive and self-assured, the evolution of Zero Complex is founded on Chef Lee Chung-hu’s philosophy that balance and harmony hold the key to great food. The outcome of his approach to cooking is authentic and creative dishes, served in a near-sterile space that provides the blank canvas for Chef Lee’s inventions.

name: Evett
description: After years of traveling, researching and cooking, Australian native Joseph Lidgerwood settled in Seoul. His fascination with local ingredients serves as the main inspiration behind the inventive offerings. Take, for example, the dish "Freshwater Snails": blended to a purée-like consistency served atop a perilla leaf with cream sauce and custard made of wild mushrooms. Lidgerwood constantly pushes the boundaries of how a given ingredient should be cooked and further elevates the dining experience with traditional liquor pairings.

name: Araka
address: Kapalı Bakkal Sokak No:8, Yeniköy/Sarıyer, Istanbul, 34277, Türkiye
description: Here you’ll find it's easy to forget you're in the metropolis of Istanbul. You’re actually in the Yeniköy district, in the north of the city, just beyond the exclusive marina you pass on the way (taking the Bosphorus ferry over is a must). Behind its charming façade, this rural-style restaurant awaits with its cosy, romantic interior and a terrace to the rear where you feel cut off from the world. This enchanting spot perfectly suits Zeynep Pınar Taşdemir's highly individual style. Seasonal ingredients are showcased on the menu.
